author: Emily
title: Disappointing
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content: I'm disappointed with the plot. It seems more like fan fiction than a piece written by the original author. I love Harry Potter and was hoping it would add to the story, but I feel like it has just retroactively twisted the original characters and plot lines into something unrecognizable.

author: Gabie Kim♥books
title: The most disappointing book in history... Make your own worlf.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
I usually avoid critisizing books. Especially books I love. But this.....I hate it. It totally ruined my imagination. Ruined my image of the kids, even Harry, Hermione, Ron, Ginny, etc. Everyone. Albu is so obnoxious. Annoying. I was so determined to love him... instead I love Scorpious Malfoy, and I was determined to hate him. I don't like how Hermione and Harry's work positions changed. I don't like the writing style. I hate most of the characters. Especially Albus. Grrrrrrrrrr!!!!!! I will give this 0 stars if I can. I wanted to cry when I finished-I almost cried because the story was beyond awful. Beyond horrible. Ack. My mood necklace was on stressed all day. And it is very hard to get that black color. It spoiled my Harry Potter world perfectly. I put it in a corner so I can't see it again. I developed a trauma. Seriously. DON'T READ THIS. Better read this to your worst enemy.
*SPOILERS*
I knew it was a bad omen since Albus went into Slytherin. I sniffled when Albus was horrible at Quidditch. I threw the book across my room when the horrible time turner showed up. I almost threw myself out of the window when I realized Delphi was the daughter of Voldemort. Wasn't Voldemort unable to love?! Ew, just ew. Bad fanfic.
*End of spoilers*
I wish J.K. Rowling was not part of it. I wish I could Obliviate myself. But no. No. It just sucks. A hot mess. I love J.K. Rowling best of all authors, but sorry. I can't let this past. It is a insult to the Potter family. I'm just going to forget it and make my own Harry Potter world. Where everyone is happy. No obnoxious Albus, just the nice Gryffindor kid Albus I invented. The know it all but kind, understanding Rose instead of the cold one. The Gryffindor Scorpious. The silver trio. Please, just end it from the epilouge, fellow Potterheads. Make up your own world. It will be better. If you have it in your hands, chuck it out of the window. Or read it to your worst enemy. Your Draco Malfoy. That will be the wisest thing to do. And I will stop ranting. I'm going to throw Al out from my head. Make your own world, fans, I beg you. Don't spoil the memory of the great Harry Potter we love, and all our other favorite fans.

author: Zachary Christman
title: I want to unread this
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2016
content: This play was horrible. Part 1 was completely unnecessary, and Part 2 wasn't much better. It was like Back to the Future and Harry Potter had a deformed, unwanted baby...perhaps that is the true reason why it is called "The Cursed Child."

author: Kelly
title: It reads like poorly written fanfiction
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 7, 2016
content: I think everyone basically covered it here. It reads like poorly written fanfiction. :( SO disappointed.

author: gwen doyle
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content: Boring.

author: Deik017
title: The first nail in the coffin of a once perfect series of books.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2018
content:
The beginning of the end, of what was once a perfect series.

This book would be fine if it was a non-cannon silly little children's play, but this is certified by Rowling herself, so it's an abomination.

The characters are all inconsistent with what has been established. The plot is a excuse to have "Harry Potter and the Greatest Hits Collection" on stage. The twist is bland, uninspired and illogical. The book makes a major mistake by bringing back the time-turner, something J.K herself has said was a problem because of the plot holes it created. Well now we have a book consisting of nothing but plot holes!

Like I said, if your kids want to see the play, fine, they will enjoy it. However, as a die-hard adult HP fan it breaks my heart to see such a cheap product pass itself off as Harry Potter.

author: Xeno
title: It's Missing the Magic
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 23, 2016
content: I have read many plays that I have enjoyed so the problem with this, for me, is not that it's a play.  The problem is consistency within the narrative.  Many established characters act in a way that seems out-of-character.  The new characters aren't developed particularly well and often state things that should be apparent to the viewers/readers without being stated (how many times to actual friends discuss the fact that they're best friends?). A first year college English class will tell you why it is better to show the reader details about your characters' personalities/actions rather than just blatantly telling them. There were some things that happen that actually broke rules/events set in the actual Harry Potter Series, but I won't discuss what they actually were in order to avoid spoilers.  I know that J.K. Rowling didn't actually write this, but given that she endorsed it, I was really expecting a lot more from this.

author: Amanda Kruse
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2016
content: Reads like it was written by a teenage fan

author: Joshua T.
title: Spoiler! This book blows. Don't buy.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content: Complete rubbish. Don't waste your time or money.

author: Francisco Cerbino
title: Deplorable.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
It is disastrous. Idiotic. A lack of respect for the readers, and the public who'll see the play. I can't imagina the amount of money JK is getting to permit such a outrageous mutilation to the continuation of the story.
This script doesn't deserve the "HP Series 8" title. It has nothing to do with it. It's just a marketing strategy (not to mention it's not definitive, since it's a "special rehearsal edition").
It's nothing to do with the previous writing, neither. Miserable plot. It's got a continuous lack of intrigue, it doesn't generate any interest while reading.

SPOILERS

They're only excuses to cast all the characters on the play. Fan fiction'd have done better, really.
It's really disappointing, specially due to the fact it's "co-writed" by Rowling.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Disappointing to Say the Least
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content: I am an avid Potter fan and I knew this was going to be a script but the excitement was lost with the dry writing and how some things didn't align with what happened previously. I am still on act one and can't even force myself to read it. It's disappointing to say the least and a waste of money if you are a true fan of the previous 7 books.

author: Lauren M. Eilenberg
title: Disappointed.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: The anticipation of this book was high. Being a life long lover of all things Harry Potter, I couldn't wait to start reading. My sister bought the book, so like our childhood tradition- she got to read it first. I took the book and read the first couple scenes, and then I put it down. I was very disappointed that it was written as a play. The characters that I grew up with no longer seemed like themselves. I gave the book back to my sister and said I can wait. I think the fact that this made it to the best seller list is the sheer fact that it's got Harry Potter in the title and Rowling's name attached. Maybe the play is great, as I've heard. But I don't have the luxury of traveling abroad to see it. Maybe one day, my idea will change. But all in all, I'm disappointed with the outcome having waited so long.

author: Tyggie
title: This is NOT a Rowling book.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content: Falsely marketed in my opinion.  Marketed as a new book, a new generation of Harry Potter for months prior to it's availability and only the last week of July was it admitted that this was a script. It is NOT written by Rowling, it is written by Thorne based on a Rowling story written with two others.  Even the cover image shows "J.K. Rowling" prominently displayed.  Nor do I recall the blurb about it being a script on the description when I first added it to my Wish List and later ordered the book. Why not print the story instead? Then you receive the actual product and learn the truth. The script is thin and double spaced.  It lacks the ability of the Rowling books to draw you into the story.  It is hugely disappointing, disjointed and there is no flow to the story.  I seriously considered returning the book.  Had I not purchased it with a gift certificate I might have done so. But I've read it so ethically I keep it.  Better to have ended the story line with the last true Rowling book than to have pulled this substandard stunt.

author: Evgenia
title: The first book in my entire life that I didn't ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 26, 2017
content: The first book in my entire life that I didn't finish reading. Awful. I find this book an insult to the Harry Potter world.

author: Nanci S
title: Don't Bother Reading This Book
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2016
content: I'm a huge Harry Potter fan and I hated this book. I never take the time to write reviews, but that was how much I disliked this book.

author: maria
title: Don't waste your money!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2016
content: The book was horrible! I understand it's a script and would be written differently, but this was horrendous. Not something I would expect from J.K Rowling. It felt like those two guys wrote the script and stamped Rowling's name on it. Absolutely the worst thing I have read in a VERY long time.

author: Sirena Rayleeta
title: Round and round and round we go, where the awful stops, I'll never know.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2018
content: I'm not even three scenes in and I already want to cry with how awful this is. I expected more of Rowling. Has a war taught this world nothing? And what the bloody whoa is with Ron and his nose idiocy? Ugh. I'd rather just read a well written fanfic. Poor Scorpius seems so lonely in this, and Rose is just acting like a Malfoy. It's enough to make me want to scream. Read Lord of the Rings instead. At least that war saw some growth and development. Honestly. I could get into the epilogue here too, which seems to be where this began, where Slytherin is still seen as the "house of the snake and of evil dark wizards", but I'll leave that for another rant. Honestly. Hell. After seven books, you realize nobody learns a sodding thing and the Wizarding World remains completely stagnant, as witnessed in this play. I'm not even certain I should finish it.

author: Gorilichis
title: Ridiculum!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2016
content: As my good friend Amy says, if you read this as fan fiction it is not that bad. But JK Rowling gave her seal of approval and I was expecting more. It would have been OK if it had gone to the distant past, or the future, or revisited a tangential character (the Trolley Witch story was the only part I thought was worth reading about). But messing with the main storyline? Ignoring plot points that are now set in stone for Potterheads is lazy writing. I don't care if there are a million versions of reality: there are things that make you who you are no matter the circumstances, and taking a hero and turning him into a villain for the most pedestrian reason is beyond infuriating. I wish I knew an obliviator who could help me forget I ever read this.

author: Florence M. Morris
title: Cursed Child =  Blah Child
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2016
content: It failed to capture "Harry Potter"  very disappointing a waste of money

author: Deon F. Winchester
title: I was hoping the reviews were wrong, they are not.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2016
content: I had hoped that the reviews were wrong, but they were not. If I wanted to read a play I would purchase a play. I wanted to read a Harry Potter Book. I have read all the previous Harry Potter Books, several times. Love them. This was not one of them. I can not believe that JK Rowling had any part of this book. I think it was written by a group of people that had never read Harry Potter. Sorry. I can not tell anyone to purchase this play, unless you have never read a single Harry Potter book. If J.K. Rowling did write this, I am embarrassed for her.

author: Susan Stinson
title: Boring
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content: Thought it would be as good as the other Harry Potter books. But it sucks. Wish I court get a refund.

author: Love Wireless
title: scam on kids
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2016
content: what a scam on kids who think this is a book written by Rowling.  No this is a script.  Yeah yeah the little words are on the top but kids aren't that careful reading all the fine prints.

author: J. L. Jelley
title: Bad writing, I don't know why JK put her name on this
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2016
content: Honestly, this reads like BAD fan-fiction, I'm honestly shocked that this was brought to production. I've worked in theater, the "play" aspect doesn't bother me, it's honestly just bad writing and characters so unlike themselves. I really don't know, I read a lot of books and some plays and honestly this is just bad writing/story telling.

author: Paul Paredes
title: This is the faithful proof that the "second parts" are never good. The complete saga (1-7) and its end
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2016
content: I agree with almost every comment posted here. If I have to describe the "book" (I know it is a script) in one word it would be DISSAPOINMENT. This is the faithful proof that the "second parts" are never good. The complete saga (1-7) and its end, as it is, it's perfect, leave us the opportunity to make our own continuation, our own new book. This book is full of old allusions and forces the plot with improbable soltions. Anyway, give it a try and let it be :)

author: kathleen165
title: Waste of money
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: Waste of money

content: Very disappointed.  Did not like the play format in which the book was written. Found all the cues and stage directions very distracting to the flow of the book.  If she writes another in this manner I will not purchase it.

author: MrVeggiez

date: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2016
content: I'm  beyond disappointed with this.  I can't even begin to think of it as 'the eighth story'

content: Do not waste your money!  This play/book is a rapid fire short scene pitiful attempt at a Harry Potter book. I did not like it at all. It would be nice if J. K. Rowling would write another Potter book.

date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: I purposefully didn't read anything about the new book because I wanted it to be fresh and a surprise.  A play??? Definitely not in the spirit of the original series. So disappointed.

author: Drusilla Eckersley
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2016
content: No it did not because it was written in a play screen form, not in a book form.

author: Jana
title: Wish I could un-read this.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2016
content: Just awful. Our favorite characters grow up to be this? No.

author: SailorCitrine
title: Check it out from the library instead
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2017
content: I refuse to count this abomination as canon to the series that defined my childhood and I'm disappointed in JKR for sticking her name on such a poorly written piece of, let's face it, fanfiction. I mean, the idea that Voldemort would ever express a love or lust desire and do the piddily-diddily is preposterous. This whole book was preposterous and I wish I could erase it from my mind.

author: Sara Hollis
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content: A script? Not written by her...very hard to follow in script format.

author: Vanessa
title: My least favorite one of the series
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2016
content: My least favorite one of the series, it lacks the descriptions that make the story rich in details which are an essential part of these books, with all the imagination that they've been written.

author: wilson317
title: Utter Junk
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2016
content:
This was horrible. A ridiculous story line coupled with twisted versions of beloved characters mashed together with a few flashbacks in an extremely awkward format. Not at all an enjoyable or engaging read.

First, why did they not pay somebody to turn this into a novelization of the play. It would have been easier to read and follow. This comes across as a purely moneymaking product. They seem to have obviously thought that the legions of loyal Harry Potter fans will buy this no matter what so why bother fleshing it out into a book. Just let the suckers fork over their money for this horrible product.

But honestly even had it been rewritten as a novel, the story is ridiculous. And the familiar Potter characters have been twisted into bad caricatures of themselves. Time and again I found myself thinking that's not at all the behavior or dialogue I'd expect from the characters as they were written in the original books. This reads to me more like it was written by someone who disliked the books and rejected the basic friendship, honor, and sacrifice themes of the original stories.

I cannot believe that this was approved and embraced by Rowling to the extent that she wanted her name front and center on this. That this is the continuation she chose for her beloved Harry Potter series baffles me. That this was really the best they thought they could come up with as a so-called 8th installment to the series is extremely sad.

author: Julia Walker
title: if this was actually written by Rowling, then it's been sucked dead by Dementors
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
Last summer was the Harper Lee disaster.  I can’t bear being that disappointed again.  And yet, here we are.

I don’t like fantasy lit, but I adore the Harry Potter books.  Why?  I’ve never been able to answer that clearly.  Now I know.

I like the narrative, not just the story-telling (none of that here), but the brushstrokes of character development applied by the narrator’s word choice, the incorporation of setting into the plot.  Oh yes, and here there’s virtually no plot. Rather than the unexpected twists and twists Rowling gave us in the real books, this has a circumstance – plot is too strong a word.  The circumstance emerges with the props (no spoilers here) and is instantly apparent to anyone who has ever read, well, a book.  Besides being obvious, the circumstance is stupid.  It’s a failed Saturday Night Live skit.

I could go on and on.  I won’t.  (Even though I teach a class called “Harry Potter and the Renaissance Epic.”)  Instead, I’m concluding with a revision of the best line from any presidential-year debate EVER:  Lloyd Benson to Dan Quayle:

Cursed Child, I know Harry Potter books, and you’re no Harry Potter book.

author: Jonathan
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content: so disappointed! I expected a book and received a script. cant read it.

author: Lex
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: Since this was written to be SEEN just reading it rendered it rather flat

author: Chaotic Dissonance
title: What the crap?
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 25, 2017
content: So did she just decide to let some fan write a fanfic for how life was going to be after the books? This reads like a bad fanfic, if you want to ruin your memories of Harry Potter then go for it I guess.

content: It is in play script mode personally i would like it wrote the regular way it would be more readable and this is going to sound funny but the mind agomatiom wpuld or could go firther like imagining you are the and can see whays happening instead of words

author: Amazon Customer
title: lousy book
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2016
content: i did not enjoy the way it was written

author: Ryan
title: It sucks
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 26, 2019
content: This book should never have become canon and I pity the poor soul who actually spends their money on this piece of garbage.

author: Hanna Carroll
title: Basically fan fiction
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: The plot was terrible, the dialogue forced, and the personalities of the character inconsistent with the books.

author: Jessica Struth
title: Bad fan fiction that wasn't written by Rowling
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: I was thoroughly disappointed in this book. I thought that it might be a novel adaptation of the play, my mistake. The worst part was that this doesn't sound like Rowling's work at all. I've read other reviews which state that it reads like a poor fan fiction and, sadly, I must agree. It was so bad  that I couldn't even read the whole thing.

author: Megalops
title: Pure dreck
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
content: Contrived, cold, difficult to get through. Characters are flat and boring, plot is predictable, play format strips away all quality writing. Buy it if you just have to visit Harry,s world one more time, otherwise don't give in to the temptation.

author: David's
title: False promise
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content: Not a book almost a short story just a script, not by JK Rowling, doesn't ring true

author: Sandra Roll
title: NOT Harry Potter and Friends We All Love! 😭
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content:
Harry Potter fans, if you buy this book do so with the thought that this is NOT a Harry Potter and friends story (all of whom went to Hogwart 's, etc., etc.), but that this is a story which characters just by pure coincidence happen to have the same names as the Harry Potter and friends novels written by J. K. Rowling. This is NOT a Harry Potter novel by J. K. Rowling. The characters, albeit, may have the same names, glasses, hair color, etc.; however,  those are the ONLY similarities. They share absolutely none of the characteristics of the characters created by JKR - their personalities, morals ... everything, have nothing in common with the characters we've all grown up with, laughed with, cried with, hurt with, loved with ... fell in love with by JKR.  IF you go into this book with these thoughts in mind, perhaps you may enjoy this story?  Perhaps not?

With this said, I would LOVE to have the chance to ask (beg ... lol) J. K. Rowling:  Please, please, please write more Harry Potter novels (by yourself, only)!!! Your fans want more Harry Potter!!! We miss them and want MORE!!  (But, please do so as if the Cursed book was never created, never existed, just ... never was, period.)

C'mon J.K., whatcha think? Pretty please?  😇😊😙

author: Karen Brostek
title: Not your Usual Harry Potter
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
content: I really disliked this book. It made Harry a middle aged wimp and not the hero his fans know him to be..The story was ok but if you loved the boy hero, this story will change that image forever.. It was not well done and I know JKRowling can do better

author: BD
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2016
content: I was a Harry Potter fanatic growing up and was VERY disappointed in this play. It was not written by Rowling... It reads like the group watched two or three of the movies and then tried to adapt that limited knowledge to the characters and backstory of the wonderful world Rowling generated.

author: SRob
title: Should've done my homework
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: Had I known JK didn't write every word of this herself, I never would have read it. It reads like a poorly planned fan fiction written by someone with little knowledge of the traits of major characters. It's confusing at times, and there are already some obvious plot holes. I'm just going to pretend this didn't happen and wait for Fantastic Beasts.

author: Amazon Customer
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2016
content: Definitely not up to Rowling's standard.

author: Stacy
title: Terrible
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content: This was absolutely terrible.  I cannot believe the same author wrote it.  I have loved Harry Potter and read and re-read the series.  This was not true to the original series and seemed like a very bad attempt to bring some of the Harry Potter original series glory back.

author: Amazon Customer
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2016
content: Did not realize it was written as a script.

author: Avid reader
title: The Phantom Menace of the Wizarding World
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2016
content: Once upon a time J.K. Rowling had a baby named Harry Potter. Harry will forever be the cursed child because she neglected her baby and farmed out the writing of this installment in the series to a couple of hacks. This book is some world class garbage, it is the Phantom Menace of the wizarding world. I adore the Harry Potter books and movies, but this thing is an embarrassment. Two paragraphs in and I was shaking my head in dismay at how awful it was. It is a dreadful mess, and a total train wreck from beginning to end. These other 2 authors were a disastrous choice, and have no business anywhere near a keyboard. Every single line of dialogue is tragically “on the nose”, and every character speaks in a generic voice. You could swap any line of dialogue between characters and it would no make a difference. Every character has been washed of their personalities, no one sounds or behaves like they do in the books. I won’t even get into the author’s childish understanding of how time travel works. The present ceases to exist the moment someone travels back in time to change the future. Duh. I’ve read fan fiction that put this effort to shame. So lame.

author: nigel sadler
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2016
content: It's a disgrace that this was ever released,

author: Kathleen
title: How Truly Unfortunate.
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2016
content: I wanted to love this, I really did. I'm as starved for new Harry Potter content as any other fan, but this book is sadly disappointing. I think the thing that disappoints me most is the lack of continuity among characters from the original series. None of the original characters keep their personalities or traits in this book. They just don't have the same feel. Hermoine talks to Ron like a child, Ginny and Harry are nothing similar to who they were in the original series. The characters I loved in the HP series are gone, replaced by some loosely related, poorly written shadows, really only the same in name.  I've read other reviews that say this book is like poorly written fan fiction, and I must say I agree. There is nothing connecting this book the the original series. The story is convoluted, the plot is disorganised and at times pointless. There is no trace of the magic and passion with which JK Rowling wrote the HP series. It's a scattered,  pointless mess. It takes away all of the feelings left at the end of HP, when you're left staring into a future unmarred by Voldemort, wondering or hoping or writing a continuation of your own,  and replaces it with a story unfitting to the original series. And unfortunately, it vastly fails to match the feeling, magic, or effort given to thr HP series. What a shame.

author: Maggie
title: Missing magic
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2016
content: Being a play, this misses the magic that novels can create (internal dialogue, descriptions of scenery, etc).  Overall very disappointing.

author: Lyss
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2016
content: This is probably one of the worst fanfictions I have ever read regarding the harry potter series. If JK Rowling would have looked up some stories on a fan site, she'd probably would have written a better plot.

author: kct726
title: This is NOT a Harry Potter Book.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content: J.K Rowling obviously did not write this book. There were no clever British History inserts, no jokes, none of the plain ole' mischievous Harry that we all know and love. Frankly, I didn't like it at all. Sure it was an OK book, but "OK" doesn't cut it in the Potter fandom. There is no Harry Potter without J.K Rowling, and it showed. To be realistic, I would never recommend this book as a HP Sequel because the only thing it will ever have in common is the fact there's a Potter on the title. I'm still hoping for a real, justified book about HP next gen, (and of course a prequel about our favorite fantastic four, the marauders) one that put very own J.K Rowling writes, because honestly, this was a Cruciatus Curse to my heart.

author: Omy olky
title: It reads like very bad fanfic
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 1, 2016
content: Very disappointing. I can't really believe that JK Rowling was really that involved in this. It reads like very bad fanfic. And its heteronormativity and queerbaiting is disgusting. I expect much better from a book attributed to Rowling.  Again, very, very disappointing.

author: R. Sanguily
title: Disappointing, VERY disappointing!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content: Disappointing,  VERY disappointing!

author: Andee Wyatt
title: Don't buy it if you're looking for another Harry Potter story.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2016
content: I was very disappointed. I had been looking forward to a sequel to the Harry Potter series. Instead, it is written as a play. I found it very disconcerting and could not get into the story at all. It's not a story at all.

author: Tarayn
title: Very Disappointing Plot and Lazy Writing
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: Alright... I have to say it too.  As many have posted,  this play is highly disappointing... The screenplay is just terrible. It seems like cheap fan fiction... It just doesn't feel right.  Maybe it's just meant to be seen, not read--people that have seen the London play have been raving about how awesome it is--but I don't have high hopes visuals would save this play.  I am disappointed in the construction of the story and the pathetic,  lazy use of time travel to create the story. So much else could have been written,  and honestly has been by fans. I'm very upset with JK Rowling for having any part if this rubbish.

author: anonymous
title: Like most of the other reviewers
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content: Like most of the other reviewers, I feel like this book doesn't hold true to the traits of the characters that we all know and love. It felt too rushed and ended quickly. I was left very disappointed when I finished reading. Wish they didn't call this the 8th Harry Potter book.

author: MARIZA
title: What a disappointment!
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2016
content: Disappointing!!!!

author: David Hughes
title: Pedantic
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2016
content: It was like taking a bath in nowhere near warm water. The names are familiar... But that's about as far as it goes. There is no excitement... There is no Harry Potter Wonder... It was pedantic and a waste of money...

author: CollegeGrad08
title: Disappointing and terrible
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2017
content:
If I could give this zero stars, I would.  The thing that upset me the most about this abook was the behavior of our beloved Harry, Hermione, and Ron.  Their behavior was so out of character, which made this challenging to read and incredibly disappointing.

Hermione was always my favorite character in the series, so when I read this, I found myself incredibly disappointed and surprised that J.K. Rowling would have agreed to let anyone do this to such an incredible series.

Not only did Hermione not offer any solutions or act in any way like the character we all know and love, but Ron's primary role in the book served as comedic relief or to talk about being hingry.  That was it.  Anyone who claims to have loved this series would NEVER have written anything like this.

This does not belong on my shelf with the series.  Not even close.

author: John Gibson
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2016
content: I was dissapointed to see this novel written in play script form; I did not finish it.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Bad fanfiction
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
Same familiar tune as many of the reviews before me - I knew this was a script, I knew JKR had not written it directly, and I was still supremely disappointed. As I was reading it, I kept thinking that it felt like I was reading bad fanfiction.

I can't enumerate all the plotholes and character issues, but here are some highlights SPOILER ALERT:

The reason that time travel works for me in PoA is that it is abundantly clear that Harry and Hermione were always there - there was never an alternate timeline or alternate universe. As Harry says, he knew he could cast the patronus because he had already done it. This is not the case in TCC. And having saved two extra magical time turners? I could not suspend my disbelief for that.
On a related note, it seemed that many of the magical laws that had been established in 1-7 were ignored, such as taking a month to brew polyjuice potion. And transforming Harry to look like Voldemort, then having the transformation wear off?

And don't get me started on the character assassinations. Ron was like a caricature of himself, oafish and drunk. And Voldemort having a secret child??? It would have been much more believable to have the enemy be a Death Eater who remained in hiding.
END SPOILERS

To be fair, there were parts that I thought how cool this must look on stage. However, without  the bells and whistles of a stage production to distract from the dialogue and plot, it was impossible to ignore the multitude of major problems.
If you take my advice, don't read this. Preserve the memory of the untarnished seven books.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Make it stop...
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2016
content:
So let me make this as clear as can be. Harry grows up to be a bad father and a bit of a jerk, Ron is an idiot and Hermione raises a hateful bully? The writing is just so bad. So silly. It's like a high school sophomore wrote the dialogue. The hogwarts express trolley witch has claws and polices the train now?! What?! So ridiculous.
  I truly believe if JK Rowling has written this story by herself the result would've kept with the beauty and wonderment of the Harry Potter universe. BUT as she did not, this miserable embarrassment of a story is something that I am chalking up as an insult to the Harry Potter character and dumping from my memory.
  Of course some JK Rowling sheep will love it and cheer for a encore but the reality of it is that the three wonderfully amazing children who saved the world and banded together grew up to be stupid, hateful adults who speak like 12 year olds? I sincerely hope not. Maybe the next play will feature another time turner and make it so this one never happened.

author: Schuyler Pierson
title: Harry Potter fans, save yourself!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
I am a true-blue Harry Potter fan; I fell in love when read the first book and never looked back. 14+ years later, it's still my favorite series. What I'm saying is, I am one of those Potterheads that would love to read more in this universe, learn more about the Marauders, would even consider attending a HP convention.

All that said, I hated this book. I know, it's a play. But I've read plays, and they are better than this. The writing was like fan fiction--that thought came to me multiple times while reading the book. The characters were terribly one-dimensional; we learned almost nothing about the new characters, and the old ones didn't feel like themselves at all. The story felt a lot like the marathon camping from DH, which wasn't really my favorite part of the series. It felt repetitive and boring. And the big bombshell was so unbelievable, so soap-opera like, so ridiculous that I wondered what ACTUAL fanfic I could read that would help me forget what I read here.

I wish I had never read this. I'm going to pretend I didn't; it's not canon. If only it had been in the Room of Requirement during the Battle of Hogwarts. I never thought I could be disappointed in HP or JKR, but damn... I feel like something got ruined for me here.

author: Jessica Martinez
title: Not like the other books!!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2017
content: **WARNING SPOILERS**I've  loved reading all the Harry Potter books over and over, always catching new things because JK's writing was so rich and full of depth and complex storylines. THIS IS NOT LIKE THE OTHER BOOKS. First, it's written as a screen play, so background stories are short and limited. Second, the plot line is terrible. Voldemort having a daughter and not knowing?? Harry and his son having no relationship whatsoever?? Draco having no hard feelings to his ex enemies?? Ughhh. The characters are shallow and altered forms of the beloved ones Rowling wrote; I have a hard time believing Harry would tell his son he wish he wasn't his son sometimes?!? Also, Harry's other children deserve more representation and are given like 1% of words in the entire novel. Why the heck would Ron be running the joke shop?! George should be doing that, unless Fred's death really kept him from doing his job, which I doubt , but otherwise that should be stated! The believable parts are that Hermione is running the ministry, since she's probably the most qualified witch out there to do so. But even then, I have a hard time believing she is content with running the wizard world while her spouse is at home with the kids. Ugh, it made me sad to read it but I obviously had to finish to see if it had any redeemable qualities. The friendship between Scorpius and Albus was nice, but also lacked depth and detail, like everything else in this play.

author: Nisha Manzoor
title: You're Better Off Reading Actual Fanfiction
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content:
I'll start with the good things about the book since there's barely anything good about it.

The good things about the book are that some of the concepts are a little interesting and that Scorpius Malfoy is actually endearing in several parts. That's pretty much it.

The bad things are that a lot of the concepts are convoluted or just make no sense in the grand scheme. The plot itself is a hot mess. A lot of the characters are badly written and even just parts of the story are badly written. I don't know why, but I'm still really stuck on the fact that 'darker, blacker robes' that Scorpius ended up in during one of the timelines. I strongly recommend you avoid this book and just hit up some actual fanfiction sites. I promise you that there's better written fanfiction out there and it won't cost you any money to read them.

title: What a crap! Ruined everything for me!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content:
I've loved and adored Harry Potter all my life  and I have a harry Potter marathon to read all Harry Potter books over again every 2 years!
This book was crap!
I have no idea why should someone write some crappy and disappointing book like this and ruin the whole thing for fans. It was not even a book! Even if we assume it is just written and meant to be for play, the dialogues were so poor and fake that no-one enjoys the show.
I've also read J. K. Rowling's Casual Vacancy. She has a descriptive and multi-dimensional style of writing that doesn't suit this book. I'm pretty sure she didn't have a hand on this book. However, when her name is on a book even as a reviewer, we expect way more!

author: Rio
title: Author-approved fanfiction
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2016
content:
I'm not usually a stickler for canon content, but I have to say this reads like bad fanfiction from someone with less than a passing knowledge of the book.

Most of characters act a little outside their previous norms, which is understandable and adds depth.  They've changed in twenty years. (All fair deviations, with the exception of the Death Eaters naming a holiday Voldemort Day.  It would be the Dark Lord's Day if anything.  Avoiding his name is a massive plot point.)

What's unacceptable is the blatant disregard of the HP universe's rules.  Namely, that one can't change time.  Harry and co. never change time with the time turner--they're fulfilling their predestined roles.  E.g. Harry sees himself cast the Patronus charm in the present without realizing it was himself, and then he returns to the past to cast it.  The timeline is fixed.  In The Cursed Child, going back in time suddenly has the power affect the present adversely in a sort Back to the Future bit of wackiness.

That being said, the children are entertaining and their struggle to cope with their families' legacy is  engaging.  The time travel plot just felt like a lazy way to forced beloved dead characters into the mix.

author: Steven Garcia
title: "All was well" J.K. Rowling. You should have left well enough alone.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2016
content:
Never would I expect Rowling to write something that even fan-fiction writers would cringe at. Did she even remember her characters? Did she even remember the rules of the world she created? I should have stopped reading when the trolly woman suddenly had blade for hands, but I pressed on, hoping it was just a hiccup, but apart from the horrible conclusion of where the villain originated, the script itself made me cringe. At times Albus and Scorpius were believable, but I actively gagged when I read them being so nice to each other that even Frodo and Sam would blush. Young boys don't talk like this.
This is absolute garbage that should never have carried the Harry Potter name. Stick with Pottermore, Rowling. And Jack Thorne, just stay to your own material. At least The Golden Compass, while I like it okay, is already written bland enough to not tarnish anything too much.
This play offended me just on its obvious attempt to get credit off the Harry Potter name alone, because it sure as hell isn't getting any credit off its own merits.

title: SPOLIER - Um Can We Talk About the Trolley Witch? - SPOILER
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
Have read the 5 star reviews on here, the issue is not that this was written as a screen play. This issue with this screen play is that it totally rips apart the story of Harry Potter and will make you question the entire series. As an avid Harry Potter fan I spent my childhood reading and rereading the stories, delving into the detailed world that is Harry Potter with its imagery and developed characters. None of the characters in here felt right. (SPOILER) Ginny was subdued, Harry was an Arse, Ron sounded like he might belong in St. Mungos, Hermione sounded old, bitter and unpowerful, and Draco was the only original character I actually liked which is against everything in me that is Griffindor.

Wish that I would not have read, JK Rowling should have left the series as the perfection it was and not sold out.

SPOILER
Ummmmm the Trolley Witch is a monster that has claws and keeps kids on the train? WHAT? What is this god awful madness. At least have some sort of enchantment that prohibits them from getting off the train. That is all.

author: Caitlin
title: Don't read it. Just pretend it doesn't exist. Or rent it so it won't have the honor of joining your shelf.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2016
content:
I'm returning it and pretending I never read it in the first place.

The problem isn't that it's a script instead of a novel. The problem isn't that we aren't seeing the visuals when we read it by itself.

The problem is the story. It didn't make any sense! It didn't add to the other books, it only tried to mess with things that didn't need to be messed with.

HEY SPOILERS ARE COMING. DON'T READ PAST THIS IF YOU DON'T WANT THINGS SPOILED.

Things that really bothered me:

- Time turners. Awful, just awful. We didn't need those back. They were weak in the 3rd book, so I was glad they were destroyed. It's like they focused on the joke people make where "since they had time turners, why didn't they just get rid of Voldemort as a child" or other similar stuff, and turned it into a big part of this story. Plus time travel is always super messy. Especially when they had three timelines going on by the end.

- Voldemort having a child. HA. This whole story had me rolling my eyes, but that was just the worst and most ridiculous part for me. He wouldn't want a child and he wouldn't have wanted to sleep with anyone. He didn't care for anyone but himself, that was already made quite clear.

- So many people were missing. Where was George, Teddy, Hugo (Ron and Hermione's son), Neville, Luna, Mr. and Mrs. Weasley, plus Lily, Rose, and James are barley in it. I'm sure there are more that are missing.

- None of them felt like the characters that we know and love. Ron is more of an idiot. I don't like him all that much in the other books, but I can tolerate him. What little roles he has in this is dumb. Especially that he was drunk at their wedding? There's no way. Hermione seemed dumbed down and simplified. If she had something as important as the last surviving time turner, she would've hidden it better, not to mention it probably wouldn't be in her office. And Harry. Everything about him seemed wrong. I know that he's going to be different than we last saw him, but this Harry seems like a different person. I hate what he said to Albus. I don't believe he ever would actually say that to his son. Oh and you know who else was different? The woman who pushes the trolley with treats on the Hogwarts Express. That whole scene was ridiculous.

- They brought back Cedric just to drag him through the mud! What was the point? Also, he wouldn't have become a death eater just from the events they made up.

- Why make Harry watch his parents die? That's just cruel!

- Also, it's very jumpy. It's annoying how fast they breeze through the first 3 years for Albus at school. That would've been the most interesting thing to read about in my opinion.

Overall, I hated it. I will continue reading better fanfiction created by teenagers.

author: Jessica Moore
title: A waste of paper
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 24, 2018
content: I've blocked most of it out, but this book is a poor excuse for canon Harry Potter. I was so eager for this to arrive, but from start to finish I was shaking my head and rereading bits to make sure I had comprehended them correctly. Many people say that the book version doesn't do the story justice, but I am not in the position to see the live play. My advice, write it off as really bad fanfiction and move forward with your life.

author: Brittany Revia de García
title: Painfully disappointing
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
I'm a diehard Potterhead. Rowling's world made such a huge impact in my life.

That's why I'm so disappointed in this. It's easily one of the worst fanfictions I've read.

There are some people who will blindly love it because it has Harry's name, but the contradiction to existing canon, weak writing, and flagrant disregard for character development made it impossible for me to enjoy.

Frankly, I would've been ashamed to sign my name to that as a writer . . .

author: Heather
title: Poorly Written Harry Potter Fan Fiction
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
I'm sad, not because it's over but because I wish it never existed and I shouldn't think like that when it comes to Harry Potter. I haven't been this disappointed in a book probably ever. Harry Potter, like many readers, has been a constant comfort and escape for me ever since I started reading when I was about nine. It was the series that gave me confidence, the urge to read, and a connection with my grandmother who passed away in 2008 almost a year after the final book Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows came out.

I was excited about the idea of the Cursed Child play because that meant we would have more stories with the characters I grew up with, even if there was a almost no chance I'd ever see the play. My excitement and anticipation skyrocketed when I heard they were going to be publishing the script. I was a bit bummed about the format, hoping that maybe J.K. Rowling would write the story in novel form, and I was bummed when we found out that Rowling wouldn't be writing it. But I was still optimistic. Queen Rowling wouldn't put her stamp of approval on something that she didn't 100% believe was ready for publication.

Unfortunately, as you could probably tell by the rating this script/book did not live up to almost any of my expectations. Because I don't really know where to start, I am just going to list out my pros and cons of the story. THERE WILL BE SPOILERS AFTER THIS.

PROS:
I absolutely loved that Albus Severus Potter was sorted into Slytherin house. Having positive examples of Slytherin students is something I feel like was missing in the original books. We had a few adults like Narcissa Malfoy and Slughorn who both definitely redeemed themselves  but I always wanted a student  that readers who identified Slytherin had to look up to or admire. I wish there was a example of a Hufflepuff, because there's even few known Hufflepuff characters that have their own moments and personalities. I feel like both Slytherin and Hufflepuff get shafted in the original series. Unfortunately Hufflepuff doesn't get much of a mention in this story either but I do think Albus being a Slytherin is a step into the right direction.

I liked what we saw of how Ron grew into being a father, husband, and uncle. He still had his same Ron personality of thinking about food, being over protective, and being down right hilarious but he also did a lot of "dad-jokes" and had pretty much been a walking step-by-step instruction on how to embarrass your kids. It was great. I liked how affectionate he was with Hermione, and how he announced that he wanted to re-do his vows with her. She was the same kind of stern but melty Hermione around him. I love them together. I am happy they stayed together. After Rowling's bomb (which I do not, and will not, ever agree with) that she doesn't think they should have been together in the end I was worried she would have them end up divorced or something by the end of the play. Thank God that didn't happen.

This one is a weird PRO. But I liked that Amos Diggory was a complete jerk. It felt very familiar, hating the entitled snark that was Amos. I had this real hatred for him when I read Goblet of Fire for the first time. Of course, I sympathized with him at the end of the book when Cedric dies, but I still did not like him one bit. Now knowing the end of the story I wonder if him going to the Potter's residence was of his own choice, or if Delphi cursed him somehow or even just convinced him. But still, Amos being  a complete jerk at least felt familiar.

I did enjoy Harry's conversations with painting Dumbledore. I don't know too much about how the talking to painting things really work. I always assumed that when a witch or wizard gets painted that version of themselves is what stays immortal so anything the actual person learns or experiences doesn't have any effect on the painting. So because I don't know when Dumbledore was painting I am not sure how much closure Harry really got. But I am happy he got something, because he really let out some intense feelings towards painting Dumbledore. Things he didn't get to say in King's Cross because of the shock of being killed and him still being a boy missing his mentor and friend.

I liked Draco's relationship with his son. He really loves his son and it shows. Lucius Malfoy was never a great father. He was abusive and manipulative and it shows that Draco wants to do better towards Scorpius. I really feel like Draco redeemed himself in this book. He still bickered with the trio, but it was (most of the time) more friendly than angry. You could see a forming of an alliance, or even a friendship.

I also really liked Albus and Scorpius's friendship. I liked that their outcast personalities drew them together and that Albus didn't judge Scorpius about the rumors about him. It reminded me of when Harry didn't judge Ron because of the way his family was perceived by Draco. Albus at times reminded me a lot of a younger Harry. However, they are obviously in love from their dialogue and the way they act around each other. Plus other characters perspectives. I feel like the writers wanted to bait the fans that would have liked seeing a LGBT+ couple in HP but they didn't want to take that last step and make it official. Ridiculous.

When Harry transforms into Voldemort, although it was a awkward scene (more in that in my cons), I like that he completely sucked at acting like an evil Dark Lord. It reminded me of when the trio break into the Ministry of Magic in Deathly Hallows and they suck at pretending to be someone they're not. It had me laughing.

The scene after Harry witnesses his parent's death, when Hagrid walks into the house and finds Lily and James dead. When he talk to Harry and picks him up. More on Hagrid later, but he's one of my top five favorite characters and I am so happy to see that moment with Hagrid and Harry. I know we get a piece of it in Deathly Hallows, and maybe it's because this was a new perspective but I definitely had tears in that moment. However, wasn't Sirius already there with his motorcycle when Hagrid shows up? In HPatCC Hagrid enters an empty house.

CONS:
We jump between small moments for about three years at the Potter's time at King's Cross Station every September 1 we see Albus go from this innocent but nervous kid to a complete jerk who is an ass to Harry. Because of the fact that we don't see why he becomes so angry and why he hates Hogwarts so  much and it makes him seem angry and irrational for no reason. Honestly it's kind of draining an gets a bit annoying at times. If some sort of specific incidents were referenced or played out showing Albus being picked on by his fellow classmates maybe it would make more sense. Scorpius, who has a stupid rumor over his head and has a real reason to hate his classmates seems to love Hogwarts. He loves to learn and he loves being able to be with his best friend.

Talking about the rumor, damn it was dumb. They wanted the reader to know that there was a chance someone would shack up with Voldemort and have a kid and they tried making us believe that the kid was Scorpius. Which didn't work because like Scorpius says, he looks just like his father Draco. Plus, why would going back in time and having Voldemort's son be Draco and Astoria's decision after not being able to have children? Voldemort tortured and royally screwed up the Malfoy family (who, of course kind of did it to themselves - but still) so why would Draco have his wife go and have sex with the man who he probably really hates? It just seemed to make zero sense as a rumor.

The trolley witch, why? Really - why? It made no sense. Why did she need to turn into a spiky  monster thing. Why was that pointless part in there?

I didn't like that Rose was barely a character in the story. I thought she was going to be the girl for their trio, so when it turned out not to be the case I was really bummed. Especially when thinking about the play itself. They made the bold and awesome move to have two women of color play Hermione and Rose and they are barely in the story. I understand Hermione, because the story is about the children more than the parents. But Rose seemed like a cool character. She reminded me so much of Hermione in so many ways but at the same time she had the same judgment (when Albus and Rose meet Scorpius for the first time) sometimes a young Ron carried with him. Why have all the drama and news about having two beautiful (and from what I hear - amazing actresses) women of color be characters that many people for many years thought of as white characters to not use them? I pictured all these little girls and boys who had darker skin going to see the play and seeing Rose as this bad-ass witch and relate. But she wasn't in enough to make enough of an impression which is a real bummer. Now knowing how long they are in the story it feels more like a publicity stunt.

I know that the story mostly focuses on Albus and Scorpius, but I would have liked to see more of the other Potter and Granger-Weasley children. It also would have been nice to see more of Ginny's feisty side and Harry's funny endearing side. Everyone seems to be really awful to Harry in this book, and it made me feel for him. For a moment I honestly thought he was going to die in the end to save his son because of how awful everyone was being to him.

All the time travel seemed pointless because in the end, nothing was changed when it came to timelines. So it seemed like a complete waste of time. I am not against time travel, if it is done right I can really get into it. I loved it in Prisoner of Azkaban. The only time the time travel seemed to really matter was the very last time, and even then I could have lived without it because of how absolutely ridiculous it was. I also don't like that we see Severus Snape. He tells Scorpius to tell Albus that he is proud that Albus has 'Severus' as his middle name but it seemed completely out of place. Maybe because I still think it's absolutely ridiculous that Harry named his kid after a man who tormented him and his friends for years because Harry looked like his dad and because Snape couldn't get with Lily. But that's a little off topic. It just seemed out of Snape's character. Because that version of Snape that feels like he failed Lily on keeping Harry safe doesn't exist, and I don't think it ever would exist. I am not a fan of Snape as a person. He's an amazingly fascinating character but as a person I hate him so much. So for him to have any redemption just made me roll my eyes. It seemed fake and too cheesy for me. Also: because in this time line Ron and Hermione aren't together she is a grumpy old spinster? I don't understand. Hermione is a brave, smart, dependent woman without Ron. I think he writers were trying to parallel her to McGonagall but the problem with that is the writer doesn't know the character well enough so it came off like without Ron, Hermione would never fully be happy with her life. And although I love them together, I think they would both be fine without each other. I just think they're stronger together.

Harry had a bad childhood. He was starved and neglected. I know we don't see Harry as a toddler almost at all with the Dursley's but I assume he was never shown any real love which is something every child needs and deserves to grow up healthy. The fact that Harry went though that and still had such an open heart to Ron, Hermione, the professors at Hogwarts, and the Weasley family is some sort of magic in its own right. Because of this, having Harry tell Albus that he wishes Albus was never his son after Albus says he wishes Harry wasn't his father seemed wrong. Even in the heat of the moment. I know Harry has had a short temper in the past during stressful times. I know he regretted it the moment he said it. But I still don't think it's something Harry would say to any of his kids.

No Neville really pissed me off. Neville killed Nagini! He was the final piece into saving the wizarding world. And all we get is a few references? And no Teddy Lupin! I wanted to know the kind of person he would be. I wanted to see parts of my favorite Marauder shine through his kid. I wanted him to have cool colored hair and a mischievous grin like his mom. No future Hagrid mentioning at all. What the actual crap is that? I may be a bit biased about Hagrid, but it's more than that. If Hagrid saw that Albus was having troubles he would have without a doubt taken Albus under his wing and made sure he was loved. Does that mean he's dead? (Nope I am never ever accepting that. Nope) Because if not then I am a little relieved, but mostly upset he was forgotten about. But sure, let's have a scene with the random Trolley Witch and annoying extra time travel scenes that pretty much lead nowhere. That makes total sense.

How did Scorpius, Delphi, and Albus brew a Polyjuice Potion so quickly? It takes a month to successfully brew a Polyjuice potion. How did they expect to do it at the end of the story while waiting for Voldemort? Hermione you're literally standing right there, you brewed the potion when you were eleven years old. YOU KNOW it takes a month. It's not an option. The group comes to the conclusion it isn't an option because you need a bit of someone to use the potion to transform into another witch or wizard. But no one mentions it also takes a whole month!

How can Albus and Scorpius peak into the house and see Lily and baby Harry when the house is protected by a Fidelius charm? It makes no sense.  Also - right after that scene when they get the idea to write a message (and destroy Harry's last childhood possession. Good job Albus) on Harry's baby blanket, why do we skip the cool and probably hilarious scene of the boys sneaking into the house to steal the blanket from baby Harry? How did they get the blanket without being caught and then have the time to write the message and slip the blanket back into its rightful spot?

The fact that Delphi was Voldemort and Bellatrix's love child is absolutely absurd. Even if Voldemort would have the urge to have sex with anyone (which, I honestly don't think he would. Especially after he lost his pretty boy body/face and turned into a white gross red eyed snake man) why the hell would anyone have sex with a white gross red eyed snake man?! I knew Bellatrix was insane, but really? Also - wouldn't someone notice that Bellatrix was carrying a child? She says she has the baby before the Battle of Hogwarts. So did no one realize that Bellatrix had gotten enormously round during Half Blood Prince? She was standing there the night Dumbledore dies. She was never described as pregnant. Or even when Bellatrix was torturing Hermione in Dealthy Hallows? Nothing makes sense.

On the awkward scene with Harry transforming into Voldemort. Is that a thing? Can you transform witches and wizards into other witches and wizards? Wouldn't everyone do that instead of making Polyjuice Potion and having to wait a whole month? It seemed very convenient.

It seemed fairly easy to detain Delphi, even after she realized Harry wasn't the greatest actor in the world and he wasn't Voldemort.  There were a few quick spells back and forth and the Hermione [as always] jumps in like a BAMF and ties her up with a brachiabindo binding spell. She didn't seem like much of a real threat.

Why exactly did Harry have to stick around and watch his parents die exactly? Hasn't he been through enough crappy situations? It's bad enough he remembers pieces of it as a child, does he have to see the whole thing? It seemed unnecessary.

Harry is scared of pigeons? It's so random. Maybe I'm just nitpicking now because I'm wound up and angry. But it seems so annoyingly outrageous.

Seriously this book reads like the authors scrolled down fanfiction.net, wrote down plot points other people did that they liked and then published the first draft. It reads like a cheesy not well thought out Disney channel show episode.

Not plot point cons:
The fact that it wasn't written by J.K. Rowling showed in the writing. It didn't have the same writing style, which makes sense because everyone has their own style but the problem is I don't think Jack Thorne is that great of a dialogue writer from what we were given. And since scripts are mostly dialogue it wasn't a great experience. The dialogue was stiff and unnatural. No one really talked like how actual people talk. I am hoping that the actors maybe change the words around to make it seem less fake? If not I can't imagine how awkward it is to watch on the stage. Even the way the setting was set up in between scenes, the way the words were strung together read awkwardly. It felt like a really bad fanfiction. I don't read much fanfiction, especially not Harry Potter fanfiction but the ones I have read seemed better than what was given us in Harry Potter and the Cursed Child. I am just surprised and deeply disappointed that J.K. Rowling let this get published without making sure it all made sense and that the writing was polished. This will not ever be cannon for me. I don't think I will be forgetting the story any time soon, but I am treating it fully as fanfiction.

author: Amazon Customer
title: A Bad Fanfiction
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
Another nice example of how it is important to stop and leave at a right moment. Unfortunately this story brings almost nothing to the HP Universe. At the same time it alters the magical laws and provides even more questions than we had before. And the characters are not saving the situation this time. If you still remember them from the books then I would advise you to forget them. Almost all of them are out of character. If you are hoping to find good dialogs here, I guess, you would probably be disappointed as well. Most of them are pointless, some of them are full of pathos. Well, there are some nice jokes and lines. But they are lost in the whole mess.
In conclusion, this play looks like a very bad fanfiction. I personally would never consider it as the 8 HP story.

author: PieRsquare
title: It's not the Harry that we know or love.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
J.K. Rowling just trashed her legacy. She deviated from the core of her characters. You'll find yourself thinking "She/he would never have said that." or "He/she would never have done that!" It just doesn't track with the characters we knew so well. Fans of the books will be very disappointed in the script. Firstly, it's not actually a novel (duh) and it doesn't read like one (also duh). Many will blame the format for the departure from her past quality and while it clearly didn't do Rowling et. al. any favors, this reads like fan-fiction. Start to finish. The new characters, the changes to old characters, the plot, the concept - all of them scream "fan-fiction" and not even good fan-fiction. The key points of the story just don't fit the universe. It's uncomfortable to read this if you're deep into the original stories. You'll struggle to fit the actions of characters into what you know of them. So much of the plot feels like a retread of old material and not just flashbacks but the themes. This didn't add anything new to the Harry Potter universe. At least, nothing that we couldn't have lived without.

There are a few brief moments that feel like the wizarding world we all know and love but sadly, they are few and far between.

Fans of Harry Potter do owe it to themselves to read the story but I strongly recommend that you lock this tale far far away from your memory of the 7 books.

title: Read the orginal books instead!

There is one scene in the entire book where I truly felt sorry for Harry, but other than that, this book was just plain BORING!

author: Rachel
title: I wish I had a time turner to erase this book.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content:
Alternate titles for this book:
Harry Potter and the Cynical Money Grab
Harry Potter and the Overhyped Fanfic
Harry Potter and the Gaping Plot Holes
Harry Potter and the Phantom Menace

JK Rowling officially pulled a George Lucas on this one.  I don't know why she put her stamp on this but it was awful.  Contradicted existing rules of the HP universe, ridiculous character assassination, and a rehashing of previous plot points to disguise the lack of any new or fresh material.  Anyone who gave this a good review is either so blinded by nostalgia or so happy to have more HP material that they're making excuses for this poor excuse for a fanfic.

author: Jessica Sue
title: No
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
I don't understand why good things can't be allowed to just end, without being dragged out and reanimated until they lose the spark that made us love them in the first place,  but that's what happened here.

I am a die-hard Harry Potter fan--I've read the books and listened to the audiobooks dozens of times, I have a deathly hallows tattoo. But I can say with certainty that I wish this "book" had never been written. Not only is it completely nonsensical, but it upends settled characters and plot points in a way that breaks my heart, as a Potterhead. I'm hoping it won't taint my experience of and love for the old books, but I'm afraid it has.
