author: annev
title: Skip this- you'll be glad you did
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2017
content: Not only did this book not cohere on the level of plot and characterization - even just on the level of writing it's so poorly done, in fact bafflingly so. The dialogue is cringeworthy throughout, and in the play/drama format we totally lose the tongue in cheek references and lush descriptions that pepper the narration of the canonical books, giving them intellectual and emotional depth. How could Rowling have had a hand in this at all?!?! I have no idea why she allowed her name to be put on this book, and can only hope it was through some misguided sense of the books value rather than a gimmick to make a load of cash. Honestly, I'd skip it if you love the canonical books- it will just depress/anger you and sour your view of the vast majority of the series' most beloved characters and places. Skip it, and go back to the Half Blood Prince or the Prisoner of Azkaban for all the things that make us love this series.

author: Sarah Misheff
title: But this "book" was absolutely horrible. The plot was ridiculous
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: I'm a huge Harry Potter fan. I've passionately read all the books countless times, went to midnight release parties, watched the movies over and over, bought the merchandise, was sorted on Pottermore.... I grew up with the books. But this "book" was absolutely horrible. The plot was ridiculous, the language was pompous, awkward, and over the top ("it's now wizards and witches in robes mostly trying to work out how to say good-bye to their beloved progeny "stands out), and the characters such as Snape, Harry, Cedric, and Voldemort are completely different and horridly out of character. It's absolute garbage and I will never see it as canon.

author: Amazon Customer
title: I just don't feel like wasting my time to finish the story
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2017
content: I am a die-hard Harry Potter fan. When the 7th book was released, I didn't sleep till I finished the book, which, with a job, was very very difficult. This book spoiled the entire series for me. I got it as a gift for my birthday in August and even after 4 months, I am yet to reach the climax. I just don't feel like wasting my time to finish the story! It has JK Rowling's name on the cover, but I doubt she has applied herself to make this story as amazing as her original works. The entire writing style is childish. It's like a school play. I saw the Potter series during the new year holidays and couldn't help writing this review. This is one of the most badly written books I have ever read. I wish someone could use the obliviate charm to erase this from my memory.

author: Farah
title: fail
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2016
content: bad book it doesnt have any of the charm that the first seven book like other reviews have said this book does not deserve the harry potter name because this bok is not a harry potter book in any way

author: Amazon Customer
title: Terrible terrible terrible
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2017
content: This book was terrible. Plot holes, bad portrayal of characters, just a weak story in general. Jk Rowling should use a time turner and never let herself write this awful book.

author: Haileyg
title: Dont be fooled by rowling's name on the cover. She didnt write this crap
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: I wish I hadn't wasted my time or my money on this. It was comparable to poorly written fanfiction. There is actually much better fanfiction that you can find online for free, I suggest you do that instead.

author: Lionors
title: Don't waste your money
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2018
content: This was so bad I returned it.  I liked Scorpius and the idea that Draco could have been mellowed out into a halfway decent person by a decent wife, but Albus?  I *hated* that little whiny, sniveling little attitude monster.  The dialogue was off, the characterization was crap -- honestly, to call this a fanfic is an insult to fanfic; I've seen better fanfics.

author: Kimmie
title: Don't waste your money!!!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content: NOT A BOOK!!!! I guess I trusted Amazon too much. I didn't read the description well enough. I thought it was going to be a new Harry Potter book. Don't waste your money on this. Not very nice of JK Rowlings after ALL the MONEY she has made off her fans. I'll think twice before buying another book she writes.  What's worse, she didn't even write this.

author: Joseph Mastrangelo
title: I liked the movies
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
I liked the movies. I loved the books. This? I'm pissed about.

15 bucks for the kindle version down the drain.

I was able to get into it despite it being still just the literal script. But that stripped the entire world from it. The actual books had the nuance of the day to day life of a schoolkid. The snowball fights. The taste of butterbeer.

I'm sure this gets more as an actual play, because the play lets the actors bring the characters to life. But when reading it, I need the "stage" to be the extra words describing the scene. This felt like an 'artistic' minimalist play of one actor up there just delivering the lines and expecting us to appreciate that. I didn't. Maybe that's on me, who knows.

The characters also didn't feel like themselves. There's some lines from Harry I just can't picture him saying, despite him being 40 now. And there's some 'youthful adventurous' scenes, one specifically on the Hogwarts train, that just seems absolutely silly.

I also agree that it feels more like a fanfic. The returning characters seem more written with the surface personalities, not with the nuanced other personality traits you sensed under the surface with a whole book.

The bare bones maybe gives me hope. Maybe if a legitimate book is written around this it wouldn't be bad. And maybe with the actors bringing the lines to life, the play may be great. But this? Not worth the money at all.

author: Rae
title: A Waste of Time and Money
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content: I am  huge Harry Potter fan and have been looking forward to reading this. I can't even begin to describe how disappointed I am in it. The story is horrible. I wish I could have the time I spent reading it back. I'm not talking about how it being written as a play makes it awkward to read. I actually didn't mind the format per se. The basis of the story and where it went was very simply terrible. It was not an enjoyable read, and even the ending was unsatisfying.

author: Sarah Campbell
title: Save Your Money, Borrow from Your Local Library
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content: I could go into all the ways this book sucks but I would just be repeating what everyone else is upset about. VERY poor attempt at trying to keep the Harry Potter world alive.

author: CSThomas888
title: Why 1 star? Because they won't let me choose 0
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
I HATE this..... I hate to say "book". This is not a official continuation of the story we know (I don't care if Joe tells me to my face that it is), and I wish Joe had not let her name be dragged into it.  The issues are as follows:

-The number of plot holes is staggering. Worse than almost any fanfic I've ever read.
-All the character building in the original books has been promptly scraped.
-The laziest, and most cliche plot device that exists in media.
-The wasted potential! This is what hurt the most. The more basic and reasonable plot points could have build into such an amazing story.

If you want to know what happens I will summarize to the best of my abilities.
SPOILERS!!!
SPOILERS!!!
SPOILERS!!!

So Albus and Scorpius become friends on the train and both end up in Slytherin (good stuff in my opinion) Amos Diggory calls on Harry and asks him to go back in time and save Cedric. Harry says no. Albus overhears and decided he and his new friend should embark on this nonsensical quest for someone they don't know to save the other person they heard of maybe once, with no motivation of their own. In short they mess up time in may ways many times to the point where Voldemort had killed Harry in the 2nd Wizard war and Albus doesn't exist. After this being fixed through silly means it turns out that Voldemort had a daughter with Bellatrix and she had orchestrated this elaborate scheme to bring Voldemort back. She tried to confront Voldemort only to find that it is Harry in disguise and they fight, and she actually gets the upper hand on him ( a trained Auror) before, once again, Harry has to be saved by his friends. Anyways they beat her and imprison her.

fin.

author: Noreetachan
title: Astonishingly poor drama
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2016
content: Astonishingly crappy dialogues, predictable and cliché parent and child conflicts, poor dynamics in the build up of the drama, hollow and cheesy ending. I as the reader was treated as an imbecile throughout. Something essential must be missing compared to the stage version.

author: crichter
title: Don't bother!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2016
content: Dialogue between characters is horrendous.  Main characters from previous 7 don't "feel" the same at all, their personalities have been butchered.

author: Megan
title: Grateful that it was made available, but a major disappoinment plot-wise
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 31, 2016
content:
I started reading the Harry Potter books when I was eleven years old, and the last movie premiered when I was nineteen.  I was part of the Harry Potter generation to the fullest, reading and writing theories, attending midnight releases, solving the puzzles on Jo's website, reading the new books in one sitting.  I have enjoyed the supplementary material, hoped to visit the theme park, looked forward to the Fantastic Beasts films.  This play is the one and only aspect of the Harry Potter franchise that has been a major disappointment to me.

First, I want to address the format.  Many complaints are being directed at the script format being difficult to read.  This does not bother me.  This story was intended as a play and I am grateful that the script was made available to the public.  It is meant to be brought to life on the stage rather than in the reader's mind, and there are inherent limitations that come with that.

However, when it came to the story, I was not impressed.  Generally, I felt that it read like fanfiction, and not even the best fanfiction. While I enjoyed the little nostalgic nods placed throughout the story, I found that the characters I love were lost, the plot was lacking and even problematic, and Rowling's well thought-out version of time travel was ruined. I could say a lot more but I want to avoid specifics/spoilers, so suffice it to say that I will *not* be considering this play a part of the Harry Potter canon.

author: Kathleen C Kirby
title: The story is cursed
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2016
content: I was thoroughly disappointed with this story, which is unfortunate as we have read the other stories multiple times as a family.  I agree with the other reviewers who noted the lack of moral compass in the story and how the major characters are changed.  In addition, the prose is poorly written compared to the other HP stories which are magnificently authored. This does seem more like fan fiction than an actual extension to the story.  I'm sure the play is a great experience and I really appreciate the theatre, but this is not an HP story.

author: Anas Mahmood
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2017
content: i dont like the book

author: Holly
title: Don't bother to read it.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
content: It was nothing like the Harry Potter Series.  I have to doubt that JK Rowling had much to do with it at all.  The book did not ready like her style of writing, regardless of it being a play.  It was simple and extremely dumbed down, written like a very bad fan fiction.  I was very disappointed and sorry I spent the money.  Buyer be ware.

author: Nina Minor
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 26, 2016
content: She has gone nuts, no other way to put it, and never will.

author: Caho
title: Disappointing
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 29, 2016
content: Disappointing. Very little character development and predictable plot "twists." All our favorite HP characters became lackluster adults and the new children seem incapable and a bit idiotic, which starkly contrasts with the children in the original series. May better translate on stage.

author: Deon Bothma
title: JK sadly missed the mark
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content: Save your money and dont buy it. I fully knew this was a script when i bought it.  But even as a script this publication lacked heart and emotion. Definately not Potter worthy.

author: Jenn Kelly Elischer
title: Definitely Not Up To JK Rowling's Usual Standard
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 7, 2017
content: I was very disappointed with this book. It is written in the studio format, which is probably the only way the authors could get it to work. It is obvious that JK Rowling did not write this; it is so far away from the usual quality workmanship we've come to expect from the author of the Harry Potter series. The story here, if there is one, is disjoined and choppy with glaring omissions and convenient scene changes which seem to be used not to move the story along, but rather used as a device to get the characters out of an untenable situation. This could have been a really good book; unfortunately, it is not. Don't waste your money --- borrow it from the library if you simply must read everything about Harry Potter and friends. But, prepare to be disappointed.

author: Aaron Butts
title: Let's pretend this didn't happen
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2016
content: really disappointed with this play. I really wanted to like it but it made it so hard. Probably the most frustrating thing was being a former actor and reading the directions for this play and wondering "how the hell would they do that on a stage"?

author: Leigh Young
title: If you love the Harry Potter books
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content: If you love the Harry Potter books, then most likely you will not like this script.  I was very excited about it but just a few pages in I realized I was not going to enjoy it.  I can get past that it was a script, but the characters did and said things that do not follow who they are and how we know them from the original series. If it had just been about the boys and their adventure without bringing the the major players from the book series back in, they might have been able to pull it off. When you read certain lines and emotions that Harry, Draco, and even Dumbledore say or feel, it doesn't come across as realistic.  HUGE disappointment.

author: Amazon Customer
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2016
content: I was looking so forward to reading the book. Not the screen play. I was so Bummed.

author: mray
title: NOT A STORY!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content: What a joke.  Don't waste your money.  This is a script that you would direct a play from, not a book you sit and read.  A great disappointment to my son.

author: Amazon Customer
title: No. Just, no.
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: I think casual fans will really like this, but if you're a big Harry Potter fan it's very disappointing. Years of character development are thrown out the window, and the plot holes are more like craters. Overall the dialogue is poorly written, the characters are over to top, and the basis of the plot is beyond ridiculous. Because this is a script book you really don't get any emotion out of the story. I'm sure it's beautiful on stage, but on paper it's a disaster.

author: Marina Buchanan
title: No.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2016
content:
I am a huge fan of Harry Potter and have passed that love on to my children. However if I have my way, my children will never know of this book. It is a discredit to the entire series and does not give life to the world that I fell in love with. Huge disappointment.

I would agree with the reviews on here that say the book reads a lot like a fanfiction. Though some interesting ideas were portrayed, I do not feel they were well developed and it fails to surprise the way the other books did. The plot is an overly used and worn out version we have seen a dozen times in other stories and Harry deserved better.

Harry himself seems lost in this story and while parenting is a constant learning process - he appears to have forgotten himself in this story. Some of the actions he takes regarding his son's friend seem out of character to man who's friends mean everything to him.

author: M. Scott
title: Trash.  Utter Trash!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content: The female characters are flat, stereotype, caricatures used as accessories.  Not a single strong, intelligent, dynamic female character, not even Hermione (whose success is dependent upon the love, attention, and approval of her husband, turning into a "psychopath" without it despite her childhood brilliance and ambition).  As if Rose being depicted as a condescending, egotistical, bulling snob and then being completely written out, Hermione's dependence upon marriage to Ron for her adult success and decency, referring to "her sins" stereo-typically sexist harking back to Eve's original sin, Delphi being the evil witch the men have to save the world from, wasn't bad enough, they didn't even redeem the ending to reflect the obvious consequences of the hero's hate being their own self-fulfilling downfall.  It is the hero's blindness (Harry, Ron, Hermione, Ginny, Draco) that causes the inevitable war.  They are blinded by hate.  THEY lacked empathy and mercy at the end of this story.  They are turned into the REAL antagonists.  The writers had the opportunity to allow Delphi to see Voldemort, giving him the love he needed to break the curse (which was loneliness and the absence of love) that made him cold in the first place.  Delphi's crime was that she wanted to see her father and make him proud?  What kind of hero/role-model is Harry Potter who cannot empathize with that?  This book has turned the Harry Potter hero's, once decent role-models, capable of recognizing their mistakes and the underlying reasons for bad deeds in others, into stagnate, rigidly judgmental, hypocrites who mirror those they demonize and pat themselves on the back for doing so.  The ending should have reconciled the hero's hatred and allowed them to be dynamic characters.  It is truly nothing more than a great author selling-out and cashing-in on her big success.  It is an ultimate betrayal and disgrace.  I'm not just disappointed.  I am insulted.

author: Madison
title: Just relying on the fans' loyalty, instead of good writing...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
SPOILERS AHEAD

Let me start off by saying I love Harry Potter. Like, seriously, I LOVE Harry Potter with a passion. I've read all the books multiple times, frequently watch the movies, and have made the pilgrimage to Universal Orlando. But even I'm not "blinded by love" enough to ignore the fact that Harry Potter and the Cursed Child was really, truly awful.

I just finished reading it and honestly, it just read like badly thought out fan fiction to me. They completely disregarded the rules of magic regarding time turners, I thought the characterizations of a lot of the characters were completely off (there was nothing Harry wanted more in life than to have a family. Don't tell me he would have been a screw up dad.), and the whole thing about Harry being able to speak parseltongue again made absolutely no sense. He was only able to speak parseltongue because of the horcrux living within him--when the horcrux died, that ability died with it.

And in all honesty, the plot just seemed plain lazy. "Oh yeah, let's just throw some alternate universes at them and give the Dark Lord a daughter! That'll work! And doesn't contradict ANYTHING in the original series!" I didn't have high hopes coming into this, but it just seems like they didn't even try to come up with a creative story. I can't tell you how utterly disgusted I am with all of this. I mean, really? Voldemort and Bellatrix having a daughter? That's bad fan fiction at it's finest.

The one saving grace of the script was Scorpius. He was a fun character to read about, and his character had some of the spark that the original books had, but even he's not enough to save the script. At the end of the day, one decent character can't save a terrible plot. I honestly wish they'd never put this out. The series had a good ending, we didn't need this to come along and muck everything up. The fans were happy (for the most part) with how the series originally ended. Who's gonna be happy with Harry being a screw up dad, a cheap Voldemort knock off plot, and contradictions galore? I know I'm not.

author: Amazon Customer
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2017
content: Terrible its horrible to read

author: Lucila Healy
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: Terrible book

author: Old Wizard
title: Huge disappointment
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content: So very very sad ... Rowling created a special place, special characters and encouraged millions of people to READ ... this work was pointless, poorly executed, poorly conceived and an overall disappointment.  Silly story line, further damaged by weak characters and ultimately destroyed by making it a play ... should have stopped at 7 J.K..

author: SM
title: Not what I wanted
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2016
content:
Not what I wanted and its a pain to ship back.
It was written in "play"format

author: Marisabelle
title: A Sad Waste of Time and Money
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2016
content:
No need to reiterate what others have said in great and passionate detail.  The following are my main problems:

SPOILERS AHEAD:

1.  Why JKR allowed anyone but herself to write a story using her characters is a huge mystery to me.  It's obvious from the get-go that she did not write the story because the characters speak and behave NOTHING like themselves.  Moreover, the writing is, at best, mediocre.  Even allowing for the skills and talents of actors and the emotion with which they might imbue the dialogue, I can't imagine it would come out sounding anything but boring.  It simply has no **heart**.

2.  Can anyone really envision Voldemort having sex--like, *ever*?  Really?  I don't think I've ever read a more asexual character, anywhere.  So it was basically impossible for me to suspend disbelief to accept that he had a love child with Bellatrix.  Nope.  Sorry.  Never would have happened (despite that *she* surely would have wished it had).  Thus, since I couldn't accept the premise on which the entire story is based, the whole thing just didn't work for me.  At all.

3.  Twenty-plus years of marraige, and Ron and Hermoine still seem like the worst-matched couple, ever.  I love them both, but living their day-to-day lives under the same roof, raising a family...?  I still can't envision it.

4.  Hermoine--Minister of Magic...?  Makes me sad for her--like she's never learned to loosen up at all, is still trying to control everything around her (and why? What's she so afraid will happen?).  Also, it seems like a terrible waste of magical talent; I mean, why take the "best student of the year" and turn her into an adminstrator who, doubtless, spends most of her time in meetings, organizing stuff, and making decisions that other people will execute.  As I said, it makes me sad--and, maybe, a little disgusted.

I wish I could think of at least one thing I liked about the play, but I'm very sorry to say that I can't.  I have to chalk it up to a waste of time and money.

author: Andrew
title: Umm
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: Written like a play? I was excited to get this book and I had no idea. This is by far the worst thing I've ever read, I'll be sure to ignore anything else with "Harry Potter" in the title because the series is truly dead. Don't waste your time, this book is stupid.

author: shellgirlreader
title: My 11 year old son is a die hard Harry ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2016
content: My 11 year old son is a die hard Harry Potter fan. He re- reads the books frequently and casts spells often. He started reading the kindle version and then insisted that I take him to the book store because the version on his kindle certainly was the wrong one. He's convinced that JK Rowling had nothing to do with this book.

author: Bryce2113
title: See the Future, Just Without the Detail
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2016
content: Having read all of the books at least twice (and many four times), I missed the level of detail offered in the normal series. The book's format leaves many things out that made the HP books so brilliant. Overall, the story is solid and it's a great glimpse into our beloved characters' futures.

author: Zach Whittle
title: Absolutely terrible.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2016
content: This book is absolutely terrible. Right off the bat, the writing leaves much to be desired. As the story goes on, the plot makes less and less sense. The characters are nothing like the ones that we've come to know over the last seven books and the sheer amount of plot holes is frankly embarrassing. This reads like it was written during a night of heavy cocaine use. It should never have been made.

author: Marc Wieber
title: Did not like the reading format
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2016
content: The format of being written in "play rehearsal" form was extremely aggravating. It was very hard to follow having to read a name next to every line

author: Elle Michelle
title: This was such a disappointment. I'm honestly wondering how much input J
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content: This was such a disappointment.  I'm honestly wondering how much input J.K. Rowling even had in writing this.  The characters were out of character, the plot was awful, the dialogue was bad. I didn't even care that it was written in play form.  I felt like I was reading a bad fan fiction written by some 12 year old.  I don't recommend this to any fans of Harry Potter.

author: Christina L. Kelson
title: Not impressed
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: I have not read the series but my 9 year old son has so he was expecting a book not a play script.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Very disappointed. Did not like play format either
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: Seemed to just recap old scenes. Very disappointed. Did not like play format either.

author: Katie
title: Don't Waste Your Money
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2016
content: This script was extremly disappointing. No one in their right mind should be able to enjoy it, and all the good reviews that you see...those people are just blindsighted by the fact that this is considered "Harry Potter". There are fanfictions out there that are more entertaining and more well-written that this utter peice of crap. The plot was batshit crazy, the characters, minus Scorpius Malfoy, were static and flat, not to mention how ridiculously stupid the writers were to include lame plot devices like timeturners. But hey, if you want to read a terrible fanfiction-like story written by inexperienced 12-year-olds, go ahead and be my guest. I just hope you ship Voldy and Bellatrix. Oh and don't forget the Mary Sue character Dephi, famously modeled after Ebony Darkness Dementia Ravenway.

author: Daniel
title: Don't waste your time
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 11, 2017
content: I don't understand how this was ever approved.  I would give it a 0 out of 5 if I could.

author: Cindy
title: Very disappointed
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2017
content: I was able to adjust to the format change in the first few pages. The problem was the lack of everything I love about HP. This was just a stupid waste of time and I've no desire to see the play. Come on J.K., give us what we love, what made you such a huge success!!

author: Michael Johnson
title: Huge Disappointment
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content: Like many on here, I purchased this more or less blind on Kindle, expecting something written by Rowling. This is sub standard as literature, although the play itself may well be excellent in performance.

author: Darth Kitty
title: Zaps all the magic out of the magical world of Harry Potter
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content: All wrong! I'm not sure how much "input" J.K. Rowling actually had into this piece of rubbish, as the characters that we have all grown to love are so completely out of character it's shameful. Rowling penned Dumbledore as once saying, "We must all face the choice between what is right and what is easy"...this was very clearly the easy route to a quick buck at the expense of Potter fans who trusted that Rowling would not lead them astray. Alas, we were very much mistaken.

author: Eric K.
title: A Sad Disappointment.  So Many Plot-Holes It's Ridiculous.  PLEASE just wait for it to be in the library!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2016
content:
WARNING:  SPOILERS!!!!
Pros:
- Albus becomes a Slytherin, and how Harry is perfectly fine with that. It erases the stereotype of  'all good main characters get to be Gryffindors'.

- Scorpious is not the antagonist or a hated character.  It makes me so happy that the son of Draco is friends with Harry's son.  Even though a lot of the school seems to think that he's a son of Voldemort, we get to see who he really is.

- We got to see Severus Snape again.  After we found out that Severus was a good guy, and actually had a soft side, he dies.  We never really get a chance to learn who he really is.  I'm really happy that we got a chance to see him again in this series.  My favorite part of this book was when Scorpios tells Snape about his love for Lily and how Harry named his child after Snape. I liked how he told him how he was proud that he carries his name.

- I also liked how we got to see what would have happened if Voldemort had won. I'm sure we have all wondered at least once what would have happened. I thought it was cool to see that alternate reality.

Cons:
- The relationship between Albus and Harry... All Harry wanted growing up was a father, but he's not a father figure for Albus. Albus wishes Harry was not his father and Harry wishes that Albus was not his son... it was just so out of character and I'm not sure where the anger is coming from.

- The whole Time-Turner plot... there was a reason that Rowling destroyed all of the Time-Turners in the fifth book.  And now there are two Time-Turners?  Oh wait... but noo... One of them is fake.  And our favorite, super-high-IQ, GREATEST WITCH OF THE AGE Hermione Granger decides to hide it in a LIBRARY.  Who would have guessed??  And when Scorpious and Albus go back and try to save Cedric... THEY HAVE NO IDEA WHAT HAPPENED AND WHAT ROLE HE PLAYED. In the end of the '19 Years Later' They ask why everyone is staring and Ron says, "Because I'm famous." This makes me think that they don't really know what happened during and before the battle of Hogwarts.

- How on earth did Ron end up running the joke shop?  What happened to George?  Ron became an Auror.  George was literally my favorite character, and probably the favorite character of a lot of other people, and suddenly the book decides: 'oh.  Well, we don't really need George Weasley for the plot, so we can just pretend he doesn't exist.'  His brother died.  Why would they not carry on the beautiful and tragically sad legacy of Fred and George Weasley?

- Rose is a bit of a bully 'Al. We need to concentrate.  On who we choose to be friends with.'... 'On the contrary, it's exciting.  I'm a Granger-Weasley, you're a Potter--everyone will want to be friends with us, we've got the pick of anyone we want.'...'We rate them all and then we make a decision.'  I get that the authors wanted her to  be a sort of Hermione-like character, but this is a little overboard.

- The rumor about Scorpious being the son of Voldemort.  It didn't really make sense to me because it didn't change the plot. I have no idea why it was mentioned. Just so that he was bullied? I'm not sure it was needed.

- The whole thing with Bellatrix being pregnant with Voldemort's child.  Not once did the book mention anything about her being pregnant or looking pregnant.  Then, she dies.  When did she give birth to Delphi?  Also wasn't she too old?  She must have been around seventy years old.  Tom Riddle's diary was dated to fifty years before Harry was at Hogwarts, and Voldemort and Bellatrix were in the same year.  Before the battle of Hogwarts, Harry was seventeen.  Bellatrix was sixty-seven years old.

- Voldemort could not love because he was conceived by a love potion, and also he was so gone from all of the Horcruxes.  If he wanted an heir, he could have just preserved a part of him in a Horcrux, and then brought himself back to life again.  He already did it once, why not do it again?

- Trolly Lady... what... So Albus and Scorpious climb on top of the Hogwarts Express..., and the old Trolley Lady appears there, pushing her trolley (how on earth did she get the trolley up there?!)  and becomes a monster or something.  Suddenly, she says that James and Sirius tried to escape, and then Fred and George, and now them.  But none of the others escaped.  Fred and George seem to be considerably more intelligent than the main characters, but the main characters escape anyway... I get the Percy Jackson vibe; old ladies turning into monsters.  What's with the exploding pumpkin pasty thing, anyway?  Why would an old lady need a grenade sweet?  Why is she allowed to work on a train that is stuffed with children if she is a senile psychopath?

- The whole Delphi thing.  I read that and all these characters from Percy Jackson started coming to mind...She had an augurey tattoo on her arm, and she was obsessed with a prophecy.  I was suspicious of her from the beginning.  And also... how on earth did she appear in the room?  She's just randomly on the staircase.  Then, when Albus and Scorpious go back in time to bring a random boy back to life, she goes right along and is all like: 'okay, let's do it!'  These main characters are teenage boys, which already means that their common sense level is kind of low.  She decides to go right along and trust them with this endeavor?  It doesn't make any sense.

- Scorpious's mother's death was supposed to be an emotional event, but I didn't care much about the mother, mostly because she had never been mentioned in the book.

- Amos Diggory suddenly becomes lost in the past and is releasing all of this pent up anger about his dead son.  "They did not blame him for what had happened; on the contrary, both thanked him for returning Cedric's body to them. "  That is a quote from the Fourth book after Harry returned from the Maze.  Amos was a reasonable man, even after his son's death.  It doesn't make sense that nineteen years later he would suddenly become so angry.  It wasn't clear as to whether he was confunded or imperiosed or something, because at the beginning he says Delphi is his niece, but at the end, he says he had no niece.

-  The whole thing about Harry's scar hurting doesn't make any sense.  Harry's scar originally hurt because Voldemort was feeling some sort of strong emotion, or was somewhere near.  It doesn't make sense that he would feel it because VOLDEMORT IS DEAD. It was a hard life but we did it. And then his scar is hurting again and we all get the impression that he is alive. Why is his scar connected to Delphi?  Harry was connected to Voldemort because part of Voldemort's soul went into Harry.  Harry's soul couldn't have been passed down to Delphi, or Harry would have felt his scar hurting long before.

- The thing about Delphi being obsessed with a prophecy... Again... Percy Jackson, and also, how wouldn't harry have heard of this before if it obviously concerned him?  It would have been next to the first prophecy ball (neither shall live while the other survives) because it was all in alphabetical order, and if it was about Harry, it would have been right there.  Also, weren't all the prophecies in that section destroyed?  If so, then why does Delphi know about this?  She was born so many years later.

-  Harry starts getting these strange prophetic dreams.  (Again, like Percy Jackson)  But before it was just seeing out of Voldemort's eyes... feeling the emotions that he was feeling.  And now... What exactly is he dreaming about?

- When Delphi randomly whips out this polyjuice potion, it immediately set off a bunch of alarms in my head.  Who carries around bottles of Polyjuice potion?  It takes a month to make.  A MONTH.  And she randomly has it.  Also, how did she get the hairs of Ron, Harry, and Hermione?  As far as we know, nobody has heard of her before, except for Amos, who might have been confunded, which means that she probably hasn't met any of them, other than Harry.  (She was on the staircase the night that Amos came to visit.)

- When Albus, Scorpious, and Delphi infiltrate the Ministry as Harry, Ron, and Hermione, Albus(Ron) blocks the door to Hermione's office, saying that he might have left a Stinkbomb there.  Hermione never questioned Ron about it later.  Why didn't they get caught?

- How did Delphi know all of these spells?  She probably bewitched Amos, and she definitely used spells to subdue Albus and Scorpious but she never went to a magic school or Hogwarts.

- When Albus and Scorpious go back in time for the first time, Hermione is some sort of Snape professor.  How did she become so bitter?  I know that she was in love with Ron, but, knowing Hermione, she would probably rationally set all of her emotions straight and find someone else.

- The second time, they say that Albus went down the sink.  A sink.  How on earth did he disappear down the sink?  Sink drains are pretty small as far as I can remember.

- When Albus and Scorpious go back in time to the night that Harry got his scar, they figure out that they can send a message to Harry through some sort of magical...potion... chemical reaction.  How did they find the time to go into the house, unwrap baby Harry, find whatever dust they needed, write the message, and wrap it back around baby Harry?  How did they do it unnoticed?  And even then, how did Harry not notice the words on the blanket before?  From the other times they went back in time, we know that the two times aren't parallelly existing.  I'm sure that Harry would have noticed strange holes that looked like numbers burned into his precious baby blanket.  And when they found out that they could make a chemical reaction... It wouldn't work because the love potion wasn't on the blanket when Harry was a baby.

- Delphi destroys the time turner.  But she seems to do it with physical force.  'She crushes the Time-Turner.  It explodes in a thousand pieces.'  How could something so valuable be destroyed but someone's hand?  It makes no sense.

- When Harry gets transformed into Voldemort, his disguise starts to wear off.  Firstly, his transformation was not caused by a Polyjuice potion, so it wouldn't wear off like a potion.  Secondly, the only reason that Harry, Ron, and Hermione's disguises disappeared in the seventh book was because of the waterfall.  So why did Harry's disguise disappear?

- At the end, Harry and Albus have this bonding moment and talk about their fears.  Harry says he's afraid of darkness, which, in a way makes sense, since he had major issues with Dark Wizards and whatnot, but PIGEONS?!  Seriously?  If this was supposed to be a joke for younger children, okay, fine, it might be slightly humorous, but in reality... Not once was this mentioned in the previous series, and Harry had to have discovered his fear of pigeons earlier.  For people who are older, the joke was completely unnecessary and made no sense.

-  TEDDY LUPIN?!!  Where are you???  This one really struck me hard.  All of the hardships that Nymphadora Tonks and Lupin went through, and they don't mention anything about their legacy?  They finally admit their feelings for each other.  They get married.  A child is born.  They die to defeat the Dark Wizard.  They die for the protection of their son.  When Lupin sees Harry while he has the resurrection stone, he says "I am sorry too... Sorry I will never know him [Teddy]... but he will know why I died and I hope he will understand."  Well, from what the book tells us, Teddy never did know why his parents died.  Teddy didn't exist.

Overall, this book seems to ba a fanfiction book that has J.K. Rowling's name on it. Maybe she was in it for the money? I have been reading Harry Potter for forever and I am absolutely obsessed with the series. But this book isn't the complex, well thought-out book we are used to seeing.  There are so many little plot holes that might have been smoothed out if Rowling actually wrote the book, or even if it was in book form.  I did enjoy some parts of the book, and I must admit I was super excited when I saw its cover in Barnes and Nobles, but I was sadly disappointed.  I hope that the play form is different, and maybe it can be enjoyed by more people.  The book is a new style, for sure, but the Harry Potter series just aren't supposed to be written in play form.  The book ended up being a little flat.  If J.K. Rowling wanted to tie up the Harry Potter series with something that was memorable in a good way, this wasn't the best way to do it.  I still don't consider this book as part of a series, and I'm praying with all my heart that Rowling does something with her talent and creates some sort of sequel that doesn't have so many plot holes.  I'm just glad that the original series is something timeless.

Just a note:  This book isn't worth buying if you haven't bought it already.  If you want to read it, I would recommend waiting for it to come out in a library.  I spent twenty-two dollars on the book, and now I wish I had just waited.

** Sorry the review was so long.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Wish I had a Time-Turner to Unread This
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2016
content:
*Some spoilers* I get that this is a script for a play and that you need to SEE it to really get into the world of Harry Potter again.  I get that there are new characters and I am asked to get to know and love them from a bare-bones script whereas I spent years learning and loving the original characters.  What I DON'T get is why almost every one is so damn unlikable. Albus is as annoying as Harry circa Order of the Phoenix with his angst. Ron--on paper--is a caricature of his former self: his corniness is highlighted in a less than enduring way, his mediocrity more glaring than ever.  Hermione seems to be an ineffective leader and hardly believable as the head of the magical world. Harry is just--awful, just awful. Draco suddenly became overly emotional and unlike the haughty, cold British boy I loved before. Scorpius is the saving grace and pretty much the only likeable person.

And then there are the glaring plot holes...why is Cedric Diggory only one awful event away from becoming one of the worst people ever? His honor, valor, chivalry, and fairness are what his character was about--so one bad day turns him into a demon for all time? No. Unconvincing. Why--WHY--if the Malfoys had real Time-Turners, wouldn't they have gone back and achieved their plans before? Or if they acquired them after Voldemort's fall, they still could have gone back in time and made Draco a hero--which is befitting of their prideful ways and would have been pretty interesting. The love-child with Bellatrix and Voldemort is just wrong.  Of course we knew Bellatrix was panting after him, but Voldemort seemed to be apart from lust of any kind for a woman. It is just awkward and disgusting. It also seems like Bellatrix would have piped up about such a thing prior to the war, or even any of the Malfoys. It also seems that the baby would have been made into another Horcrux if she was so top secret.

Finally, perhaps the most annoying thing of all to me, is the just plain weirdness of some things. There seems to be a lot more SPOKEN emotion in the play.  In all 7 of the original books, none of the characters say "I love you" or anything. Their love is implied and demonstrated in their actions and this somehow makes it more realistic than mushy words, however in this play they are all about the mushy sentiments and it is just out of character for them. And there is this one scene with Albus--who is 14--disguised as Ron with the aid of polyjuice potion is trying to distract Hermione from going inside of her office and is practically making out with her and actually says he wants to have another baby with her. Ew.

I would see the play if I am ever in London, or if it travels to the US, but only to see if it redeems itself somehow in some measure. It will never be right or perfect and I wish I had a time-turner so I can unread this crap and go back to platform 9 3/4 to see a bright-eyed 11 year old Albus off on the train and leave the saga there.

author: Kit
title: Trust in Rowling and Harry Potter lost
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2016
content: This isn't even fanfiction. The characters are ridiculous and the writing is oh-so-bad. People were actually hysterical when I read parts out loud to them - "her spikes particularly spiky" ? No... really? Regardless of the content... it is some of the worst writing... ever. I've seen middle school students write better. Now, onto content: At least fanfiction understands and respects the original content. This piece breaks tons of pre-established rules set down by the HP series. Polyjuice can be whipped up in an instant? Azkaban lets people out on parole I suppose? The trolley witch is the terminator? Ron is some strange man we've never met before. Harry is the worst father on the planet. Ginny - oh, poor sweet Ginny. She could have been a great athlete but instead she is an utterly depressed housewife-type whose only solace is found in Draco. Yes, apparently Ginny and Draco are best buds because they are constantly having little asides of their own - and really who can blame Ginny with Harry constantly throwing his life story into her face. As for Albus and Scorp, they are obviously in love, complete with strange scenes of doe-eyed longing on moving staircases. I'm fine with that. In fact, I applaud it. I wish the writers had. Instead they turn around and shove down your throat "NOPE! See, they like these girls who will inevitably rip out their hearts!" (quite literally in one respect). Bellatrix was pregnant and no one knew... despite having the baby at Malfoy Manor... where... you know, everyone was? Draco didn't know despite living there? Bella, who was obsessed with Voldemort, didn't take out an ad in the Daily Prophet announcing her unbridled joy at such an honor? Please. And these are all just a small sampling of the insane things you will read inside. I'm so disappointed that Rowling put her name on this and as such has helped it enter canon. All trust lost. The rest of this is all just greedy money-making.  Don't be sucked in.

Also Snape still would have been killed!!! Do you seriously think Voldemort would have been okay NOT have full ownership of the Elder Wand?! NO!! Snape is D-E-A-D!!

author: Briana
title: VERY DISAPPOINTED - Story is ridiculous and there are way too many plot holes
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2016
content: I have been reading Harry Potter since the first book came out and am a huge fan. I loved the books and read them at least 5 times each (probably more). I wanted to like this book but it was really hard for me to finish because it was so bad. I used to read the original Harry Potter books nonstop until I finished them. I read the last book for 10 hours straight and that was around 900 pages. It's two weeks after I got this book and I can't even get myself to finish the last 50 pages of this book. It's obviously not written by JK Rowling and the whole story is ridiculous. The rules that JK Rowling set up for going back in time in the Prisoner of Azkaban somehow don't apply in this book. Ron and Harry don't even appear to be the same characters. Ron somehow turned really funny and Harry is a bad dad that doesn't understand his kid. The Harry that I know from the original books would have got to know his kid and his kid wouldn't resent him for no reason. Also, there's NO WAY that Voldemort would have had a kid. He couldn't love and I cant imagine him liking anyone touching him. This book feels like fantasy when the other books felt real. I hope that JKR contributed very little to this because of how poorly it is written. If she contributed even 5% of this storyline, I am very disappointed in how this story of Harry's life and his children's life are going. If JKR wanted to create a play, she should have done a story about the Marauders at Hogwarts or during the first war against Voldemort. She could have even done a story about the Harry's kids at Hogwarts facing other evils but to create a child of Voldemort feels fake and like the story just needed a villain and used almost the same one as all the other books. I am very disappointed. I wish this book had never come out at this point because it puts a damper on the original books. I'm going to live in denial and pretend that this didn't come out and this isn't the future for the Wizarding World. As far as I am concerned, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows concluded the story and Harry's scar never hurt again. All was well and should have stayed well.

author: michelle knutson
title: None of the "magic"

content:
18 years ago I couldn't put the series down. I was completely hopeful that I could recapture the world and be in the Potter induced euphoria that I loved.

I am very disappointed. The story itself is bland, but what really emphasizes the fact that this is more fan fiction than anything is the American slang that is somehow embedded in the dialog, with uncharacteristic amounts of pedestrian "emotional" moments.

I need a time turner to go back and keep myself from buying this book, so I can remember the world as it was.

author: SE
title: Childish, terrible story with one dimensional characters
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
Spoilers ahead!

Maybe the script doesn't do justice to the presentation of the play on stage, but the story itself was truly awful. It seemed like a poor man's badly developed fanfiction mashup of Back to the Future and Harry Potter, with characters whose personalities were warped and distorted to fit the childish, fast-paced plot. The internally inconsistent logic (Scorpius and Albus are smart enough to give their father a message in the future...but not smart enough to realize the sheer stupidity of changing a significant historic event?) combined with an almost comedic, eye-roll-inducing villain made it clear that this play is written for kids and pre-teens who probably never even read the original books. Releasing a book with "Harry Potter and the..." in the title, with JK Rowling's name on the cover gave me certain expectations, none of which were met.

I'm not sure how this play will be presented given the special effects requirements, but maybe those will at least distract from the fact that the plot is nonsensical and definitely not the Harry Potter fans know and love.

author: Acanthea Grimscythe | The Ghastly Grimoire
title: this book sucks. To put into perspective how much this book ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 14, 2017
content:
I clearly remember the I discovered Harry Potter. I don’t remember my age, but I do recall the place. My Dad took us to Barnes & Noble in Little Rock, AR. I couldn’t find a book I wanted to read. Seeing Harry Potter and the Sorcerer’s Stone on a cardboard display, Dad pointed to it. That night, I discovered never-ending magic.

Or so I thought. Let’s be frank, shall we? I pride myself on my ability to remain unbiased when writing a review about a book. Sometimes I’m friends with the author, sometimes I’m asked to cover it, sometimes I choose to. No matter what manner brings this book to me, I’m honest. I will remain the same with Harry Potter and the Cursed Child. That said, this book sucks.

To put into perspective how much this book sucks, let me put it this way: I dropped it. The only other book I haven’t finished is Outlander. Harry Potter and the Cursed Child is based on work by Rowling, but it is not a Harry Potter book. Not in the sense that those of us who grew up with it see it, anyways. When Harry Potter and the Cursed Child came out, I felt as much excitement as the next fan. After attempting to read it, I chose to leave the series where it ended in Deathly Hollows.

Harry Potter and the Cursed Child is not so much a continuation of the series as it is a fan-fiction. And while there is good fan-fiction out there, this is not an example of it. This book (or screenplay) is a desperate attempt to continue a completed series. Not only does it fail to breathe life back into the friends of our childhood, but it does so with a timeline restrained by rules of the theater.

Even worse, the friendship that blossoms between Albus and Scorpio seems too farfetched. It’s as if the screenwriters sought yet another retelling of Shakespeare’s Romeo and Juliet. A retelling that doesn’t do the pair justice, from what others that forced themselves to finish the book have told me. The only thing I find worse than romance in a story is a romance that falls short of its potential.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Harry Potter and the Cursed Child (by J.K.Rowling) is neither Harry Potter nor by J.K.Rowling. It's Trash.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
Some said a play script isn't supposed to be read on paper, and that the play is fantastic. But the script is also HP canon now, with all these flat characters, cliche dialogue and a contradictory plot. Maybe he actors can cover the issues and make the play enjoyable, but the canon is spoiled anyway.

---- Spoilers below ----

The familiar characters are humiliated.
Harry, who fought Voldemort face-to-face at 16, the Master of Death, an Auror, is now an insecure man who needs to occasionally hold his baby blanket (that's not a metaphor), loses self-control, never fights alone and is afraid of darkness and pigeons. I'd understand PTSD - actually, it'd be pretty interesting - but he's defined as "an average person struggling to be a parent", and it's just insulting.
Hermione, the brightest witch of the century and the Minister of Magic, hides a dangerous artifact behind 3 simple riddles. Even using her mom's maiden name would have been a better security measure.
Ron, who tried to pursue his own ambitions despite being in shadow of his brothers and friends, has not only not reached his potential, he is now a shadow of Fred. All his character development is just thrown away.
Almost nothing is left of Ginny's fierce spirit, of Dumbledore's quirks and wisdom, of Snape's ice cold attitude, of Sedric's unshakable goodness. And if you thought Voldemort and Bellatrix were creepy - believe me, it gets worse.

The plot makes no sense.
Time travel is inconsistent. The authors time model is "whatever lets us fit our fanfics in the canon". The plot holes are everywhere, and I believe the authors didn't even understand how time works. Seriously, the heroes exclaim "there's no time" while holding a timeturner. Harry's scar hurts because Voldemort is about to be brought back - okay, but he's about to be brought back 40 years ago, why would the scar hurt *40 years later in another timeline*?
The villain' plan is so oblique it's surreal; the only explanation why she haven't chosen a reasonable plan is "it was prophesied to be that way".

The writing is horrible. Just, bad-fanfic-level horrible.

And all this hot mess is now canon, retroactively spoiling the previous books.
Also, the trolley witch. I can't even. I'll go weep in the corner.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Don't read it!
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2016
content:
I am a long time Harry Potter fan and I can say this might ruin your view on Harry Potter forever in just 320 pages.
I wasn't expecting much of this book. But I never thought it would be this bad.
The story is ridiculous. There are plot holes on almost every page. The storyline just doesn't seem plausible with the original seven Harry Potter books in mind. It all feels rushed and not well thought through. It isn't fun, it isn't clever, it is not memorable.
The new characters have very little motivation. Everyone has one character identification. Nothing more. They are one-dimensional, they are not likeable. One of them (who is supposed to be liked) is a straight out horrible and shallow person. How are we supposed to like them?
There are a lot of (new and old) characters. I mean in a play we don't get to read what they feel; we just get the dialog. And that works (we have all at least once read a play), but only if we get a lot of the lead characters and only a bit of the supporting ones. Here we get a little bit of everyone and so it is a miracle, that the characters even have one clear trait. They obviously count on the actors to do the job, but as a reader it just doesn't deliver.
Even the "old", known characters feel flat. And here we know the characters from amazing books. They just would have needed the right direction. If Harry had just once acted like the original Harry, we would have thought of all his other character traits, even if they are not mentioned. That is how it works if you have a well-established character. But the original trio is astoundingly dull and boring. They don't resemble the source material at all. If they weren't named Harry, Ron and Hermione i wouldn't have recognised them. Ron for example has now the character traits of Fred and George. He is constantly trying out the joke shop gadgets and he is playing the fool. That doesn't feel like Ron at all. We know how these characters should act and when they don't it feels off. Consequently, the whole play feels off.
When I first bought the book I thought J.K. Rowling had actually written this book in cooperation with other authors. But now I feel like she thought of a story, described it in three sentences and other authors made this play out of it.
I understand that it was never intended that we readers would get the whole experience and I knew that when I bought the book. I could forgive the flat characters and the rushed storyline, because it is a play. But I cannot ignore the plot holes and the way they portrayed all the original characters. It feels like bad fanfiction. Someone had an idea for a good story, but neither time to fully think the plot through, nor experience in portraying characters or getting the right pacing.
Conclusion:
I don’t recommend this book to anyone. If you read the original seven books, you will be deeply disappointed. You will get a poorly told story, without getting the chance to care for any of the characters. Don’t destroy your memory of Harry Potter. Stay with what you know. I will try to forget.
And to anyone unfamiliar to the HP universe: you will not be able to follow the story; it relies too much on the source material. So I would suggest to read the Harry Potter books actually written by J.K. Rowling and then never to come back!

author: Mommination
title: Maybe dementors sucked out all the goodness??
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2016
content: I borrowed this from a friend and I'm delighted I didn't spend my money on this. I was very much aware that it's the play script and that didn't bother me. I looked forward to imagining what the stage looked like, the actors gestures, etc. So the format was not a problem for me. What I simply cannot understand, is how ANY self-proclaiming die-hard HP can could possibly like this story. It's a lame fan fiction at BEST! At the very, very best. Why'd you let them do it, Jo, why??? The script is painful to read. Just plain corny and predictable most of the time. The characters are unrecognizable. Seven years of character development flushed down the tube. You mean to tell me that Harry Potter, who was driven to use an unforgivable curse on Amycus Carrow because the latter dared to spit on McGonagall, that this same Harry Potter would speak to her in such a disrespectful way? This woman who was one of the only two mother figures to Harry?? No way! Not especially when his son is in danger. Not to the woman who stood with him on the eve of the Battle of Hogwarts. It seems every single character had turned into a watered down version of themselves when they grew up. We change as we age, true. But our hope is that we do not lose the essence of who we are. It is a terrible tragedy when that happens. And it's exactly what we're present with in this cursed play. Don't even get me started on what they did to Ron. I could write a whole dissertation on that travesty. So many times, I wanted to stop reading this garbage but I was bound by my no-book-left-unread rule. So I ploughed ahead and finished it. I'm very sorry that my memories and experiences with the HP series is tainted with this tripe.

author: Jim
title: A disappointing abomination. If you want to continue loving Harry Potter, please don't read this sad excuse for toliet pa.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content:
Thank you JK Rowhling for giving me a magical childhood. Then this book came along and smashed it with a hammer.Harry Potter and the Cursed Child is best deacribed as a disappointing abomination. If you want to continue loving Harry Potter, please don't read this sad excuse for toliet paper. I am very disappointed Ms. Rowhling, I really thought you had more respect for your fans.
Personally I have lost alot of repect for you as a writer for allowing this travesty to be released as book 9... I waited 19 years for a book that was supposed to be the book to end all books, literally. I have been a follower and lover of the wizarding world of Harry Potter since Day 1... My old paperback  copy of Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone has been read so many times its held together by tape... all 8 of my books are in some form of shabbiness due to the overwhelming amount of times each were lovingly read. I memorized almost every line, able to repeat the books almost from heart. Well yes 90% of my books on my shelves look like this. Harry Potter was and will always be my favorite series. Then this sad excuse for a story dare I say piece of crap shoved between two decieving covers, disguised as a book I was supposed to love just as much landed on my doorstep. I thought JK Rowhling respected her readers more then this. How could she have been so LAZY as too take a s***ty play written by someone else, slap her cover on, and sell it to her adoring and mislead fan base. My cat could have written a better play.

1. Main characters are nearly unrecognizable from earlier books
2. Story does not follow the history accurately from earlier books
3. Writing is not enchanting
4. Plot holes are very puzzling and annoying

It reads like fan fiction by an author that is not that familiar with the Harry Potter series. If this is the way sequels will go, I am not buying any more in this series. I wished I'd stopped with book 7 so I would not have the bad taste in my mouth from Cursed Child. So sad, So bad.

content: I have to say this was disappointing. Most of the script reads like fanfiction and is basically a rehash of the original books. There is very little that is original or creative. author: Danae Maria Liarou
title: Heartbroken,  and not in a good way.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: Oh where to start... Firstly i am a huge HP fan! Grew up with the novels and they made me who i am today! This was, at the very least, a disappointment!  I didn't mind the script form at all, what i did mind is the terrible, awful and ridiculous plot! I had read spoilers online (never done that before for HP) and was completely "discombobulated" by them. I was certain it was an elaborate hoax by JK and the keep the secrets campaign to throw off fans! I began reading being absolutely sure the real thing would be different! What an utter disappointment it was! Of all the possibilities a vast magical world provides for an original story, they went with the time travel theme. Urgh. I will not go into details for it will take forever to write, and honestly.  i.  just. cant. anymore. This story is as unoriginal as they come. Relying heavily on already tested material, creating plot hole after plot hole, destroying beloved characters, this is a travesty. And it is killing me. The plot is so farfetched and sloppy, so many mistakes! I did  not even nitpick, if i had i dont think i would have finished it at all. I was looking forward to this more than  words can convey. I spent years of my life invested in this world, these characters, and this was a slap in the face. If i wanted fanfiction i would have read it for free. It would probably be better. I will continue hoping this is a hoax gone out of control! PS Scorpius is the only good thing. He is adorkable!

author: Brit
title: I Don't Understand
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content:
I really wished I would have read the reviews before buying the Kindle version. I just don't understand how Rowling could have made such a story like this. She has amazing books, not just from the Harry Potter World. This book is as if a 15 year old girl who was obsessed with the epilogue wrote it all. It's purely fanfiction at the worst level, and I know, I've read some. The characters that we have loved, cried, and laughed at since we first picked up the first book are so different from when they were 17-year-old kids.
I'm very disappointed how it all came out. I really wish someone would obliviate it all from my mind. It doesn't deserve all the hype that it's been getting. I don't know why Rowling's people didn't tell her how awful it was. Bad on them, and her. Thanks for ruining something that could have been great...

author: J. Bradshaw
title: Really Bad!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content: When I first heard that this book was being released and pre-orders would be taken, I was excited. But then I found out that it was in script form and not in novel format. I told my friend that I wasn't going to order it. Well, she gave me a copy for my birthday and I thought I would give it a try. Well, my original gut feeling was right - this is garbage!. Don't waste your time or money. If you feel that you really do need to read it, borrow a copy from your local library. You will see what I mean. JK Rowling ought to be ashamed putting her name on this script! I gave it one star only because I couldn't leave the stars blank!

The plot is nonsensical and at points infuriating; in many ways it reads like bad fanfiction. It is somewhat relieving to know that Rowling doesn't seem to actually have written this - even though her name is the biggest on the cover.
After finishing it, I wished I hadn't read it. If you're expecting the quality that made the other books great, you won't find it here. Do yourself a favor and skip the Cursed Child.

Parts were interesting and I wish that if this was actually something Rowling wanted to develop, she'd taken the time necessary to do so. Overall, it felt very under-developed and half-hearted.

author: Amazon Customer
title: This book is utter crap. It is a case of someone writing their ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: This book is utter crap. It is a case of someone writing their own fan-fiction, and they were somehow lucky enough to get it published with J.K. Rowling's name attached. While there are some good ideas in the play, they are childishly under-developed. The stage directions try way too hard, the references are overly involved with every detail of the original series, and the characters are clearly derived from the authors'  personal fantasies and wishes, and not from the great character sketches Rowling provided throughout the series. Congratulations to Jack Thorne for riding the Hogwart's Money Express. I only gave it one star because I had to give it a star.

author: Samantha Weber
title: A train wreck from start to finish
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
I love the Harry Potter series. I read the books multiple times a year, watch the movies frequently and have read a lot of additional articles from pottermore. I had to wait a few days to get this book because of cash flow issues but Now that I have read it I fully regret ever reading this.

while I was looking forward to this and I knew it would be a script from a play not an in depth novel that I am used to; even with expectations being lowered a little to accommodate this being a play, nothing could prepare me for this travesty of a story.

Firstly: time travel is a weak plot line at best. After waiting years for a new story from Jo we get "what would have happened if Cedric hadn't died" this was such a let down.

Secondly: Cedric being embarrassed during the triwizard tournament would have been enough to cause someone who we remembered as brave, and selfless, to become a death eater? What type of garbage is that? How dare they drag his name through the mud and tarnish his memory like this.

Thirdly: Voldemort has a child? This is such a plot line cop out and even while reading it this doesn't make sense. Voldemort was conceived under a love potion, he doesn't know or understand love. Even with Bellatrix falling head over heels for him, in what universe do these two  get together and make a baby? And wouldn't Hermione have noticed that Bellatrix was pregnant when she used polyjuice potion to become her so they could enter her vault in Deathly Hallows?

And then Scorpious and Albus constantly referring to eachother as their best friend got to be annoying. And I am still wondering what qualities either of these boys possess that had them sorted into slytherin.

There were parts I did enjoy but they were few and far between. This is without a doubt garbage and I hope that Jo did not write this and that a corrected version of this will appear on pottermore or in print at a later date. My only hope is that I can return to reading the original 7 books and seeing the original 7 movies without this mashup of terrible plot lines tarnishing my love for Harry Potter.

author: beverly
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2016
content: it was like eating a piece of unbutterd toast compared to her other Harry Potter books

author: rycette
title: Eh.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
As someone who has read the original books countless times, it would be an understatement to say I was overjoyed at this release. I downloaded the Kindle version at midnight and read it in one sitting.
I'm really sad to say it felt hollow. The reader gets a small look into the characters with little development. Ron is portrayed as a complete goof with no charm. In fact the whole original cast seems to have completely changed with Ginny the only one who turned out even remotely respectable.
The hard part is this is a script. This was written to be depicted by actors and actresses and therefore is lacking detail and strong character development.
I was very disappointed in the story, however it gives me hope that some real books may be on the horizon. I hope to see the play so I can get a full picture, but until then my review stands.

author: NewMomma
title: Awful
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: I don't think J.K. Rowling wrote much of this play. It's awful. The dialogue between the characters is awkward and embarrassingly elementary. I re-read the whole series in anticipation for the release of this play. After finishing it,  I am very disappointed. I can't even think of any good thing to say about it.

author: Jasmin
title: Worst Soap Opera ever
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
I still can not believe that this is actually supposed to be a Harry Potter book or even a play. I am really sorry, but throughout the whole Script my only though was that this has to get better - maybe on page 100. Or on 200. But it never did and thats mainly because the characters apparently ony had one attribute they were showing off: Harry = Insecure, Draco = Unwanted, Ron = "funny", Hermione = Bossy, Ginny = Caring. Only the two boys got a chance to shine once or twice. The plot was predictable most of the times and all the hints they gave throughout the book, came together in the end - no matter how absurd the story became of it though.

If you haven't read it yet and you are a Harry Potter Fan you still should. Not because its great but because we all should realize that only a book coming straight from J.K. Rowling herself will have the magic the books originally had.

author: cw
title: The scar had not pained Harry for nineteen years.  All was well.
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 24, 2019
content:
The only reason I gave it a one star was that I probably couldn't write a review without any stars at all.
It's awful.  Thorne should have left it how it was.  The whole story contradicts the last line of Harry Potter and the deathly hallows, when it says his scar hadn't hurt for the past 19 years.  I hate this so much, that's all I'm going to actually say.
 But there are some thought provoking ideas in it.....
 Ha, who am I kidding? I'm beating around the bush, simply because I can't remember what actually happened.  I read it when it first came out, threw it out the window (where it is still today, lying in the garden, where all vegetation refuses to grow since it is so bad), and haven't read it since.
To be honest, I nearly gave up on Harry Potter after that.  You know what supposedly happens.  Voldemort, or his spawn isn't truly defeated; how can you read each and every one of Harry's victories without having harry Potter and the cursed child whispering in the back of your mind?  But thank heavens for fantastic beasts and where to find them; hope is now in order!!!
Can't wait for number three!

author: Julien A. Sebag
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content: boring

author: Bre
title: Waste of time and money
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 23, 2016
content:
SPOILERS! This might be the worst thing I've ever read. None of the characters felt like themselves. And I must say that the whole time travel thing was a big mistake. I've always thought that The Prisoner of Azkaban handled the time travel aspect rather well and the fact that the "changes" made in the past were actually visible in the present. That being said, if it were possible for someone to go back in time to save Cedric...he wouldn't have died in the first place! This book made me hate time travel plots even more. It is a weak premise to base a book on.
I can't believe JKR allowed this trash to have her name associated with it. If she wanted this story told she should have written it herself in a well thought out book format that didn't have gigantic plot holes and stay true to characters. I'm sure forty year old Harry is different from sixteen year old Harry, but come on!
The play format was very distracting up me. I haven't read a play since high school. But I do remember them to be well written and entertaining with complex characters. This book...thing was none of the above. I'm going to try my best to forget it. This cannot be considered canon!

author: Robert S. Gould
title: Clumsily written and not up to the standard of the Harry Potter series
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 26, 2016
content: Loved all the books, disliked this play (it isn't a book) - as unrealistic, rather stupid, and bored me so that I didn't bother finishing it.
