content: Everyone quit complaining.  This is a PLAY written by two other people, based only on the book written by jk; if even that. Daft play, daft writers, and daft reviewers.  Look at the facts before bashing a prolific, outstanding author as jk.

author: CompassionComfort
title: Not worth it.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
I got this as a gift because I'm a diehard Potterhead...

I don't know how to say this lightly, so I'll just say it: the story is crap.

I'm sure the effects make it fun to see on stage, but the plot was awful, discarding established canon in a major way and adding plotlines that sound like they came from a horribly-written fanfiction. The main characters seemed like different people, too--and not in an "Oh, well, it IS 19+ years later" sort of way, but like they were entirely different personalities who happened to have the same names.

I'm super disappointed that J K Rowling okayed this. It really seems like she only did it for the money. I guess after the ruination of Pottermore and how she treated Native American History, though, I shouldn't be surprised, but it's still extremely upsetting.

author: LH
title: This reads like bad fanfiction
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2017
content: This reads like bad fanfiction. Severely out of character. As a hardcore Harry Potter fan, I found this to be so disappointing that I've discarded my copy. It does not deserve a place of honor with the other Potter books on my shelves. I would give it zero stars if that was an option. Save your money.

author: Amazon Customer
title: A waste of time for me to try to read it
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: So disapointed!!!I did not know it was written as a play, not a book. So much for pre- order. My first mistake. A waste of time for me to try to read it.

author: rainny
title: that almost explains my disappointment. In fact
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2016
content: I knew it was a play, but I didn't notice Rowling wasn't the only author. In my mind, that almost explains my disappointment. In fact, Rowling shouldn't put her name on it at all.  The characters have strangely different personalities, especially Ginny, Ron and Harry. The only person that's still more-or-less true is Hermione. The story is based on a magical world, but there's nothing magical about the story. The story is not different from any other time-travel stories in any significant way. I don't know about anyone else, but I could  totally predict what happens next when reading it. The first half of the book was so boring that I almost decided to throw it away. (Had I known how Rowling didn't have much to do with the book I would have) The story is conventional and full of the cheesy hollywood value about love and family, which is fine except when it's executed in such a bad way. The bottom line is: any Harry Potter fan is capable of writing something like this, and better.

author: AMZRKB
title: Cheap Piece of Fan Fiction
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content: Being a Harry Potter fan I was excited to read this book even though I had low expectations knowing that JK Rowling did not write it and it was in script format. I guess the part I'm really surprised by is that Rowling felt author Jack Thorne had "entered her world" (see her dedication in the book). Despite a lack of character development and details you might get from a novel the first part was mildly amusing and I think had decent potential--mind you, not the potential of the HP series but the potential to not drive me batty. However, in the second part the book completely fell apart and the "plot twist" was not only predictable but extremely unconvincing. My least favorite thing about this book is the way some of our most beloved (and hated) characters were portrayed--McGonagall, Dumbledore, Hermonie, Ron, Harry, Snape, and even Umbridge. I know character development is hard when you're writing a script and not a novel, but these characters hardly resembled the ones of the HP series and did much to deflate my imagination. It felt like Jack Thorne was more concerned with cramming as many of them between the book cover for the nostalgic factor...but there was no nostalgia. Even the new characters were really lacking--Albus, Scorpio, and Delphini. At the end of it all it read like a cheap piece of fan fiction.

author: Melody
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2016
content: Didn't read more than 5 pages.  Not a fan of the screenplay format

author: Cryman021
title: Not at all what was expected.
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2016
content: Love the Harry Potter series.  This however is very predictable and a re-hash of some of the same old spells and events. Very disappointing.

author: Cathy Heinlein
title: Clearly from a different author, it's like one of those flashback shows.
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
There seem to be some significant plot holes in this story. It's not written as well as the first 7 books. The first 7 books go into great depth of each character and let you really get to know them.  This seems to be just written for high action entertainment instead of plot likers.  Besides the plot holes it seems to contradict things from the book series.  It was an easy read that I finished in 24 hours.  There were very clear differences between the books that were writtten by JK and this joint effort. This book lacks her wit and humor and just repeats things from her books.  I've read and loved the 7 Harry Books she wrote MANY times. So it was very tedious to reread quotes from them over and over and over again.  This play is like one of those tv shows where they just show you the clips from old episodes with very little new material. And I'm guessing this play makes the assumption that you've read her updates to the story on Pottermore?  There were some real holes in continuity from where the last book left off and where this one picked up.  We miss out on a lot of the beloved characters.  There is no Dursely humor. There is no Hagrid, no house elves, only the mention of a ghost other than Moaning Myrtle who gets a few lines,
  ------ spoiler alert--------------

In book 7, Voldemort killed the horcrux residing in Harry. That got rid of Harry's scar and his ability to speak Parsiltongue.  Both his scar and Parsiltongue are back in this book.

His scar hurt in the books because he had Voldemort's soul fragment, Horcrux, in his body. That's gone now yet his scar hurts because of Voldemort's daughter being around?  Since he no longer is connected to Voldemort, he has no connection to his daughter.

  I'll never pre-order a book from Amazon again. I tried to call them to see when it would be delivered during the release date. I couldn't get even a yes or no answer from 3 different people I tried to ask about it. Then on the release date when it wasn't delivered to my kindle I called to find out why not, and they had cancelled my order. WHAT?! I called to see when it would be delivered and they cancelled it?!  What a nightmarish company Amazon Kindle has become to deal with.  Their operators clearly don't speak English.  They can only recite what's on their scripts, So if you ask them a question that's not on their script they just keep reciting things that don't have anything to do with what you are asking about, such as what time in my own time zone will this be downloaded to my kindle?  Can I do anything to download it as soon as it's midnight? - no answer to either question, then after all they put me through, to cancel my order?  And that's on top of them poorly pronouncing English words so that they are barely recognizable. They talk in a loud background so you can barely make out what they are saying. And the one operator breathed heavily into the phone the entire time and after giving him a bad review he called me back to do that more to me. Ugh.  Never again.

author: gplast
title: Like bad fan fiction - so disappointed
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content: I am a huge fan of the Harry Potter series and was so excited for the Cursed Child to arrive.  Having just finished it, I'm extremely disappointed.  I knew it was written as a play, so it's not the format that's the problem - it's the story.  It reads like bad fan fiction -  all the magic of the original series is gone.  Harry, Ron, Hermione and many of the original characters appear, but are sad, flat versions of themselves.  Albus Potter, as the protagonist, is completely unsympathetic and his motives, which drive the plot, never seem justified.  The storyline is not compelling, just depressing.  And there are serious flaws in the plot which render it all ridiculous....SPOILER ALERT: Bellatrix Lestrange secretly gives birth to Voldemort's child just before the Battle of Hogwarts?!? For that to be true, she would have been obviously pregnant in several scenes in Book 7.  How would no one have noticed that?!?!?  Also, Polyjuice potion cannot be brewed in a day. And how, if the Potters' house is protected by the Fidelius charm, did they find the Potters and steal the blanket???  Perhaps with the spectacle of a theater production, this story might be more engaging on stage, but in my view, the Cursed Child is an unnecessary and unworthy addition to the Harry Potter canon.

title: Abysmal
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
content:
This play is abysmal, combining the worst qualities of fanfic and sentimental Hollywood-style writing. The plot is a contrived rehashing of events from the original book, executed with scenes that provide wish fulfillment and little else.  Snape (in an alternate timeline where he survives the Battle of Hogwarts) learns that Harry's son will be named after him, Dumbledore and Harry talk about how they love each other, and Harry gets to watch Voldemort kill his parents through time travel.

Easily the worst thing I've read in years, play or otherwise.  It's unbelievable that it was published.

author: Olivia McCloskey
title: I was horribly disappointed on my eleventh birthday when my long-awaited Hogwarts ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
content:
I never thought I would be assigning a one star review to anything with J.K. Rowling’s stamp of approval, let alone the eighth installment of the Harry Potter series.  I grew up alongside Harry, Ron, and Hermione, and I practically breathed the wizarding world as a child.  I was horribly disappointed on my eleventh birthday when my long-awaited Hogwarts letter got lost in the mail (it. is. still. coming!  I 100% blame Errol).  I dressed up as Harry Potter, wig and all, for four consecutive Halloweens, despite everyone I encountered automatically assuming I was a boy as a result.  I desperately wanted to fall in love again with the magic that Rowling wove in previous installments, but in the back of my mind I knew it was a little too good to be true.

The one aspect that I tremendously enjoyed were the insights provided on the various characters as they aged and moved on with their lives following the seventh book and the Battle of Hogwarts.  I also appreciated the glimpses into the lives of a wide array of minor characters that were only briefly mentioned in preceding books (although I’m still waiting for Peeves to make an appearance).  Above and beyond that, Harry Potter and the Cursed Child quickly train-wrecked with essentially no other redeeming qualities.

Most noticeably, the play read like poorly-written fanfiction, which it was, in fact, considering that J.K. Rowling played no part in the actual writing of the script.  The writing in no way, shape, or form could remotely compare to Rowling’s, a fact that was painfully obvious and further highlighted by blatant differences in styling, phrasing, etc.  The dialogue routinely seemed awkward, out of place, and forced.  While I tackled the book with full knowledge that this a script for a play that is intended to be watched rather than read, I doubt the verbal delivery of these lines would be any less off-putting.

The characters routinely acted and spoke out of character, differing greatly from the individuals Rowling had carefully crafted over the years.  They lacked a certain depth, and they were no longer motivated by the same factors nor upheld the same values.  Therefore, the characters I thought I knew were given entirely new (and highly unwelcome) personalities, traits, and beliefs by Thorne.  Yes, the play is set nineteen years after the conclusion of Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, so I expected there to be some alterations to the manners in which the characters spoke and behaved, but nothing this drastic.  The characters were so utterly unrecognizable that, had Thorne changed their names, I would never have identified them as belonging to the Harry Potter franchise.

Thorne turned the characters into simple-minded, buffoons, each with a singular focus or selfish aspiration.  Ron, for example, was a complete joke throughout the play, serving purely as comic relief.  While I adored his character in Rowling’s books, he came across as an immature idiot in the play who never transcended adolescence.  Similarly, Draco appeared to have lost his edge – his comments were no longer biting and acrid, and he didn’t appear to foster the same hatred for Harry, Ron, and Hermione.  He actually appeared to tolerate them.  People can’t alter their mindsets and ideals that severely.  My guess is one too many bludgers to the head.

The entire cast of characters were exceedingly flat and static with seemingly no affection or concern for their contemporaries.  When Harry volunteered to insert himself into a dangerous situation, his peers were more than willing to step aside with not so much as a “good luck” or “see you later,”  let alone genuine concern.  What happened to the unbreakable bond between the trio?  Why are they interacting like mere acquaintances as opposed to old friends?

The plot, although supposedly Rowling-approved, was riddled with plot holes and a multitude of suspicion-raising coincidences.  Most prominently, the focus had evidently shifted from the previous struggle between good versus evil and emphasis on magic and the wizarding world to a more mature tone that identified the challenges associated with partaking in a family dynamic as well as holding positions of power.  While this wasn’t necessarily a poor decision in and of itself, it wasn’t well-executed.  To compound matters further, the incorporated scenes felt rather fake and atypical – they didn’t capture the beloved, everyday moments portrayed in the remainder of the series: Quidditch practices, meals in the Great Hall, shopping for school supplies in Diagon Alley, stirring up trouble in Hosmeade, completing homework in the Common Room, etc.  What happened to the Hogwarts scenes and memories that I came to cherish over the years?  As a result, it didn’t feel like part of the same franchise, let alone the next installment of the series.

What little plot was present was merely a ripoff of the original novels – Thorne simply rehashed the past to avoid introducing any creativity, calling into play the same villain, the same settings, and the same tired themes.  They were new and exciting the first time around, but not the second or third.  The play, overall, lacked originality and creativity, even for a fanfiction.

And lastly, it’s a play for Christ’s sake.  It has an entirely different persona and feel to it than the rest of the series, causing it to stand out and attract attention.  The book as a whole seems like more of a cringeworthy afterthought, and I would have been perfectly content having left off with the epilogue in Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows.

I’m still in shock.  I so badly wanted to relive the magic that I recall from childhood of cracking open a new Harry Potter book for the first time and completely immersing myself in the story.  I’m still in denial that Rowling endorsed this project from its initial stages, let alone that she has officially designated it as the eighth book in the Harry Potter series.  I don’t think I’ll ever come to accept that fact.

For more reviews, visit my blog, Brewing Up Books: [...]

In any case, though I'm not necessarily a die-hard Potter fan, I didn't find this believable - too many characters speaking what was, to me, waay OUT of character - and I'm sorry it's being considered Potter canon. author: Elise
title: Tragically disappointing
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content:
At best, this is a poorly written fanfiction.

I have been a longtime Harry Potter fan. I read the books several times a year when I get the chance, and I collect memorabilia. It was a crucial part of my childhood and, as such, I was excited and hopeful for this latest edition. Although I went into this book knowing that it was A) not written by JK Rowling and B) not in its traditional format, but a play, I had high expectations that it would be as magical and titillating as the series has always been for me given that Rowling endorsed it herself and has given it high praise.

How wrong I was. The characters have been assassinated. Plot holes rob this story of any cohesion. Blatant inaccuracies exist within its pages that force us to deviate so far from what we know to be true in the original novels - basic ideas such as how magic works, how potions work, how time works. Ideas that have been dissected and discussed by fans across the world and confirmed by JK Rowling herself only to be thrown to the side in this sorry excuse for a continuation of Harry Potter.

On principle, I refuse to include spoilers in this post. If you would like to read this book, be my guest. In fact, I encourage it so that you, too, can understand where the negative reviews are coming from. I have been a longtime supporter and defender of Rowling and continued endeavors to keep the Harry Potter world alive and I will not write off the series, or her, with the reveal of this catastrophe. However, I cannot support this play. I cannot support this playscript. I cannot, in any way, support the idea that this content is considered canon in the Harry Potter universe, as not only is it a contrived and immature plot, but also the bulk of the book and its ideas go against everything that we already know to be true and confirmed by Rowling herself.

I will support future Potter projects that Rowling has written herself, however, this may be the last time that I pick up anything that was written by another and endorsed by her. This is not something that I would ever enjoy picking up and reading again, nor is it something that I want to see on the stage. I am sure the very talented and accomplished actors who will be performing it are stunning in their performance, but the story is so poorly written that I am not sure their talent can save the show alone.

content: Wow, did not know it was a Script. My wife told me and she was disappointed, she loved reading the Harry Potter  books, we have a number of each of them, we made sure we had them for our kids to read and enjoy, not this on.

author: AL Schiavone
title: Riddikulus!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
The Boy Who Lived has turned into a colossal joke. The characters were hollow imitations of themselves, emotions were said rather than felt by the reader and the plot...cancelling Christmas would be less disappointing.

Plays can be amazing but only if the story is solid. The Cursed Child falls so very short of the beautiful world J.K. Rowling cultivated. Shocking she would collaborate with two Budgers that clearly never read the books.  The only other explanation is J.K. Rowling is losing her touch.  It makes me feel bad that I should ever have to give such a Malfoy-worthy review on something that could have been so spectacular.

This book should be placed in the Restricted Section unless you're a glutton for punishment. The only consolation is to know so many other Potter fans are as disenchanted as I am.

author: Phoenix
title: Thoroughly  Disappointed
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2016
content: Let me start off by saying I am a HUGE Harry Potter fan! I've read each of the books 1-7 about 10 times each. I was utterly obsessed with the books in middle and high school and still very much enjoy them as an adult. This story, however, is equivalent to poorly written fanciful fan fiction with little direction. I was a theatre major in college and have read literally hundreds of play scripts, so that was not the issue for me. It simply did not seem like Rowling wrote this. The plot and exposition were uncomplicated, slow, and simply bad. The characters seemed very different from their former selves (even taking into account that, yes, of course 37 year old Harry, Ron, and Hermione will be different and more mature than their 17 year old selves). And the language was not the same magic we know and love from the books. Again, I know all too well that novels and plays are different artistic mediums, yet still, this story falls very flat. I definitely do NOT recommend this read and will be doing my best to delete its contents from my memory.

There were giant holes throughout the plot line. I mean at certain points in the book I actually found myself turning back pages thinking I had accidentally skipped a section because it totally jumped without transition! If I hadn't thrown away my receipt I would actually consider returning the book. I do not consider it to be part of the Harry Potter library. It doesn't deserve to rest next to the rest of the series on my bookshelf! Honestly, reading the reviews that people have posted has been more entertaining than reading the actual book itself.

title: The Story Lacks Heart
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2017
content: I'm a big Potter fan; read all 7 books at least 4 times.  But this I felt does a disservice to J K Rowland's Potter books and characters.  The actions of primary three seem out of character.  Harry apparently couldn't find time to help Albis with his schooling at Hogwarts, his self confidence or even flying  a broom. It always seemed from the books that he enjoyed teaching and could wind up as a defense of the dark arts instructor but apparently not with his son.  Plus the ministry has learned nothing in 20+  years and still has no way to detect polyjuice imposters which you'd think would be a priority.  Harry is still being accused of killing Cedric and many others neglecting the fact that it was Voldermort, not Harry.  The bulling continues. Gone is the heart, the friendship and the wry humor of the original books.  The whole story just doesn't wash for me.  I didn't mind the play format but did mind the story and the out of character characters.

author: Z. Barger
title: The First Book I Ever Threw Away
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2016
content:
I just wanted to add my opinion to the masses - please do not read this book. I've never been so disappointed by a book in my entire life. In fact, it's the only book I've ever thrown away.

I am a huge HP fan. It literally changed my life, and I've invested thousands of hours and dollars into the franchise. I keep my first copy of the first book in a fireproof safe, alongside pictures of my grandfather and my most cherished sentimental belongings.

But I couldn't even finish this book. I got about 75% of the way through before throwing it across the room in frustration. I eventually skimmed through the last few pages but it was harder and less pleasant than reading a Calculus book. I was so angry that I threw the book away. I've never done that before, even to my Twilight books. Twilight is a work of art compared to this.

This book ruined my views of the Harry Potter series. I intended on re-reading them all after I finished it, but now I can't even look at them without getting a sick feeling in my stomach. I know this sounds melodramatic and extreme, but it's the honest truth... It's like someone spit on my childhood.

Please do not read this book. If anything, read the plot summary online and leave it at that.

author: Yves
title: Beating a dead horse
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2017
content:
This sad attempt to cash in on the Harry Potter legacy is an insult to the fans. Gone was the clever and detailed dialog, the fleshed-out and endearing characters, and the well told story. Instead we got awkward dialog, caricatures of established characters, and a choppy version of the butterfly effect. Think I'm expecting too much from a play? I'm not, just read Our Town or Death Of A Salesman and see for yourself.
  Rowling did a great transition to adult stories under her Galbraith name, making those three novels equal to her Harry Potter series in my estimation. If she wants to go back to YA books, think up something new. Let Harry keep his dignity.

author: L. M. Duncan
title: A Monumental Disappointment!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
Having been a Harry Potter and Rowling fan from the start, I was thrilled to see something new come out to quell the amateur fan-fiction that sought to keep the legacy going after Rowling ended her Harry Potter series.  This, however, is a chaotic mess, a mash-up of other story arcs, and a monumental disappointment.

While the script format could have been clever, the plot is lame and the dialogue is forced and silly.  The characters we had come to know through the "real" Harry Potter books are watered-down, shallow, thin, and barely recognizable.

I kept reading waiting for redeeming value, but sadly, there is none to be found in this horribly written bit of overly sentimental schlock.

If only Rowling herself would bring her creative powers to her Harry Potter series to keep it going, this sort of callow offering would not have been marketed.

Alas, I had to give it one star because no stars was not an option.

content:
This is by far the most horribly executed literary project I've ever encountered.
The characters were totally out of character. The strongest characters were reduced to weak, over emotional cry babies. There is nothing to make you feel any real connection to the characters, even when they're in danger. The young kids talk like undergrad psychology majors. Suddenly it's totally normal for his supporters to freely say "Voldemort" aloud???? Nope. Not ok.

If I was expected to live in this version of the wizarding world, I would ship off and live with the muggles.

author: someonesomewhere
title: The worst HP fanfiction ever...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
Read this as a library copy before deciding to buy it. It's that bad.

The play format isn't obnoxious; it's easy to read. That's the only thing going for this book; you'll get through it quickly, provided you don't damage it too badly throwing it across the room in disgust every time you encounter another badly-written passage.

 Everything other reviewers are saying about this being a fanfiction is true. The characters are underdeveloped; after everything we saw in the first books, there was a lot they could have drawn on for who these characters are. They also don't seem to be very British anymore, which is odd. The interaction between characters is wooden and in places just ridiculous. The plot... I won't give spoilers, but let's just say that there's so much deus ex machina that it's downright disturbing. Rather than inventing a new plot, they contrived a way to retread the old plots, which feels cheap and lazy.

The teenagers don't act like teenagers. Too many of the conversations are exposition tools, and in stilted language that kids don't use. It's as if they didn't actually know any teenagers when they wrote this. The adults, however, DO sound like teenagers. They simultaneously kept the teenage mannerisms of the main HP characters, without keeping their inherent deeper personalities.

I don't believe in bad books. But... this is a bad book. Even on its own, it would be a brutal read; as part of the HP universe, it's a bitter disappointment.

title: SPOILERS Upon reading "Harry Potter and the Cursed Child, ...

content:
SPOILERS

Upon reading "Harry Potter and the Cursed Child," I can only assume that Jack Thorne lived under a rock until quite recently, and has never been exposed at all to the mythos of the Wizarding World beyond its Wikipedia page, and yet somehow, by some unknown magic of his own, he managed to con J. K. Rowling into singing off on a half-backed Potterverse rip-off of the Buffy the Vampire Slayer episode "Dopplegangland." That is the only way I can justify the grossly out-of-character depictions of no less than Ron, Voldemort, Snape, and Harry himself. No character and no event is sacred, and all are trod upon with equal abandon. A supremely disappointing addition to this series that I will just pretend does not exist altogether.

author: Gabor Wacha
title: I've read better fanfics than this one.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2016
content:
Not the characters you loved, a plot full of holes (and contradictions with the books).
Ron becomes a drunkard idiot, Harry contradicts his statement given at the end of book 7 about being in Slytherin, Hermione becomes a hysteric woman.

The plot is banal (with the time-turners and the patching of time). You loved book 3 because events were written so that when the modification of the past happened, everything made sense: the past was not modified at all. Here they actually change the past.

If you consider it as a fanfic, it is almost OK. But as a book from JKR, and a canonical one? No way.

author: onlyoneash
title: Hope JK learned her lesson on this one.
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2019
content:
You know those movies that you watch and are so stupid because you are thinking the whole time “no one would ever do that”. Like horror movies when the main character walks in a room without turning on the light. Wanders around for 5 minutes in the dark for no reason. And you’re like “TURN ON THE LIGHT IDIOT AND ALL YOUR PROBLEMS WILL GE SOLVED” because literally everyone searches for a light switch first thing entering a room?....anyways......That is exactly what this play feels like. None of the characters act like themselves.
The 1,000s of pages JK worked meticulously to craft including friendships and core personality traits in the books are disregarded. It is incredibly awkward.

THIS IS NOT WRITTEN BY JK. It’s a couple random playwrites who somehow got her permission to use her work. When an author is dead, you expect rip off crap books like this due to the heirs giving permission use for $$. But while a literary masterpiece is still living, why would she allow this horrific “play” to be written?!? DO NOT READ if you are a fan of Harry Potter and want to keep things the way they are supposed to be. I repeat DO NOT READ. THIS IS NOT WORTH RUINING YOUR CHILDHOOD OVER.

author: Naillig
title: Can JK Rowling's next book be about going back in time to stop this book/play from being written?
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
I can’t believe it, but I am truly saddened, disheartened, and disgusted with this book. Like many of the reviewers on here, I have grown up with Harry Potter. These books have been a huge part of my life ever since I received the Sorcerer’s Stone and Chamber of Secrets for Christmas seventeen years ago, when I was in second grade. These books got me into loving to read, they brought me closer to my family, who read the books to me when I was young, they inspired my love for fandoms and geek culture in general, they got me through difficult times, and they shaped the person that I am today.
I was not expecting too much from this book/play. I figured that I would go in with low expectations so that the story would hopefully rise above them and I wouldn’t be disappointed. Oh boy, that technique did not work. I knew that the story was written along with two other authors, however I was not aware of just how much of this story was not written by JK Rowling. The advertising for this book was very deceptive in this way. The vast majority of this story can not have been written by JK Rowling. As many reviewers have said, the first thing that I thought of when I had gotten seventy-five pages into the book and finally started to realize that it wasn’t just getting off to a rocky start and improving as it went along, was that it read like bad fanfiction. I had a feeling that things would only get worse from there, so I skipped ahead to spoil the ending for myself, something that I usually never do. But man, am I glad that I did. I saved myself even more frustration. I will not be finishing this book. It is a disgrace to the fantastic seven books that Jo gave to the world. I am honestly shocked that she approved this story for publishing. I am willing to bet that there are fan fiction stories out there that are a hundred times better than this book and are way more worthy of publishing. The writers who wrote this story clearly did not understand or care to understand much of anything from the original stories. It pains me to know that this book is technically considered canon, but for my own sake, I refuse to call it canon. I thought that the mediocre and often downright boring movies were the worst it could get for Harry Potter, but clearly they were not. These wonderful stories deserve so much better. I am so disappointed with Jo. And I truly hope that this is the last time that these amazing characters and stories are pulled back out just to be paraded around in ways that are insulting to the fans and to the original stories and all that they represent.

author: Dragonomine
title: Very poorly written fan fiction
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2017
content:
This wasn't written by J.K. Rowling and so the cover is highly misleading.  What this is, is fan fiction.  I have nothing at all against fan fiction.  Love it!  In fact, I've even written some forever ago.  No.  This.  This is very poor fan fiction.  The play format isn't my favorite but on such well established characters, no need to over elaborate.  We know what these characters are.  Who they are.  Their personalities, fears, hopes, dreams. And now let me tell you that they're so completely out of character that they are barely recognizable.  It also takes liberties with the original story lines.  Those of you who have read the books and seen the movies more times that you can count know when something is wrong on this book.

I guess the good news is that the actual play is a big hit.  As for this book, I'm very disappointed JKR signed off on this tripe.

author: Thomas J. Brumfield III
title: Disrespectful to the source material and poorly written as well
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2016
content:
I get that art is inherently subjective, but I'm truly at a loss to understand how anyone felt this work was thoughtful or respectful.

It directly contradicts canon. It gets characterization all wrong. The main plot points really fly in the face of the series. It primarily centers on the weakest plot element from the original books. I don't want to spoil anything, but it was akin to Mission Impossible 2 over-playing the face mask gag from the original Mission Impossible movie.

This is a rare work that is not only terrible itself, it undermines what came before it.

I literally had to step away from this several times and then force myself to come back. It was really hard to get through the first half of this because of how terrible the writing is. This criticism is often dismissed by the defenders saying people are just not used to reading plays, but I'm an actor who loves reading plays. But the stage directions aren't so much stage directions as they are needless melodrama. There is a scene with a missing family member so the stage direction reads "There is a lot of tension in the room!" You don't need to spell out the obvious. You only need to description the non-verbal action with stage directions.

The second half isn't quite as cringe-worthy from a writing perspective, though the plot and characterization is pretty poor all throughout.

I imagine this might be an entertaining play to watch because of the effects necessarily for all the magic, but this was a truly terrible read.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Dissapointed
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2016
content:
I will start by saying I read this poorly executed play several months ago, so forgive me if my memory fails me slightly as I try to recall what gave me such a bitter taste in my mouth after I set this "book" down.
Harry Potter is a story I grew up with, I was eight years old when I read this Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone. This was the book that introduced me to the wonder and the magic that is the Harry Potter universe. I was nearing 15 when the last book was released. This was, as I believed, to the last installment of the Harry Potter series. After all the trails and tribulations I as so many others have, felt the intensity of the ending and itch for more. When I found out about this play I was so excited by the notion of another installment!
Reading through this story reminded me of a really poor fan story. I was disappointed beyond belief. The characters JK had spent years developing became very static, there was no development on the solid foundation that was left. The characters seemed to almost regress back into a state that was very reminiscent of their very first year at Hogwarts. The entire plot had so many holes it reminded me of Swiss cheese. All in all I strongly believe they could have expanded on this idea much further and made it a decent story versus a pathetic attempt at a sequel that so many fans are thoroughly disappointment in.

author: Anna
title: Utterly disappointing
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
If you love Harry Potter, if you grew up with the stories and this world was or is one that you resonate with then do NOT purchase this book and treat it like the 8th installment of Harry Potter because it is absolutely not that, despite its advertisement as such. If you insist on reading it, treat it like a fan fiction because it truly does not jive at all with the world that JK Rowling created.

I was disappointed by the changes to the characters, by the lack of plot development and story holes, and the unrealistic ideas presented. I felt there were so many things that never would have occurred had these characters been in line with their original personalities (set forth in the other seven books). Part of the magic of the HP novels was that they were consistent. The characterization was real and the main trio were reliable and kind; things they most certainly are not in this most recent story. SPOILERS: Harry deserves the award for Worst Father of the Year, Hermione is a ministry maid and apparently absent at home, Ron lacks all of his charm and quirks, Ginny is as flat as she was in the movies, and Snape is perhaps the most disappointing of all! Every word from his mouth is in stark contrast to the character we knew and hated (and loved).

I am sure the play is entertaining and the production set is great but this story is the greatest letdown the Harry Potter world has faced yet. Sometimes no story is better than any story, and that is certainly true in this case. I desperately wish I could un-read this story.

author: Steve
title: You'll be shocked JK Rowling approved this script
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
As everyone here has already said, this book...err "script" wasn't written by JK Rowling.  It's sad that's she has allowed her name to be plastered on the front of this book, because the writing style doesn't even come close to her own.  It makes me wonder if she'd read the script, or only saw the production.
The best was to summarize this explanation, is to compare it to "Wicked".  We're all familiar with The Wizard of Oz, but no one ever thought what had happened there before Dorothy arrived.  That's why the 'book' (not script) was popular (pun intended), & eventually written as a screenplay.
This script is being touted as "Book 8".  Sadly, that's not what it is at all.  JK ruined the characters by allowing someone else to "puppeteer" her characters which she slowly allowed to grow and thrive.  It's proof that a "Book 9" won't be written, because she'll have to clean up what was essentially a ghost writer did to her characters.
The only way she'd be able to revive HP, would be to write a prequel. And that d need to be a direct prequel to The Harry Potter series.  NOT Fantastic Beasts, which only links to Potter's world because he reads the book at Hogwarts.
Book 8 has essentially ended Harry Potter for good.
It's fantastic to be able to imagine the characters coming back to life in our heads, but sadly, I think this may have been "money motivated".

author: Melissa Stuart
title: Wish this story never happened.
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: This story is a travesty to the HP series. The screenplay format allows none of JK's strength as a writer to come through. Instead of the nuanced, careful unraveling of a story, it barrels through time and plot with no creativity or skill. Where JK had previously concluded the original story with care, by revisiting these same characters the author has managed to ruin that original ending and muck up the HP universe by raising so many questions that the story doesn't bother answering. This is not an adequate addition to the delicately crafted HP series. All in all, I'm going to pretend this story didn't happen.

author: barefoot rabbit
title: Protect your kidz! Fanfic drowning in nostalgia/sentimentality
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
content:
Well, I guess adults will appreciate Harry & friends' parenting woes, but this will just depress kids who've loved the books--so be kind and warn them that this is a boring book about parenting (or something like that). Most of everything's already been said, but I'll just comment that I understand now why JKR refused to keep churning out more books like so many other commercially successful authors do to squeeze every ounce out of popularity from their early books possible. And she did well to quit after 7.

I won't completely criticize her though for taking part in this play as I think it probably started as a creative idea. But I do wonder how she signed off on the script as the author went way too far with the nostalgic fanfic aspect. I mean, half of it is like 'oh, let's remind ourselves of all the cool highlights from the HP years! But not in a cool way!' I liked the two kid protagonists, particularly Draco's kid, but they weren't awesome enough to make the whole story worthwhile. And I'll just say that the dialog is tragic--way too much sentimental cheese rather than the wit we expected--and way too many let-me-explain-my-emotions-to-the-therapist soliloquies that are totally fine and great for first drafts but so not okay for a narrative with any movement. Not sure how this was pulled off on stage in that sense.

And finally, every single author should be petrified of time travel while writing about time travel. I'm not a hardcore scifi fan who demands the sanctity of logical physics in a fantasy, but you gotta think things through. And usually your first plot idea is going to break down big time. HP & the Cursed Child is not an exception. So much worse when you have magical solutions at your beck and call that can completely ruin your time travel plot! JKR worked pretty hard to keep things tight plotwise in her books, whereas this story amazingly suffers from almost eyerollingly magical magic.

So glad I borrowed this from the library rather than plunk down good money for it. (Although...I hear you can return Kindle books you hated/felt cheated by?)

author: Joehawk92
title: It simply isn't a good story and it reads unfortunately like bad fan fiction
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
It simply isn't a good story and it reads unfortunately like bad fan fiction.  As a long time fan who has read and retread this series countless times I am very disappointed. Time travel as a plot device needs to be done right to work and it simply doesn't in this. At no point was I overly concerned about the fate of the characters nor was I sympathetic with main character albus potter. Maybe the script format makes it difficult to connect with characters and understand their motivations but I found the whole parent son relationship problem forced down the readers throats and eye roll worthy.  Spoilers ahead to save trouble of reading.  What good moments are Hidden in mediocrity

Albus potter is indeed sorted into slytherin and becomes best friends with Scorpius malfoy. Albus is black sheep of family with no great magic talent and isn't good at anything. Hermonie is minister of magic, Harry is head of magical law enforcement and Ron helps run The joke shop. Harry finds a custom time turner during a raid and is approached by Amos diggory to use it to save Cedric and he refuses. Albus overhears and decides to steal the time turner and drags Scorpius with him. The time line is almost destroyed blah blah blah ending with battling evil descendant of a death eater who wants to prevent dark lords fall during the night of Harry's parents death in godrics hallow.

title: Oops on the screenplay
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2016
content: I was under the wrong impression about what this book actually was.

author: Salena
title: It’s a fan fiction.
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2018
content: Missing the essesence of what Harry Potter originally captured. And you can tell JK did not write this.

author: Garrett B.
title: Alas
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 14, 2016
content:
Alas, what a disappointment.  I am unsure what I can write that has not already been written, but I will try to contribute.  I should start by saying that I am an incredibly devoted fan who has cosplayed Harry Potter and who avidly anticipated this new installment of the Harry Potter world. Like many others, I question how much Rowling contributed to this and I agree that it is like a horrible fanfiction.  A Very Potter Music, a parody, is more canon to the fans of Harry Potter than this debacle.

A few reasons that this dismays me go as follows (Please, excuse the spoilers):
1. JK Rowling has admitted her folly with time turners.  Yet, they were the main plot device in this book.  It was almost used to explain why one could not have used them to go back in time to stop Voldemort.
2. The characters were disastrous.
  a. Harry Potter, who has completely mistreated by his aunt, uncle, and cousin would never have treated his son so shamefully.
  b. Ron was used as a comic relief and a joke.
  c. Hermione wasn't Harry's best friend; Ron was. However, Harry treated her as such.
  d. There are more, but I don't have time.
3. Bellatrix was never pregnant which makes the whole plot moot.

Anyway, if you must ruin your Harry Potter experience, please rent it from the library.

author: Amazon Customer
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content: It was unreadable

author: tue
title: Not for my bookshelf. Sendng this one to the thrift store.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
content:
I honestly wish I had my own time turner. I'd love to NOT have read this book. Even though I'm well out of the "Harry Potter " generation I have read all 7 books at least a dozen or more times. This book is jammed packed full of way too many "adult emotions and PC happenings". Didn't even finish the last chapter although I suspect they may have ended sitting around a campfire,
 singing campfire songs and reciting loving poetry to each other.

author: Wolfking
title: Where's the STORY? The Novel, the book? ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2016
content:
Where's the STORY?  The Novel, the book?
This is just a script somebody stamped her name to for the sake of windfall profits beyond a stageplay few would ever see.

author: Kendal Crowther
title: HUGE Disappointment
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content: There are other reviews that go through the reasons that this play falls flat. So, as a huge Harry Potter fan, I'll just say it does not at all fit in with the stories we've all read and loved. I am severely disappointed.

author: Urahara
title: Disappointed, underwhelmed, poorly conveyed
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
Some plays read well, some are shown well, and others manage both. I believe this would be an amazing play to see, but as a read, it is supremely bad. The plot is thin and non engaging, the dialog poor. I could see the scenes trying to be set and imagine that they would be wonderful and enchanting in person. This just doesn't translate. Further, there is absolutely no time to connect to characters.
Lastly, I feel robbed buying this. 29,99 US for a script is ridiculous. If there was some effort put into this, I can stomach that. However, the script was published with a pretty cover, without any other thought or effort put in.. I think I'll just pretend I lost the money and hide this "book" away.

author: krull895
title: Don't waste your time!
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content: Terrible!  A few hours of my life and money that I can't ever get back!  Flat characters and implausible plot!  At least one third of it was dialogue directly from the books.  Atrocious!

author: JLL
title: Disservice to the amazing Harry Potter series-none of JK's wit, humor, skillful story telling.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2016
content: It doesn't take very long to realize J.K Rowling did not write much, if any of this (the writing is awkward, not well told and prone to the occasional error).  Although her name is huge, when you look closer it says the play is by Jack Thorne based on a new story by J.K. and two other guys.  I love Harry Potter, have read everything about it and seen all the movies and this play/"story" bears no resemblance to the original masterpiece that is Harry Potter.  I feel totally tricked by this book and preordered it based on the massive title and J.K.'s name.  I still love the series but my respect level for this franchise and the author dropped.  After so many of us have waited too long for something original in the series, to feed us this drivel is poor form.

author: K. T.
title: Wish *I* had a time turner...
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
I'm so disappointed.  I wanted to love this...I love Harry Potter and everything about the Harry Potter world.  I wanted to immerse myself in 320 pages of old friends and new friends and love it.  Instead, I put the book down as I finished it and just thought "eh."

1) The plot -- weak beyond weak.  'Going back in time causes changes in the present' is one of the oldest 'what ifs' in history, and authors have used it beautifully to explore possibilities (see Amazon's original series Man in the High Castle for a great example!) Unfortunately, this book used the "what if" as a cheesy excuse to stick scenes from past books in almost word for word.  Not only that, but the "effects" of the "changes" were weak and not substantiated by the cannon of Harry Potter.
2) The characters -- see the above...if you're a Harry Potter superfan you know these characters like your own best friends - but even if all you've done is read the books, you still have clear expectations of characters.  Rowling's series is YA literature, and despite the classes that have tried to read depth into them, the characters are unarguably clear.  Having those characters change dramatically in a story with no catalyst besides "getting older" or "thinking" is a huge plot weakness. (I'm trying to avoid spoilers here, but Harry not being Harry, Hermione and Ron almost completely negligible - characters of themselves, Draco?? )
3) The writing....this is the death knell in my eyes.  It doesn't ring with JK Rowling's language.  Reading this is basically like reading a cliff notes version of a weak fan fiction piece.  The language, the voice, the diction -- all of it basic and weak.  Don't try to tell me it's because it's a play.....I read plays fairly frequently, and depth and beauty of language is even more important on stage -- see Tennessee Williams, or even Miranda's recent Hamilton. This just feels rushed and forced.  I'm sure great actors could make it feel better - but as a pure script it fails.
Overall, my final review is that this feels like a very weak attempt to keep the Harry Potter money train moving forward.  I hate to say anything against Rowling, but this is clearly NOT her work...and why she would put her name on it is beyond me unless she just wants the money.  My suggestion -- check it out from the library, don't waste your money.

author: ReviewVixen
title: I AM SO HEARTBROKEN!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content: This story was horrible!  I am seriously so upset, sad, and disappointed.  It had nothing to do with the fact that it was in play form, I actually enjoyed that.  But the plot was horrible, the characters and dialogue were one dimensional and boring... I can't believe this is even associated with the beloved books I grew up with!  I am a huge HP fan and it's breaking my heart to even write this review!  I wish I never read it 😩

author: dilemma
title: Crappy fan fiction
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2016
content: If you value you memories of Harry Potter , run away from this horror.  Crappy fan fiction . Just, no.  I cried. I actually cried over what they did to the legacy of JKR amazing books .  This is just crappy. And not in the Tommy Wisaue Room crappy way . More like a 7th grader with no idea of life, politics, parenthood and story tellingwrote it. just , yeah that bad.

author: Jennifer J. Mccrary
title: painful to read
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2016
content: I am a huge Harry Potter fan. I read the REAL books about once every 2 years, and I finished the 7th book for the 4th time immediately before purchasing this travesty. I returned it about half way through because Harry Potter and the Cursed Child was, in a word, painful to read. The dialog is trite, the characters behave in ways completely counter to their personalities in the books, and the while thing was generally terrible. This play is an example of fan fiction at its worset. Don't bother.

author: Jesika
title: Don't bother
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 14, 2017
content: Sloppy and thrown together with very little thought or building of the new characters. I missed the image that the other stories painted with great detail, effort and imagination. This book lacks all of that. I honestly wish I'd never read it and stopped after the last book of the original series.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Truly awful.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2016
content: It is a blight on the entire series. The WORST Harry Potter fanfiction. Ever. We will be hosting a burning party for anyone else interested in 'losing' their copy. Truly awful.

author: bob
title: Ew!!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: Ewww!!! What a piece a crap. (Forced.to give one star by Amazon doeanst deserve it)

author: Lorel Shea
title: It sucked. Really
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2016
content:
Allow me to begin by saying that I adore the original Harry Potter series. It's entertaining, poignant, and unforgettable. J.K. Rowling has conjured up a whole new world that rivals Narnia or Middle Earth.

Harry Potter and the Cursed Child is just not in the same literary ballpark. I mean, if books were baseball, the original seven and their companion stories would be in the World Series, while the Cursed Child would get beat out by the lowliest T-ball team. It sucked. Really, really sucked. Why, you ask?

Well, for starters, the characters do not resemble those created by Rowling. I don't want to be too specific, but these people are barely recognizable compared to their previous incarnations. Either they are behaving like they had a personality swap or they are basically reduced to caricatures. (Poor Ron- I was embarrassed for him!)

The plot is full of holes. The dialogue is stilted. I have devoured every other HP book, but this one I had to force myself to finish- it was that boring!

I truly don't see why she put her name on this product. I have read fanfiction that was far more interesting and better written.

If you are a true HP fan like myself, I am sure you will feel compelled to read this anyway. My suggestion is that you borrow a copy from a friend or local library, so that the "authors" don't get any more money for this ridiculous play.

author: Steven Smith
title: maybe the worst ever written
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2017
content: Awful book, maybe the worst ever written. Would not recommend it expect for maybe as a paper weight.

author: Wolfheart
title: this book was terrible & I refuse to acknowledge it as part of ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 30, 2017
content: To start, I am a long time fan of Harry Potter, since the first book came out. I have read the books more times than I can count & JK is my queen. However, this book was terrible & I refuse to acknowledge it as part of the Wording World. It's basically horribly written fan fiction that got published. Urge all Potterheads to stay away, it isn't worth your time

author: Maddie Youngstrom
title: Awful. Just awful.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2016
content:
I would give it zero stars if I could.  As a fan of the Harry Potter series I was excited to read this only to be extremely disappointed.
Lame story and writing.
Stop adding to HP.  It is perfect already.

author: Book Lover
title: So disappointing
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content: I am a long standing fan of the Harry Potter series, having read the books as bedtime stories to my children when they first came out and again every several years thereafter. I love the additional books, too, likes Fantastic Beasts and Quidditch through the Ages. I even enjoy the fan fiction. I was so excited to see the series break officially into theater, having thoroughly enjoyed A Very Potter Musical. But this play was a chore to read. It is very two dimensional. The characters are not in character as related to the book series. Even the stage directions are poor. It reads like poorly written fan fiction from someone who only watched the movies. I highly recommend other Potter fans keep their money and wait until you can borrow it from your local library.

author: Jack Bailey
title: Disappointed to Tears
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 2, 2017
content:
Terrible. My kid just devoured the JK Rowling HP series. LOVED them like nothing before. She got halfway though this one and is now literally in tears about how bad this book is. I'm hopeful this book hasn't ruined the whole series for her. The author should be strung up by the short hairs.
If you or your children like the original Harry Potter books, stay far far away from this piece of garbage.

author: emma right
title: Harry Potter fan will probably hate this like my kid did.
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2016
content: If you are a Harry Potter fan don't bother to read this. My child read the HP series about ten times over and can't even read through the first chapter--it's that boring. Sorry.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Ruined the actual series
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2016
content: I am certainly not one to leave nit picky reviews online, but if I can influence one person not to read this and wreck their vision of the once great books like I did, I will be happy. I have been reading Harry Potter since I was a child and was so excited for this new "installment". However, this book was just AWFUL. I don't think people are emphasizing just how horrible it is. It really honestly feels as though someone found a really bad work of fanfiction and pretended it was part of the actual story. I was so dumbfounded I started pointing out random lines to friends and family to see if they were reading what I was reading. I was so devastatingly disappointed with this "book" that I tried to go back and read the old harry potter, but it wasn't the same. I really really don't want to be mean or complain that this book "ruined my childhood" but it simply is one of the worst things I have ever read. The same little eight-year-old girl that dressed up as a character for almost every Halloween years later has given up Harry Potter.

author: Cargilper
title: The Harry Potter and friends you knew will forever be tainted.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
content: I went in with low expectations knowing very well that it would not be like the original 7 books... even then I was hugely disappointed. *No spoilers!* The story was all over the place, had a weak plot, brought forth ideas and characters that ultimately were a waste of time, and left a lot of unanswered holes. Actions characters took as adults, don't make sense... it's like a complete need set of Harry Potter and gang! I honestly wish I had not read it. I almost feel betrayed by JK Rowling for signing off on this story. As a Harry Potter fan for almost 20 years, I had to read it and recommend you read for yourself. Just be warned that your childhood image of Harry Potter will forever be tainted.

author: Rachel G. Miller
title: Should have called it Harry Potter and the Cursed Screenplay
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
I was looking forward to the new Harry Potter book, looking forward to immersing myself in a good story. I knew it was based on a play, but I didn't realize that it was ONLY the script and only 234 pages.
Trying to look past that, I started to read the story. I honestly hate it. Harry is a terrible dad. Albus is rebellious and dark. He's an anti-hero. The story is extremely disappointing. There's no depth, and I can't bring myself to care what happens.
Should have called it Harry Potter and the Cursed Screenplay

author: Katie

Rowling's name on it to help it sell. I knew it would be in play format, but I thought there would be more details. For the amount of money I spent and the length of this book, it only took me a few hours to read it (if even that) which is ridiculous. This was a lazy attempt at making money for J.K.Rowling.

author: GIOVANNI

It overturns stuff from the previous books. I won't reveal too much about the book. But each character does not act like themselves. It's just not good.

author: Amazon Customer
title: SOOOO Disappointing
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 26, 2016
content: Terrible. I feel like this does no justice to the Harry Potter series and I am a HUGE Harry Potter fan. I have read all 7 books six times. I'm just going to pretend that this play doesn't exsist. They have changed the personalities of the characters in the books, including Moaning Myrtle and even Aunt Petunia (who's new, extra verbal personality reminds me more of Aunt Marge or Vernon). Half the time I'd read a line and have to remind myself that this continuation of the story doesn't actually exsist, so it doesn't matter that Harry, Ron, Hermione, Ginny, Myrtle, ect. would never have actually said that particular line according to the original (the REAL) stories. They included scenes from the original books, but changed what the characters actually said, and/or changed which characters said what. The story line is NOT well thought out compared to the original stories... It's corny. I mean obviouly I was disappointed when I found out that it was a play, but I'd have been less disappointed if it at least kept the original Harry Potter feel.

author: Amazon Customer

author: Taylor
title: Why would you do this to us JK?!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
I totally think this was a money grab by Jk Rowling-that's the only way I can explain this to myself. I don't think she could have misjudged her fans so much. Rowling has more money than God, so I don't understand why she allowed this bad fanfiction to be published! Her fans certainly didn't need it.

I devoured all seven books of the original series. Went to the midnight release and read them within 48 hours tops. This one? I'm only half way through (this relatively short script) after 3 days because it is PAINING me to read this, and is also ruining Goblet of Fire for me on top of that. DO NOT RECOMMEND. Save yourself and reread the original series.

author: Erin

content: I'm sorry. I love Harry Potter, but this book just made me upset the whole way through. It was like the creators of the play saw the harry potter movies and decided to write a play about it. I'm very disappointed.

author: ICR
title: No, just don't... save yourself the dissapointment
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2016
content:
This review pains me beyond belief. I am a huge fan of Harry Potter. I've read all of the books 3 times and always on the same day they were released...
The plot in the book is thin, and the characters are completely unrecognizable. Harry disgustingly rude to Prof. McGonnagal? Ron --barely present-- is an idiot, not the smart, funny and supporting friend he was. And why is he running a joke shop? that was his brother's, he was an Auror...
I will proceed to confound myself with a memory charm and pretend this didn't exist.
There's no way on earth J.K Rowling contributed in any way here... at all.
Whether you are a fan of the real Potter books or not, don't read this. Not good at all.A HUGE disappointment.

author: Chevelle

content: All the other 1 star reviews perfectly describe all the issues with this book so I won't repeat everything. I took the advice of o e reviewer and took the book out at the library before spending money on it. If I had bought it I would be returning it. I thought maybe there was going to another series based on the kids but most of the years at Hogwart's is squeezed into pages. So many occurrences do not fit with what happened in the real HP books...yes, I say real because this is a bad joke...it has to be. I can't come up with a better explanation.

author: vahid hameheinejad
title: Reads like a fanfiction

This isn't written by JK Rowling and the writing style has many inconsistencies. They called the Ministry of Magic "Ministry FOR Magic"....why

Also the characters don't act like themselves and it's very unnerving. I finished the book because I love harry potter so much, but it almost pained me to finish it.
