author: David Rosser
title: Substandard
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2016
content: Like the majority of Potter fans, I eagerly awaited this final installment in my favorite series. However, the second I started reading, I got the impression that J.K. Rowling had absolutely NO influence in the "book". There were some interesting parts of the script, but the remainder, to put it simply, sucked. No teenage boy acts like Scorpius or Albus, and I found it disturbing that Albus genuinely thought that he had it bad when Harry grew up without parents or a life. I do not, however, regret reading it, partly because it made me appreciate the first 7 books so much more.

author: Elizabeth Munson
title: This book was awful. It was as if it ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: This book was awful.  It was as if it had been written by middle school children.  The dialogue and voices weren't even close to what you would expect of these characters if you'd read any of the other books.  Very disappointing.

author: Dearnys
title: I grew up with the Harry Potter books and reading this was like losing a lifelong friend
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2016
content:
The requisite one star because it is indeed a written work. I grew up with the Harry Potter books and reading this was like losing a lifelong friend. I was honestly in horrified disbelief reading this. If, like myself, you regularly reread the Harry Potter books in a nostalgic and comfortably familiar way, this book will shatter you. I anticipated being disappointed because I read a brief synopsis of the plot before purchasing but it was ten times worse. At first I thought the online description was a joke. Surely it couldn't be that bad. But it was. It really was that bad. I would venture to say the Wikipedia summary is as good as or better than the play. I resigned myself to reading it because Harry Potter is one of the few series which have an enduring place on my bookshelf and in my heart and I wanted to support it's legacy. I read this book in horrified disbelief on a 24 hour hell of airplanes and layovers. This was worse than the security check and delayed flight.

 The play was written with the endorsement of Harry Potter author JK Rowling and apparently some collaborative efforts but it reads as a poorly imagined and terribly executed fan fiction. It draws from other fictional works like Star Wars in its contrived plot and deviates from established truths and details from the Harry Potter books.

Without revealing too much, some of the low points and deviations include the replacement of Ron's personality for Fred and George's. Ron also gets their jokeshop because apparently the authors combined all the Weasleys into Ron and Ginny. I would have preferred they just not be mentioned rather than suddenly change Ron into a laugh a minute practical joker. In this poorly imagined Harry Potter universe, the characters are reduced to one dimensional versions of the original series. Another example would be time turners. Though we have encountered them before until they were all smashed in the Harry Potter books, they are brought back with new rules that only make sense if you completely forget the past Harry Potter books. And so on. I would classify it as a tragic comedy because it's unbelievable how terribly this was done. It's almost like they decided to take random plot elements and events in the original series and mash them together in the most horrible way possible. It's like a cross between MadLibs, the worst possible fan fiction, and a choose your adventure story.

I read this book the day it was released but have only now gotten around to posting a review because I needed to recover. It was truly that bad. Since reading The Cursed Child i have reread the real Harry Potter books and read several true literary works and enjoyable, engaging novels. If you have never read Harry Potter books you may enjoy this play. If you are a Harry Potter fan you've probably read this and were left disappointed like me. If you haven't read it and are weighing the pros and cons, it is a waste of time and a huge disappointment. I personally would not use a time turner to go back and unread it because at least now I know it really is this awful.

author: ELS
title: Unreadable
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content: Virtually unreadable (re)hash of old HP.

author: bob
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2016
content: Looks like a money grab for JK. Nowhere near the quality of the original Potter series.

author: Chris
title: It's just not a good read
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content:
I understand Rowling didn't write this and I understand this is s play. But the story/plot are predictable, boring, and over-the-top. The personalities of the characters, including Harry, Hermione, and Ron, are terribly developed and quite wrong. There are even plot holes that don't make any sense! Just terribly written.

If you feel that you have to read this because you're curious as to how everyone turned out, it's still not worth reading. I even had the thought that maybe it's better as a well developed play, but I doubt it.

Frankly, I would not recommend reading this script or watching the play.

author: One Frogs
title: Yeah, it really sucked
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2016
content: Yeah, it's a terrible play totally missing the soul of Harry Potter.  It's as if two semi-serious fans saw the last few movies and wrote a play just for the money.  I was very disappointed.

author: Ramage
title: Dissapointment
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2016
content: I have never been more disappointed in my life. The writing was sloppy and the authors interpretation of the characters was horrid. I really hate to say it, but the screenplay is absolute garbage. It is written like really bad fan fiction. Please don't waste your money or time.

author: jules
title: This is time wasted that I will never get back in my life
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2016
content: Let me start off by saying I am a huge Harry Potter fan.  I read the books three times a year, have a season pass to Universal Studios, and have been to Leaky Con.  I started this play and barely made it halfway.  This is time wasted that I will never get back in my life.  I have a hard time believing that JK Rowling even read this, the characters were so off.  Another review described this as a poorly written fanfiction and I 100% agree.  Don't waste your money.  Rent from library or don't bother at all.

author: Staceylynn McGinnesss
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2016
content: Thoroughly disappointed!

author: Sheila Wolf
title: Terribly disappointing.
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 9, 2017
content:
I absolutely disliked this. It could have been written by a third grader. There was nothing to it.
I love the Harry Potter series, bought all the hardback books, saw all the movies (I'm 71 years old!)
This is pure drivel, another way to make money I suppose.
I hope the actual play is better, but I'd never go see it.
I'd really like for Amazon.com to refund my $14.99 for this.  It took about 10 hours to read.
No worth one dime.
Sorry, JK.
Sheila Wolf

author: Amazon Customer
title: I'm nit blind to the flaws in the Harry Potter series through I love them. This book I was extremely excited for
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2017
content:
I grew up with Harry Potter (literally), I read the first book (The Prisoner of Azkaban: Book 3) when I was 13 (So was Harry) and the last book came out when I was 17. I've read it a couple of times after that. I followed it thorough the change in tone and the depth that was added as the years passed! I'm nit blind to the flaws in the Harry Potter series through I love them.

This book I was extremely excited for! I had my reservations about it being written by someone other than JKR, but JKR said this had her stamp of approval (YAY!) so I bought it and I read it. It's simply awful! Not only does the author not stay true to the characters from the book but the plot line is shoddy, shallow and effortless. It's like a bad fan fic written by an emo teenager on the way to school. I have actually seen better fan fics online which have stayed more true to the characters! I want this book to desperately to go away! I want the pure joy of the books back. This book has forever ruined the comfort of Harry Potter for me (HP got me through high school). I refuse to accepts this books existence!

author: Richard
title: A massive disappointment
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content: I love Harry Potter; I've read the books multiple times, have seen the films each 15 times, and I've even read a lot of fanfic. This book was too foot to be true. It is such a disappointing book. It's very poorly written, and the authors didn't know the original characters at all! They're totally flat and just unbelievable. So many things that happen in the story are just utterly ridiculous, even for a story about magic. There is absolutely no depth to the plot, and the new characters are chaotic and shallow. I'm so disappointed, and I'm telling all the other die hard Potterheads to save their money and avoid this book.

author: alygruber
title: NOT the eighth book
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2016
content: this book is a fake hp book. dont get your hopes up. many of the characters dont follow their personalities in the original 7 books.

author: Teri Southerland
title: Even for a screen play it was bad
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: I was disappointed in the play. Spoiler alert ....with Harry having Sirius as a God father he knew what he missed out on. the fact that his son felt unloved is beyond reason.  I mean growing up with the Dursleys and seeing Ron's family. Harry saw what it took to be a family. My personal opinion is this play shouldn't have been written. J. K. Rowling had such a living breathing memoir with the seven books and movie. My disappointment knows no bounds.

author: Millennial CPA
title: It didn't happen...
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2016
content: I love HP with most of my heart. I grew up with these stories. I pre ordered books 4-7 on Amazon as a child, flew to Florida just for HP World, listen to the audio books on repeat, all of it. But this.... this screenplay... is an abomination of all things HP. This play wouldn't have worked without JKs approval, but her approval is a discrace and just a way to ensure it makes money. The characters are so wrong, the things they say, the things they do, the actual characters would never ever in a million years say or do. It makes Harry look like a terrible dad, Ron an idiot, Hermione unethical. Don't even get me started on the concept of Voldemort procreating. I wish I wouldn't have read this. I'm pretending I didn't. I would burn the memory from my brain if I could. It didn't happen.

author: Geoff S.
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2016
content: Relied too heavily on nostalgia. Story was weak and logic would have made the originals pointless

author: ADHD
title: Worst than Twilight. Such a disappointment.
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: This wasn't just a let down, this book was actively awful. The whole thing was like a thrown together fan fic by someone who didn't know the characters. Absolutely cringe worthy, empty, nonsensical, rubbish. Don't bother reading it, it will hurt the whole series.

author: Ron Burgundy
title: R.I.P. Harry Potter series
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 13, 2017
content: This was so unlike anything all the other books were about it's almost as if someone else wrote it. I wish I could erase this from my memory because it tainted the series for me. I'm having a hard time not connecting these characters to my favorites now. Its bad because the new characters are so unlike their parents that it makes no sense.  I wish I had never of read this. What was JKR thinking.

author: Ian Phaseman
title: Just. No. smh No.
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2016
content: To say I did not enjoy this book at all is an understatement. I endured it. Rubbish through and through. Can't wait to get rid of the copy I actually paid money for. Simply awful!

author: L. Cockrum
title: Very disappointing
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
So many people have already written much more eloquent reviews that I could ever write, but I need to add my voice to those saying how disappointing this was. I did not realize that it was in play format, and that it was not written by her, only approved by her.

Sadly I think that they deviated very far from the personalities of the characters, as well as the plot was really insipid and not anywhere near the quality of the books.

I am glad my husband bought me the kindle version, as I have no need for such a sad hardcover book.

author: Cyn W.
title: It's a play NOT a book.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content: It's a play NOT a book. Horribly disappointed. Returned it immediately.

author: Robert R. Bean, MD
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 7, 2016
content: Lousy....could not even finish it😕

author: K
title: Cash-grab awful fanfiction
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2017
content: I, like many others, didn't look closely enough to see that this book was not written by J.K. Rowling. While I was not put off by the script format (since this is a copy of the script for the stage play rather than a novel), I was very much put off by the unbelievable plot and the frankly ridiculous dialogue. I have nothing against fanfiction (which this so clearly is), but I wish I had known that Rowling had no hand in it AT ALL, and that it had been better written. I've read better fanfictions online for free from authors who only wrote for their pleasure and not for money. Shame on the publisher for subjecting fans to this cash-grab.

author: Jane
title: I was bamboozled! Same time travel plot used 100x. Characters are poor imposters of the ones HP fans know and love.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2017
content: I hesitated to buy this bc it wasn't actually written by JK Rowling. I decided to give it a chance and now deeply regret it.  I would give zero stars if I could.  These are not the characters that I know and love.  The author was not able to capture any of Rowlings' magic in any aspect.  The characters were bland wannabes, fake and unfamiliar.  The tired plot is one that has been done many times, think Butterfly Effect or more recently 11/22/63.

author: ManDingoCC6901
title: ... play is a betrayal and a departure of the beautiful world Rowling built
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content: This play is a betrayal and a departure of the beautiful world Rowling built.  It unnecessarily shakes up the potter story for what?  Is the wizarding world so small they couldn't find source material?  So many things  we love are yanked in different directions in this novel it's reminiscent of the complete lack of understanding displayed by the directors of the latter movies.  If you love Harry Potter, this book will hurt your feelings.

author: j water
title: it was bad. Me and my wife are avid potter heads
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
content: it was bad. Me and my wife are avid potter heads. And we read the books together before bed almost every night. And watch the movies pretty frequently as well. The plot was very predictable and the characters were shells of themselves. I knew that Rowling didn't write this herself so I tried to be very forgiving, but as me and my wife neared the end of the book we found ourselves "oh good it's almost over."

author: Trisha Osborn
title: If only JK Rolling had written this herself!!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2016
content: I was upset over the writing. I know JK Rolling didn't write it, but I would never have put my name on this if I were her! She has a great writing style and I wish that she would have just written this herself! It could have been really good if she had just taken the time to do this herself. The story had a few problems and was not in my view the same kind of story JK Rolling would have turned out on her own. I didn't enjoy this and it makes me feel bad to say this.

author: MaybeNever
title: Just don't
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2016
content:
I was so excited for the "next chapter" of the HP series BUT
Why??? It was a poor attempt of a fanfic and supposedly there are rumors for a movie???
No. Do not shame the Harry Potter legacy

author: Dana Germer
title: Horrible
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: This was the most disappointing read, I couldn't even finish it. Regardless of whether or not it was a play, it didn't even feel like the original characters, even aging doesn't turn you into these 'grown up' versions. Wish I hadn't wasted the time or money on this. I would not, in any way, recommend this to anyone.

author: Amy Wax-Humphrey
title: Disappointing
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2016
content:
As an avid Harry Potter fan, like many others I embraced the idea of a continuation. This, however reads like cheap fanfic. It is not JK Rowlings writing style at all. There were even idiosyncrasies that I could not get past (example being there aren't nurses, but healers in the Magical community).
The screenplay format is as tedious as reading The Bard in school, the modern day lingo overbearing, the characters more like caricatures. I wouldn't recommend this at all.

author: Karen G
title: Boring, boring, boring
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 24, 2016
content: So sorry to say this because I miss the characters from the Harry Potter series. There is so little on which to hang your imagination in this play.

author: gabrielle t.
title: this book spits on the Orignal HP seris we all know and love. Plus it ur like me and didnt know ...

content: DONT BUY IT! this book spits on the Orignal HP seris we all know and love. Plus it ur like me and didnt know a head atime its not even a book really its writen in the form of a play and personaly i hate this format. Ut passed 4 year of hogwarts in like 10 pgs. It has little to no story wat so ever and its hard to keep up with wat the hell is going on. If possible i want my money id give this a 0 star rating.

author: India Sparhawk
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2017
content: I did not realize it was a script, not a novel.

author: Whitney
title: I returned it and plan on forgetting that this book ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2016
content: I returned it and plan on forgetting that this book ever happened. Cannot understand why J.K. Rowling would endorse it.

author: Meg
title: As another reviewer stated.... Obliviate. Utter tripe.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content: As another reviewer stated.... Obliviate. I wish I had a time turner too. What an absolute disaster. Not written by her, and not even attempted to sound like her. Characters flat, angsty. I've read much better fan fiction. What an utter waste of time and money. I am shocked that JK would put her name on this, or that she even had this idea for the story. Every creative thing she could have done, wasted. No focus on anything that made the original books worth reading: deepening friendships, humor, believable motivations... ugh. I can't even talk about it. SPOILER- and the Voldemort part with Bellatrix... ARE YOU KIDDING ME. I am a serious fan, started an HP club in college... we had Yule Balls, dressed up, everything, I know the series backwards and forwards. Just NO.

author: Amazon Customer
title: and Ron was completely useless idiot. This was terrible
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2017
content: Hermione would have never left the time turner in her office so unprotected, Harry was made out to be a total ass and would have never EVER used the "might of the ministry" to bully McGonagall, and Ron was completely useless idiot. This was terrible, and I am upset!

author: Laura J.
title: Ugh.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2016
content: I didn't bother finishing reading this, and I returned the book. I've loved the Harry Potter series since I was waiting for Book 4 to be published. I've shared them with my children. I knew this was going to be a screenplay, and that didn't bother me. I was just excited to see a continuation of the characters I loved and characters I hoped to get to know--but the characters I knew so well were not themselves at all. This was character slander on an epic scale. Not to mention the story and relationships. There are a lot of things I could say about it, but I think others have said much about it already.

author: Betty Dobbins
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content: Don't know why I ordered a book in play form

author: Jessica
title: Do not waste your time
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 11, 2016
content: I loved the Harry Potter series, but this book (screenplay) was a total let down. There is little to no plot line and character building is subpar at best. Go stare at paint drying, it will be more entertaining.

author: Kelly B
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2016
content: Couldn't even finish it

author: Anna Zielinska
title: It's not a Harry Potter anymore and it's fine this way
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2016
content: It's not a Harry Potter anymore and it's fine this way.  I was interested to see the story of his children and that meets expectations. The play-form of the story gives a new flair to the series.

author: healthnut
title: Not a real Rowling
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content: This is a sketch at best.  It could also be described as third-rate sitcom writing.  I am very disappointed.

author: Jill Aren
title: The ugly stepsister of JK Rowlings work.
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2016
content: (No spoilers.) I hated giving this book only one star. I'm a huge, huge fan of JK Rowling's work. I've been reading the Potter books once a year since they came out. I've read her other works, as well. I adore them all. This just does not hold a candle to the rest.  I had not realized at first this would be in screen play format, which is really annoying and difficult to read-my fault for not paying attention to that. I had to force myself to get through it.The plot is weak and has holes, too many questions left unanswered, the story was rushed, and the characters actions were out of character (primarily Harry.)  It just seemed as if the attention to detail and rich storytelling that we are accustomed to with Rowling were missing.  This one  missed the mark. I'm gonna pretend I didn't read it now and hope one day I have enough money to travel to London for the express purpose of seeing the play in person. (lol!)

author: compulsivereader
title: Just skip it
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2018
content:
Honestly the biggest piece of crap I’ve ever read. Yes it’s a script, I’ve had no issues reading those. My issue was the characters. Not one character was true to the original books!

Spoilers!!

Weak, horrible father Harry Potter? Seriously. Yeah he had a crap childhood but there’s no way someone with as much love inside him as Harry would have treated his child that way. Stupid Ron? Ron might have been oblivious in many ways but he was far from stupid, oh and giving a kid a love potion after he accidentally took one in school? WTH. Hermianie, oh just so much wrong with her character. Basically her entire personality depends on Ron? If they aren’t together she becomes someone else completely? She also has absolutely no hidding skills if a teenager can find something she hid.

author: Alison Williams
title: One Star

author: Amanda

content: Just wanted to chime in that this book was so disappointing. The characters seemed so off. However, the book "Fantastic Beasts and where to find them" is wonderful. I'm in the middle of reading it now and am really enjoying it. As for this book though....meh

author: Arizona shopper
title: Disappointing!  Beware this book is not a novel.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2016
content: Yuck.  I'm so sad this is written in play format.  Thank goodness I ordered a hardcover instead of downloading to my Kindle so I can return it.

author: S. Ham
title: WORST BOOK EVER!
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2017
content: I have real all the Harry Potter books NUMEROUS TIMES,  and now add a mom I am reading them to my kids.  They are a part of my life have been for many many years.  That being said, I fully believe this is one if the ABSOLUTE WORST BOOKS I have read as an adult.  The fact it was written as a play made it IMPOSSIBLE it get immersed in like the other HP books.  The plot was STUPID, the story line was childish.  It horrible.  I want my money back and the last several nights I have read this POS.  I WILL NEVER GET THAT TIME BACK.

author: wendy barragan
title: reads like a play
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content: Just couldnt get past page one, reads like a play. So disappointing.

author: Melissa
title: Ugh.

content: Incredibly disappointed.

author: HM
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2016
content: did not like the "screen play" format. I think this is just a way to sell more books

author: Bad Cat!
title: Not Even Close!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: The writing was very poor!  This did not seem as if it was written by JK Rowling at all, or as if she had anything to do with its creation, except to have signed somewhere on the dotted line to give permission.  This play manuscript has none of the "magic" of a Harry Potter novel.  None.  This was evident from the very beginning.  JK Rowling's fans, Harry Potter fans,  deserve so much more than this play manuscript.  We deserve a decent Harry Potter book by JK Rowling, at least if her name and his are on the cover, and it's billed as the 8th Harry Potter story.  I have already wasted too much time on this, sadly.

author: NurseWho
title: Disappointing at best
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2017
content: I tried and tried. I loved the original HP series and read them multiple times. I was so excited to get this one, but I was quickly disappointed. It seemed as if it wasn't even written by JKR. It was cold and stilted. Yes, it's a screenplay, but even so, it had no comfortable flow. I found myself drifting off to other thoughts and eventually gave up.

author: AlexAnne89
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content: Don't do it!

author: Donna
title: What a stinker
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2016
content: Awful. The plot is weak. The dialogue insipid. And JK Rowling has tarnished the franchise. Do yourself a favor and put this one down before you pick it up.

author: Carolynn Mc
title: Don't spend your good money on this book
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2016
content: I HATED the way this book was written - like a script. It was very annoying. I didn't finish the book, and I don't think Rowling wrote this. Terrible.

author: angel
title: I loved the story the quality of the book however was ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 11, 2017
content: I loved the story the quality of the book however was grossly dissapointing! The pages were crooked and the binding awful.

author: Bea Harris
title: It was either going to be amazing or absolutely horrible
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2016
content:
What is there to possibly say about this book?  Let me start off by saying I am a Potterhead to the core.  I re-read the entire series at least once a year and sometimes twice.  When I first found out this book was coming out I knew it would go one of two ways.... It was either going to be amazing or absolutely horrible.  This was the latter.  If I could give it half a star, I would.  I went into this read with no expectations, but was still left with disappointment.

Firstly, this books reads like fanfiction and not even the good kind.  The original characters (Harry, Ron, and Hermione) were so unlike themselves it was hard to picture them as the same characters I loved in the series.  Ron is now basically the not funny dad always trying to play jokes, Hermione seems cold and distant, and Harry...well, he's just not Harry.  The story line is also just complete garbage.  Without spoiling the book, THERE IS NO WAY THIS PLOT MAKES ANY SENSE AND WOULD NEVER HAVE HAPPENED!!!

All in all, this book might as well have been of a completely different universe.  This is not the Harry Potter I grew to love.

author: Stephen
title: Just not Harry Potter...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content: It's just not Harry Potter. Plain and simple. I was completely aware that it was going to be a script format of a play...however the whole storyline was mush. It was here, there, and everywhere. The characters were NOT themselves, I expected some change since it is based so many years afterwards, but they were to "muggly". Was written in a fan fiction format and very disappointed that Rowling's name was on it. It just doesn't seem like her work.. :(

author: Brinkley Harrell
title: Don't waste your time with this book -- wait for the movie.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2016
content: I found this to be terrible. It is not the Harry Potter we know and love. The script format is awful, disjointed, and not well organized. Yes, it is a fast read because there are so few of the elaborate and intricate descriptions that J.K. has developed in the original set of stories. I wish I could get my money back!!! >-)

author: daniela droguett
title: I wanted to like it. I really really did
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
I want to start this by saying that I am a huge Harry Potter fan. I grew up with Harry, I went to midnight premiers of the books and movies. I was so excited for this play. I wanted to like it. I really really did. If you are a fan I would say read it and form your own opinion. Here is what I thought:

-  Where was George?
-  Where was Teddy? Because he was in the station in th epilogue.
-  Where was Hugo? You know the other child Ron and Hermione have.
-  Lily and James Potter… MIA for most of the play. Like James? Was he even in it?
-  Why was Ron running the joke shop? He is an Auror. WHAT HAPPENED TO GEORGE? WHY WASN’T HE RUNNING THE SHOP?!
-  Let’s talk about Ron. Why was he so non-Ron like? His character, all jokes no supporting and listening to Harry and Hermione. Also he is hardly in the play.
-  Harry’s relationship with Albus. Everything about this is upsetting.
o  In the last book when they are dropping off the children at the Hogwarts express, the kids are genuinely confused as to why everyone is looking at them and Ron makes a joke saying “I’m famous”. It is deduced that the kids do not know the extent of everything their parents went through to save the world. Yet Albus feel the weight of his dad’s legacy. Huh.
o  Then we have Harry SEPARATING Albus and Scorpious. Let’s go back to that epilogue where they all see Draco with his family and a joke gets made about not playing with his son. Which then Hermione corrects and Ron says to beat him on test but not to get too cozy and marry him. Again, making it seem that everything in the past is in the past. Then there is Harry’s history of friends at Hogwarts. He knows. He would not separate his son from his ONLY friend.
-  Albus choosing Slytherin for a friend? Awesome.
-  The rumors of Voldemort having a child and that not being stopped by the ministry? Stupid. The ministry would have stopped panic about an heir being possible. Also Voldemort was conceived without love. He never cared about having an heir because he wanted to be in power. An heir would have been competition for him.
-  More on that point. Bellatrix pregnant. She would have loved to mother the Dark Lords child; there would have been no greater honor. But. This does not work with the original time line. Bella is never pregnant, she fights at the battle. And then the gang goes to Malfoy manor there is no baby in sight. And if. IF. Voldemort would have wanted an heir; wouldn’t he have made it a horcrux and offered it more protection?
-  Sexual tension between Scorpious and Albus. Yet Albus has a crush on Delphi and Scorpious on Lily. I feel as though either they should have been opened about their romantic feels towards each other or this should have not been included.
-  The flashbacks/dreams Harry has. When Dudley is mentioned (yay!) and you find out petunia is dead. I know she was horrible but I do think Harry would have deep feelings about his mother’s sister passing. I liked the blanket part.
-  Bellatrix husband somehow got out of Azkaban and raised Delphi. How did he escape Azkaban? Because there is no way he got pardoned. So how did he escape? And after escaping how was there no alarm over him escaping. Sirius Black escapes and the freaking muggle minister is alerted! Then there is a massive breakout and it is all over the daily prophet. But hey, this guy who tortured the Longbottoms into insanity he escapes and it’s cool. Yeah, sounds legit.
-  The new prophecy. First of all: how did it happen with no one knowing about it except Delphi. Who made it? It’s sounding more and more as if this witch convinced herself that she is the heir of the dark lord.
-  Cedric. Cedric a character who was noble and good and died oh so tragically. This character who was loyal and kind and helped Harry turns DARK SIDE?!?! BECAUSE HE LOSES THE CUP. WHAT?!?! CEDRIC A DEAD EATER HAHAHAHA NOPE NOT FUNNY. Thank you for turning a good character and completely changing him for the worse. Thank goodness you did not include Sirius Black in your play.
-  On that same characters changing note. The trolley lady…. Hm. I will just leave it at that.
-  Polyjuice potion. That s*** takes a month to make. I read the chamber of secrets. Many times. It takes an effing month. And you need a piece of the person you are changing into. But wait not, here I got some polyjuice potion here in my back pocket and I just happen to carry my dad and his best friends hairs at all times. So let’s change into them and break into the ministry.
-  Btw that potion is not necessary because you can transfigure a HUMAN. Seven books and that never came out. Must be very dark magic.
-  On the dark magic note. Harry duels Delphi (a eighteen year old) and she is stronger? Um. Do we not recall Harry being a teenager and he beat Voldemort. His wand is the s***. So yeah how does this even make sense?
-  The no sugar diet. WHAT. Sounds like something movie Ginny would do, not book Ginny.

author: A. Zafar
title: Prepare for disappointment
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 9, 2018
content:
Quote from actual book:
DRACO: Hermione Granger, I’m being bossed around by Hermione Granger. And I’m mildly enjoying it.

WOULD DRACO MALFOY EVER EVER SAY THIS? You know deep down the answer is no. This book is trash and the fact that Rowling endorsed it is disappointing. Read it if you want, be ready for the disappointment.

author: Sharyl Grant
title: Terrible. Does not add to the series
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2016
content: Terrible.  Does not add to the series; is basically fan fiction.  I really wanted to love it, but absolutely hate it.

author: trevis ehle
title: DON'T GET IT IS WAISTS OF MONEY!!! If you think this will be anything like the other books its not at all its a waist of money t
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2017
content: It is so dumb

author: Amazon Customer
title: If I could give this 0 stars I would
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: The first quarter of this book started strong. We had some nice new characters, conflict between Harry and his son, and an interesting premise. Everything quickly derailed around the second half. The story turned into a mishmash of poorly written fanfiction the writers seemed to find off fanfiction.net. An over abuse of time travel, bad characterization, and the worst "secret" reveal I have ever seen completely ruined this for me.

author: Janine
title: Why did you do this to us JK Rowling?
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
The script format isn't the problem, the content is. If you like Harry Potter do yourself a favour and don't read this. I don't understand, why why why JK Rowling?
Why bring our most beloved characters back to life if it is to ruin the series for us? You can't recognise neither Harry or Ron or Hermione. They all seem like complete strangers now. Their dialogue makes no sense, it doesn't feel like them at all. Albus and Scorpio are also so disappointing, all they seem to do is to profess their love for each other and hug through the entire thing. The plot so flat and predictable.
What on earth has happened to Harry? This is not the Harry I grew up with, I don't recognise him. I wish I never red this at all!!!

author: Kindle Customer
title: I was truly disappointed in this latest book
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content: I was truly disappointed in this latest book.  I really tried to accept the written screenplay, but it was extremely slow and had no feel of the previous series.  I had to wonder if JK wrote the book.

author: Korri Kezar
title: A disappointment, to say the very least.
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: This script is in no way comparable to J.K. Rowling's Harry Potter masterpieces. It reads like fan fiction in the form of a play. The writers seem to have taken the easy way out, and there is very little plot creativity or character development. After years without new Harry Potter literature, this was a disappointment, to say the very least.

author: RonS
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2016
content: don't really like screen plays

author: Abigail
title: Total betrayal
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
Let me first begin by saying that I am a Harry Potter purist, and have a very strong affinity for the books, while feeling zero attachment to the Harry Potter films. As that said purist, I really have nothing but the highest expectation for anything to do with continuing Harry's story. And really, quality should have been their top priority, but it doesn't seem somehow that it was.

I cannot begin to describe the disappointment that met me upon finishing this book. This doesn't feel like Harry Potter. And I never could have dreamed that they would write a story so full of holes and discrepancies. The characters have been completely rewritten (I would like to apologize to Ron, who's character was completely defaced and humiliated), and the storytelling is unbelievably weak and full of holes. I cannot fathom how J.K. Rowling came to approve this story. It is a complete derailment of the seven book series.

Even if I knew how bad it was going to be before I read it, I couldn't have stopped myself, because I needed to know. It's important to be informed. But this is not Harry Potter. It doesn't gleam any essence of Harry's world, there is no spark to it, and what is even more appalling is the way they tried to rewrite actual parts of the original series. This book was beyond disappointing. My back is forever turned from it, in homage to the story that deserves nothing but honoring.

title: I can see why some individuals may enjoy this play
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content:
I can see why some individuals may enjoy this play. It may bring back certain feelings. However, speaking from the point of view of someone who has read the series a dozen times, this was undoubtedly the most disappointing read I have ever forced myself to finish. The authors have very little grasp of the characters or how any part of the magical world actually operates. It is no different, if not worse than most fan fiction based on the series.
If you have not yet purchased the book and are a true fan of the series, I highly recommend that you save both money and time and not purchase this. You are not missing out on anything but sour disappointment.

content: Both of my children disliked the book.  After reading I have to agree.  It is a weak story with characters that are dissimilar to their earlier selves.  The book is nothing more than a weak, dull Potter tale and poorly written at that.  I am honestly shocked by it's release considering the financial fortunes riding on the series.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Not good. Not if you love Harry Potter
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content: Not good. Not if you love Harry Potter. It's a silly story and the characters are shades of themselves. New characters are shallow and poorly developed. This book is definitely not a part of the Harry Potter universe. It's a shame J.K. Rowling let it be published.

author: Avogadra
title: Either J.K. Rowling did not read this script, or she is suffering from dementia
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content:
Harry Potter and the Cursed Child contains plot holes big enough for the enchanted Weasley car to fly through.

SPOILERS***SPOILERS***SPOILERS

1. If anybody has a question about the parentage of young Scorpius, a DNA test should set all concerns to rest. Surely Draco could afford such a test and provide samples from himself and his wife's family for comparison purposes. Rowling is married to a physician and would be expected to think of this instantly.

2.  Hermione Granger was called the brightest witch of her age. So her ministry door can be opened with "Alohomora"? And behind that door she hides an illegal Time-Turner in a book in her library? Giving idiotic riddles as clues to which book it might be in? Right.

3. Hufflepuffs value hard work, patience, loyalty, and fair play. Cedric Diggory was the prototype Hufflepuff, but all it took to set him on the path to killing Neville Longbottom (one of the meekest characters in the series) was two humiliating events in the Triwizard Tournament. And the number of Hufflepuffs we have previously seen in the ranks of the Death Eaters is...ZERO. Okay, then.

4. Somehow Bellatrix Lestrange was able to conceive a baby by Voldemort (How? I can't visualize Voldemort wanting anybody to touch him), carry the baby to term under the watchful eyes of a group of powerful Slytherin witches and wizards who would have been resistant to a Confundus Charm, and deliver that baby unnoticed before the Battle of Hogwarts. Not only that, when Hermione used some recently-acquired hair to add to a Polyjuice Potion in order to break into Gringott's bank as Bellatrix, Hermione never noticed that she was pregnant.

5. When Albus and Scorpius briefly stole Baby Harry's blanket while they were in Godric's Hollow, they had to break a Fidelius Charm that even Voldemort couldn't overcome without the cooperation of the Secret Keeper. The Fidelius Charm was used at least three times in the series. Surely Rowling remembers how it works. EDITED TO ADD: On page 255, we see James and Lily leave their house with Harry in a pushchair. Then what was the point of the Fidelius Charm on their cottage??? All Voldemort had to do was make himself invisible and wait for them to take a family walk. Three quick Avada Kedavras and it would all be over. No interaction with the repellent Peter Pettigrew was even necessary.

Book 8 reads as though Tiffany and Thorne did their research from the movies, only reading the first seven books to copy dialog. They didn't know the background of the characters, and settled for caricatures instead. They didn't understand how the magic worked, and used it incorrectly. Rehearsal Edition Script or not, a plot that contains so many obvious errors makes it hard to enjoy the story. Rowling should have ended canon with the Deathly Hallows.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Harry Potter next generation, harry thought Voldemort was bad until he had a teenager
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2018
content: You have to stop when you are ahead

author: TD

content: I have read all the prior Harry Pooter books and have seen all the movies.  I was so excited for the new book but when I opened on the first page and saw it was a play I quickly turned a few pages to see if a play versus a book.  To my disappointment the rest of the pages were that of a play.  I went on line to check if somehow I made an ordering mistake.  Nope...it's a play.  The purchase was a waste of money and am truly disappointed Rowling wasn't more transparent that this book was not similar to the past and it was a play.

author: Linda
title: Not written by J.K. Rowling
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: I think the description of this item on Amazon is very misleading. It says "Harry Potter and the Cursed Child by J. K. Rowling" but actually on the book I just received the cover says "Based on an original new story by J.K. Rowling". The new story written by Rowling is not included with this book and it doesn't seem she had much hand in writing this screenplay since the book jacket and cover only mention Jack Thorne as the author of this screenplay. I pre-ordered so I just double-checked if I had misread the item's description in my excitement to purchase it a while ago. But nope, it's still misleading. If it contained the original J.K. Rowling story this screenplay was based upon, I might have kept this book but I'm returning it unread. I thought I was buying J.K. Rowling.

author: Tamara Boyer
title: Awful
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content: Yech. I couldn't get past the first Act.  What an insult to JK ROWLING.  Her books are so entertaining and this was just so poorly conceived and written

author: Kate
title: What Did They Do to Harry?!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
Obviously people change between the ages of 17 and 36, but it is in no way believeable that this is the grown man version of Harry Potter. So much of this writing conflicts with JK's epilogue interview that she gave after Deathly Hallows was released.  You can read it here: [...]

Harry Potter is a hero to so many of us and this script just turns him into something else.

HP should have ended with Deathly Hallows. If JK wanted to return to Hogwarts, she should have done so with a whole new cast of characters who have nothing to do with the original characters. I'll go back and read the original 7 books now to try to erase the memory of this from my mind.

author: Mim
title: HP and the Cursed Child is the worst fanfiction ever written
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content: If I could give this 0 stars I would. Like other reviewers here, I have been an obsessive Harry Potter fan for a long time, and I've read a hell of a lot of fanfiction. This rated among the worst fanfiction I've ever read. The plot doesn't make a lick of sense and the characters are completely and utterly wrong. I wish I could un-read this. It is as terrible as it could possibly have been.

author: Eleni Arvanitis
title: Utter Disappointment
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 30, 2016
content:
I went into reading this script with slight trepidation as I had heard from others that it was just not quite up to snuff, but I had hoped that they would be wrong. I now know after wasting my time reading this that they were, unfortunately, quite wrong. This is a disaster. It's a sad excuse from J.K. Rowling to enter another story into the Harry Potter universe in such a disgraceful form. She had mentioned in an interview that she didn't want to write another novel. I'm furious that she mutilated the Harry Potter universe nineteen years after - especially starting the dialogue in this script with major discrepancies from the original text in HP DH - allowing others to aid in this sad excuse of a script. Using terms such as "Thank Dumbledore," or bringing back horrible characters in weird ways, it's clear that the writer has either lost touch on this subject or no longer finds it worthy of her time. Couldn't she have perhaps reread her own material to realize in her writing that any angry feelings Harry might have had towards Dumbledore subsided when they spoke at "Kings Cross"? There's just so much in here that is disappointing and feels to me that she doesn't even remember her own words or how they might evoke certain responses from her audience. It's bad enough that when the original books were turned to films, certain important aspects were altered or removed, but now she's done it all herself with this script... She could have done so much with certain aspects of this plot, and yet, she remained arrogant in her abilities, or simply rushed to spew this out. I can't say more without revealing larger aspects of the plot, so I will just urge you all who are in love with the original seven books to not taint your world of Harry Potter by buying this horrendous script.

P.S.: Ron is not an idiot for crying out loud! He was able to speak Parseltongue just by mimicking Harry in the Battle of Hogwarts! Your pathetic attempts at reviving a lighter mood derived from the easy swag of Fred and George Weasley have only made this script even more ridiculous.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Can someone perform a memory charm on me please?
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
I should say, I'm a massive Harry Potter fan. I'm such a fan of the novels that, at times, I can't watch the films because they are nothing like the books. I eagerly awaited the arrival of this script, and hoped that it would continue the story in a way that left me longing for more. I was severely disappointed.
You'll read it in the other reviews, I'm sure, but the plot holes and characterization of this story were just horrendous. There is no other word for it. You might find yourself, as I did, occasionally swept along in the story, but that doesn't make it a good story. It certainly doesn't excuse the poor writing which is filled to the brim with trope after trope, cliche after cliche, corny phrase after corny phrase. That JK Rowling would lend her support to a script of such poor quality is inconceivable. Perhaps she was confunded?

By page 42 I was ready to be done, by page 242 I was laughing hysterically. This script is pure tripe. I don't have a problem reading it in script form. I would rather read it in a script than be distracted from its flaws by flashing lights and (what I'm sure is) great acting.

Don't pay to read this book. Rent it from the library, or borrow a copy if your curiosity is that insatiable.

author: The Librarian
title: If only JK Rowling had written this as a book
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 10, 2016
content:
Yes, I knew it was a play script.  I found it tedious, insipid, and boring.  It was a lot of work to keep having directions to read.  It isn't well-written, but I assume JK needed some money, so she put her name on it.  The storyline wasn't awful, but the carrying out of it was. The characters were underdeveloped and I never found myself attached to them, as in the original series.  You never become invested - you don't really care if the boys achieve their goal.
Over and over, all I wanted was JK to have just written this as a book.  I understand she is a franchise, and congratulations for bringing uyourself up by the bootstraps, but I could have done without this book.  Perhaps the play is better (Emma Watson said it was).

author: Dix
title: One Star

content: I guess we Potter fans really wanted another Potter book and this was not it.

author: Sharon Koneck
title: Supreme disappointment
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2016
content: It reads like a high school play.  I mistakenly expected a new JK Rowling Harry Potter novel and got this sophomoric tripe.  Don't waste your money, it's obvious JK is cashing in on her past good works by feeding us poorly written, stilting dialog masked as the next chapter in the Harry Potter series.

author: V. Hogan
title: No stars deserved. Complete RUBBISH!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content: If I could have given this no stars that is what it deserves. For someone who loved & adored the books & the characters & even loved the movies (though books are inevitably better) I cannot imagine why JK Rowling would so destroy our beliefs on who these characters are. None of them act as we know they would have as adults. The relationships with each other are complete farce. I suffered through to the end to see if it would get better but no. No, it did not. Warning! Spoilers!! Voldemort has a love child, really? And with Bellatrix Lastrange of all witches? Give me a break. What a bunch of garbage! And apparently you don't need polyjuice potion to become someone else...let's just have Harry transfigure himself into Voldemort. Again, give me a break. This script/book/play was a nightmare to read & I give it NO STARS & one word could have summed up this story ... RUBBISH.

author: Nicole
title: Money Grab
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content: Listen, if you're a HP fan, you're going to read this book. But please, please, please, get it from the library or borrow a friend's version. Do not give these "writers" your money. This reads like a 327 page money grab. It has none of the charm and depth of JK Rowling's world. The two best words I have to describe this "book" is shallow and sterile. Everything we loved about the books (the locations, the lore, the characters) have boiled down into sterile, simple versions. It reads like amateur fan fiction; not the HP stories we all love.

content: I'm a huge harry potter fan and was so excited when i heard there will be a new book. i preordered it and was full of excitement when it was delivered. all of that excitement left once i opened the book. i read the first two pages and couldn't get passed the format. from what i hear from people that were able to get passed the format, it's a terrible story. huge disappointment. my dog came into my room and peed on it and i couldn't even be upset

author: mallen
title: Disappointed
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: I bought the book at Sam's Club on 7-31-16--usually I get books at Amazon, but I just happened to be there.  What I have always loved about the Harry Potter books was disappearing into a magical world myself--living and breathing the stories.  Well, you won't find yourself doing that here.  It is a play--a script--and so it is choppy, with one character speaking and then the next.  I wish I hadn't wasted my money.  Such a disappointment.  It is not the same thing at all.  Save your money or buy something else.  I can't believe that the author went this direction--the other books were so amazing.

content: This book is an embarrassment to all Harry Potter Fans. The way they made the characters seem was just cruel, especially for Cedric Diggory! If you haven’t read it I absolutely DON’T recommend! I absolutely love the Harry Potter series, my favorite series in the entire universe! They took all the attention off the main characters!! author: Sister Laurel O'Neal, Er Dio
title: Disappointing
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content: Okay, let me preface my review by saying I love the Harry Potter series and have written in support of it to those Christians who believe it is contrary to their faith or fosters interest in those things which are contrary to Christianity. I have reread the books a number of times. But I couldn't finish this. I knew it was a play and was prepared to like it in that format. But what I found here was disappointing in any number of ways. Character development was lacking or inconsistent with the original books. Jumps in the story (narrative line, character inconsistencies, etc) were more than a play-format could make up for or legitimize (what I mean is one expects jumps in the story when reading a play moving from from scene to scene or act to act but one cannot expect casting something in a play format make up for lacks or lacunae in the story itself; that is, at least partly,what I believe happened here). Sorry, but I gave this two major attempts to read it through (in case the problem was on my end of things) and still couldn't do it. Maybe it gets really good farther in but I never made it that far. Really disappointing.

author: Poetone
title: Terrible
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2016
content:
Not what I expected. I wanted a book like the rest. Would not recommend for reading enjoyment

author: Amazon Customer
title: Don't buy
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: I didn't read the script, but I saw the play in London and have been reeling ever since. Even before the play was finished, I wished I'd never seen it, that it'd never been written (I even considered not going to see Part II after Part I). I felt betrayed. I didn't expect anything on par with the novels, but I did expect a cohesive, enjoyable, and well-thought-out story, none of which desribe what the play actually is. How could Potter fans be elated, giving the play glowing reviews (yeah, the acting and on-stage magic is great, but the actual story was joy-quenching)? And how could JK Rowling, one of the best storytellers alive, give her stamp of approval or even call this the eighth Harry Potter story? It's really made me step back from the whole franchise, pull out my own Time Turner, and end it all in 2007.

author: Anastasia E. Wishka
title: I have read and re-read Harry Potter since I was eleven years old and grown to know and love the characters and the stories
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
Absolutely atrocious. I have read and re-read Harry Potter since I was eleven years old and grown to know and love the characters and the stories. These were not the characters I grew up with. They were flat, cheesy, and at times offensive. The plot was absolutely ludicrous and the story overall was poorly written.

As much as I love Harry Potter, I would have rather had nothing than have had this. What a disappointment.

author: melissa stewart
title: A Ranting Review (SPOILERS)
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2016
content:
First of all, as a life-long theatre lover, I have read many, many plays. So I understand that they are not meant to read like a novel. Obviously, they are best experienced on stage.

That said, I have loved dozens of plays that I haven't been able to see. I was hoping this was going to be one of those, too.

It wasn't. From the start, it felt choppy and disconnected. The characters we know and love said and did things entirely out of character, especially Harry. Ginny hardly had a role at all, and all the fierceness has apparently faded.

The plot was subpar. I have literally read the same plot in fanfiction, and I'm pretty sure they were better quality. It felt so contrived. I was hoping for a new villain, a new obstacle. Instead, the writers used time-turners to dredge up the same villain we spent seven books fighting and destroying.

And let's talk about those time-turners. (SPOILERS)

How convenient that an extra special time turner just happened to be created, and that Malfoy just happened to have one too. So. Contrived.

But the thing that bothered me the most? Hermione.

Hermione is married to Ron, and at the start of the play is Minister of Magic. She's brilliant and powerful, as expected, although I admit I was disappointed that she was in politics after all.

So the kids go back in time, and screw some stuff up, and Hermione and Ron's futures get messed up and they don't end up together.

Fine. I never liked them together.

But wait. What happens if Hermione doesn't marry Ron? She is a brilliant witch, an independent and fierce woman, so she is still wildly successful, right?

NOPE. She ends up as a Snape-like teacher, cruel to her students, bitter and angry about life, with no prospects.

WHAT. THE. HELL.

That is NOT Hermione, and the writing of one of the best female characters in fantasy did not feel like Rowling at all.

In short, save your money. This story was the worst.

author: J. Yu-Sian Wang
title: I feel like I wasted my money
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2016
content: I feel like I wasted my money.  This really feels like a fan fiction - and one that I didn't enjoy that much.  It's OK, but I personally feel that if JK Rowling wrote it, it would have been better.  If you can borrow it from the library, that's the best way.  You can always buy it later if you enjoy it.

author: nroselle
title: I have loved harry potter since the first book was released
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content: I have loved harry potter since the first book was released. I still read and reread the books frequently. I even got the whomping willow and various hp symbols and a dumbledore quote as a tattoo sleeve. This was VERY disappointing. The voices are all wrong. Harry doesn't sound like harry, Ron doesn't sound like ron, hermione doesn't sound like her mine and so on. The friendship between scorpius and albus is awkward to say the least. I am a female but I did not know any 14 year old boys who even jokingly acted this way toward each other. I cannot believe j.k. Rowling was for this. I wasted hours reading this book hoping it would get better and was sorely disappointed. Don't waste your money.

content: I am so sad to say that I hated it.  To be honest,  I think I would hate it even as a play. Honestly, I really think its quite worthless to read as the story line on it's own is just not good.

author: Chelsea
title: Nope
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 7, 2016
content:
Let's just pretend this didn't happen. New Harry Potter book? What new Harry Potter book? I CAN'T HEAR YOU.

My gripe isn't "oh Harry would never do that...Hermione would never say that...Well, that's not how I imagined their lives to turn out..." No. Although there was plenty of that. Example:

"Hermione: It's become quite popular {place to visit} as a weekend break.
Draco: I can see why - look at the thatched roofs. And is that a farmer's market?"

I have news for you. Draco would never talk about the quaintness of a thatched roof or go gaga over a farmer's market. Literally the most absurd thing I've ever read.

No, the improbable dialogue wasn't what turned me off. It was that this new story lacked innovation. Lacked magic. Lacked Hagrid. Cliché in both characters and plot development. Albus Potter was a thoughtless misguided Harry. Scorpio Malfoy was a totally-not-endearing Ron. This was just bad. I mean, read it because it's the new Harry Potter. But that's it.

Rowling was able to channel bits of the original series with at least one character - Ginny still has the personality of a wet cardboard box.

author: Linda H.
title: Such a disappointment!!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 29, 2016
content: How could someone so talented write something like this after writing all those wonderful Harry Potter books?  It's like watching a bad movie.  You just want it to end.

author: Amazon Customer
title: just the general sense of disappointment I feel makes it hard to think of what ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2016
content: Wow...just the general sense of disappointment I feel makes it hard to think of what exactly to say. First of all, being a die hard Harry Potter fan, having reading the books a dozen times in the last decade or so, having bought all of the extra books and holding J.K. Rowling to such a high standard I was extremely disappointed that her name was associated with this. It makes me feel a little better to know that she didn't actually write it, she just helped (?) come up with the general plot. It is frustrating, though, that she apparently did not even proof read?? There are so many things - big and small - that do not add up with the other books at all. The characters are barely even passable as themselves and even the terms are misspoken. "Minister for Magic"??? It's been Minister of Magic for seven books and now it changes? Even just small things like that irk me so much because it really is as though this is a poor fan fiction that Rowling felt some need to attach her name to? The narration - although I understand the need to be in play/production format - doesn't sound remotely like her! So disappointed. Going to go re-read the books and pretend like this never happened.

author: Amazon Customer
title: the plot is simply bad, and very lazy
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content: The problem is not that it's a play. The problem is that characters are shallow and unrecognisable. All of them, Harry, Ron, Hermione, Snape, even Malfoy in the end. Furthermore, the plot is simply bad, and very lazy. Instead of exploring something new, they just went back and used some old ideas, and at the same time ignored a lot of rules that had been established in the seven books. Finally the writing was not good either. I don't understand why Rowling approved of this. It really seems like the only goal was to make more money of it, and thus declare it as part of the cannon. I would never have bought this book, if I had known a) how bad it was, and b) that it wasn't even written by JK herself, although that's my mistake.

title: Read the reviews post-release, the rest are publisher driven.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content: This is fan fiction. Every time I re-read a book in the Potter series, I find a new reason to love Rowling as a writer. Her plots are tight and incredibly well developed, her use of language is art, her understanding of human dynamics is profound, and her her lesson about love and friendship is as subtle as it is powerful. The Cursed Child script is missing everything that makes Rowling's writing so genius. This "book" cheapens the brand. Why Rowling allowed her name to be attached is a mystery.
