author: Jorbatroth
title: One Real Parent
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2016
content:
This isn't the 8th book nd it is the script foe a play. I am fine with that, what isn't fine is the fact that the whole thing makes no sense. SPOILERS AHEAD. Alowing for the fact that we are to believe that Voldemort had a child with Bellatrix and that she woud have very recently given birth to said child before the Battle of Hogwarts. As well as the notion that there is a new time turner that will propel you back to your own time. Looking past those issues the time travel question and solution at Godric's Hollow makes no sense what so ever. In order for the boys to get a hold of the blanket they would have to make sure events transpire correctly therefore solving the problem.
With the introduction of a new prophesy I had assumed the writter was going to make Volemorets daughter misenterpret her role. She could have been the unknown child and lead her father to his downfall. Instead it is forgotten and suppossedly unfullfilled meaning all prophesies are avoidable and Harry, even after chosen by Voldemort, didn't have to face him. Thus making alot of talk between Dumbledore and Harry pointless.
Lastly, I just want to say that Draco was the only decent and semi-compitent adult in the entire thing. Harry hadn't grown since year 7, Ginny became pointless just like Ron, and Hermione was only good for holding meetings and being really bad at her job. Draco suffered, lost his wife, trying to rebuild his family name after his father, and constently begged Harry to say something about terrible rumors going around about his son.

If you are a diehard fan of the series you already have read this but if not dont bother it is pointless.

author: Schmidt
title: Don't bother buying this when there is better fan fiction for free!
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 3, 2016
content: I am a huge Harry Potter fan and have been since PoA came out in paperback. I've re-read them more times than I can count, seen all the movies, even been to Wizard Rock concerts. This is just not what I've come to expect from something with J.K. Rowling's name. The plot is terrible and full of holes, and there are so many continuity errors I can't even list them all. The big twist makes no sense and it doesn't even seem remotely possible that the characters wouldn't have known about it during DH. I had no problem with the script format, some of my favorite stories are scripts! It's just that I have read plenty of fan fiction that does more justice to the Wizarding World universe than this rubbish.

author: Amazoncus Tomer
title: Riding coattails like never before!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2016
content:
Yeah, you've probably already made the decision to buy this book because it says Harry Potter at the top and J.K. Rowling at the bottom.

I know I did.

You get this tome home, it undulates wickedly in your hands. A new story! A new format? Whatever, Rowling has never written anything we didn't like. No matter the waling sound drifting from the pages...

So you start into it and immediately your favourite characters are there. Only it isn't them. None of their mannerisms are left intact. Magic doesn't work like it should. Every single character, be it man or woman, adult or child, minister or muggle, talks like the same depressed adult trying to put on a brave face just to meet his deadline.

You slam the cover shut, your eyes streaming with tears. How? How could she do this?

Then you see it. She didn't write it.

Oh no. You've bought fanfiction. You've PAID for FANFICTION. Badly written to boot!

But I'd forgive it all - ALL OF IT - if I got the slightest inkling that Thorne was actually a fan. Or had read the books.
Any of them!
Instead, the whole book seems to be written from the point of view of someone who spent an evening watching the Goblet of Fire movie and spent the rest of the evening in the Harry Potter wiki. If this is true, I would invite Mr Thorne to read the following entries more closely:

[...]
[...]
[...]

Now, yes, there are a few folks here dismissing the problems because the series was meant for children. Which is insane. The cultural footprint of the series ought to back me up, though, honestly, I think C.S. Lewis beat me to anything I could say with this little gem:
"...When I became a man I put away childish things, including the fear of childishness and the desire to be very grown up."

Anywho, if you're still with me, I find it only polite to inform you that the spoilers are gonna start here and I'm gonna just start listing the parts that made me angry.

That's it, stop reading here if you still are going to read it and want nothing spoilt (though, admittedly, spoiling something already rancid isn't all that terrible, is it?)

Very well. I thank you in advance for your patience.

Right, so the character development that happened in the actual novels is gone. It's not here anymore. So Hermione is dull-witted and useless. Ron has become an alcoholic and for some reason a surly Fred-replacement. Harry doesn't seem to have any memory of coming to terms with Dumbledore's past, of his decision to save Draco and the mutual respect that developed, or of his childhood circumstances. I mean, maybe our hero underwent a massive stroke and refused treatment at St Mungo's. Also, Voldemort - who I'll remind everyone is basically a Lich - had sex (and I'm gonna just clarify that he is not "alive" per se, but essentially "undead") with Bellatrix (with Rodolfus' approval no less) in order to generate the book's personal antagonist. What is the purpose? A wizard chooses undeath just so that he doesn't need children! That's the whole point! He's immortal now!

When they start changing time, it gets worse. The author seems to have a thing for the Butterfly Effect and had things like Ron marrying Padma and Cedric Diggory becoming a Death Eater. Finally, our ponderous playwright engineers a scene in which Harry watches his parents get murdered! I might have been engaged - and thus disgusted - but this bloke forgot to explain how any of our erstwhile Time Lords manage to see straight through the Fidelius Charm that I guess just got ret-conned straight out of cannon by this mangy pile of ink and paper.

I suppose the problem, when you just get down to it, is that this reads like Doctor Who fanfiction and not Harry Potter. Indeed, you could name the characters literally anything else and the story would not change a bit. This feels like a personal story, one the author wanted to get out but could not get it published because, frankly, the dialogue is disjointed and sounds like a single adult arguing with the demon's inside his head. I began reading the lines in my head with a comically flat delivery. As if none of the people involved would even make eye contact with one another, which at least boosted the entertainment value of the book marginally.

Again, thank you for reading. Hopefully, I have saved you a bit of money. If not, I hope you enjoyed the venting just as I enjoyed reading some of the other reviews. Some of them are really quite clever and thought out. You should read those instead of Harry Potter and the Cursed Child.

Good night, everybody!

author: Amazon Customer
title: Apparently her amazing hubby spent the entire day looking for
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2016
content:
J K Rowling owes my husband a months worth of hand jobbing...

A friend of mine posted a pic of her brand new Harry Potter and The cursed Child Book on Facebook.  Apparently her amazing hubby spent the entire day looking for.  I jokingly said to Nathan, "Why can't you be like her hubby and get me my Harry Potter book too?"  He told me that he would get me the book that day.  I snorted at this response because you usually have to pre-order a Harry Potter Book.  "There is no way you will be able to find the book babe."  I said.  "Do you wanna bet?" He responded with far to much confidence for my liking.  "Cool, what do you want?" I replied... "A hand job for a month."  We shook on it and I smiled inside certain that I would win this one.  Not realizing that if he came home empty handed I would not really score.

Husband returned home with said elusive book and I was stunned.  I won't be going into our betting arrangement but Rowling owes me, not my hubby as the title suggests, a months worth of sexual favours.  I finished this book last night and afterwards wished I had never been born.  The only thing semi decent was its cover... They yellow made me feel happy and warm inside... The book was ridiculously awful, plot holes bigger than a whore's vagina, and characters that dulled the life right out of me... I will be wishing upon the next shooting star I see for a time tuner.  I will definitely go back in time and un-make my bet with hubby...

Before I receive hate mail, I would just like to let you all know that I LOVE HARRY POTTER and have watched the movies, read the books and am planning on getting a Deathly Hallow tattoo.  I am not a hater, just really hated this poop.

author: Lisa Schur
title: Dementors must have sucked the soul right out of this script.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2016
content:
As an avid Harry Potter fan, one who weeps her way through all of the novels, this book left me completely bewildered. Where was Rowling's voice, heart, soul? It was such a chore reading this script--I kept waiting for the characters to transform into their usual intelligent, caring, scrappy selves, but instead, they were all bland charicatures. Every line Ron had made me cringe.  He came off as some drunken, idiotic waste of space. To be honest, most lines in this book made me cringe. The plot was so thin, and every time there was a problem it was solved 2 pages later. There was no suspense whatsoever.

I found myself at the end of the book wondering what in the world I had just read because it was so boring I barely remember what had transpired. There was one single page that evoked emotion for me. ONE PAGE!

I just cannot understand how this soulless piece of fiction made it to print. Shame on you, J.K. Rowling, for not keeping the integrity of this beloved series intact. You owe your adoring fans a new novel to make up for this heartbreak.

author: cls
title: Potter STINKS
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
What exactly is a "Special Performance Edition Script"? "Based on an original new story by JK Rowling"?

A jumped-up play written by a couple of guys imagining they're doing Potter fans a favor--and that's the kind version of what I think is happening here.  Wonder who's profiting most from this concept?  Certainly not the reader.

I spent money on the pre-order, waited months for this book, greeted the mail carrier at the door, tore open the box, opened the gorgeous cover, and started to read....a play.

A play!

No.  No indeed.  I expected a story, an actual novel.  And I expected Rowling's hand.  I got neither.  The unread book is going straight back to Amazon, who did not make clear what they'd be shipping to hapless Potter fans everywhere.

 What a colossal disappointment.  This Potter stinks.

author: Brian T. King
title: Shameful... such a letdown!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content:
SPOILER FREE
There were so many bad decisions that went into making this it's hard to believe the person who wrote the finely crafted interlocking world of the original books was involved in any way.
First, why on earth would you issue the final episode in the form of a play? People keep saying "well it's probably better on stage". Well, the fan base is an ardent worldwide group of novel readers. Choosing to only show the true version of the story to ONE room of people in one place at a time was a just a poor choice. Everyone else gets cold and frankly ridiculous sounding stage directions instead of pages of rich description from one of the greatest writers of the century.

Second, and much more importantly, this story line is so bad it's actually gut-wrenching. As a huge long time potter it was so hard and painful to read. I don't usually like being critical or snobbish about movies or books. I try to enjoy them for what they are and not dissect them 100 different ways. That being said this script was so full of plot holes and inconsistencies it's actually hard to believe JK ever read it. Books can and will be written about the problems with this story line. It is completely incompatible with the world the original 1~7 books established. I would provide examples but don't have it in me to open the book again. The motives and actions of many of the characters make absolutely no sense at all. The decisions of both the protagonists and the main villain are so absurd and illogical that the only explanation is plot convenience to take the audience to revisit an old story.
It's so frustrating to see an almost perfect series, something which will live on as a classic; tarnished by what is essentially a polished turd.

content: If you are a true Harry Potter fan, STAY AWAY FROM THIS BOOK.  It is a play, a very annoying play.  Their children are annoying, nothing like how we watched Harry and his friends grow up. Rowling's was thinking, but she should  have had stay a sole author and written the final closure on her own and given us, the fans something worth waiting for.  This is dreadful.

author: Ashton R. Thompson
title: If I could give it negative stars, it would be negative infinity stars.....
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2020
content: This is absolute and utter garbage.  If I could force Amazon to give me back the money I spent on this vile, worthless excuse for a story I would—and then I would sue Jack Thorne and John Tiffany for emotion damages.  Look, we all wish JK Rowling would write more books, but that is absolutely no excuse for anyone to try to recreate the magic she made.  Not only did Thorne and Tiffany decide to try what is obviously a fool’s errand, they could not have done a worse job if they tried.  Did they actually even read the Harry Potter series, because it sure seems like they did not even have a passing knowledge of the contents of the books.  People who only read the description of the original 7 books could have done a better job.  Save yourself the trauma and DO NOT UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCES READ THIS DUMPSTER-FIRE OF A BOOK.  Seriously, Thorne and Tiffany should be imprisoned for inflicting this travesty on the world!

author: Marcia Blackwood
title: Regarding sample(s) only
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2016
content:
This is the most pathetic excuse for a Kindle sample I've ever seen. Seriously. Usually there's plenty by which to make a decision to purchase or not.

This sample is less than a page long.

There's more space devoted to the copyright material.

Come on, Amazon, fix this. Unless this is all you're allowed to preview? In which case this is someone else's bad decision.

Until that happens: everyone go to Goodreads. There's a review there that has more play text than this.

Sadly, it's not impressive. The review is largely positive, but what lines you see are, well, stilted would be a kind way to put it. Lots of telling, not showing. Also, very cliché. And already some serious conflicts with the existing books, which I can't say enough good things about.

At any rate, I'm dubious. I may buy a used copy from someone just to see, but I won't be buying it here, thanks to the bad joke of a sample. And I rarely have any complaints about Amazon.

Hopefully I'll be pleasantly surprised by the actual script, but.... Well, at present, I can see why people have complained. I have no issue with it being in play format and was frankly intrigued to see how it read, how it translated into the different storytelling form. But a play should still be readable, and what I saw quoted in several Goodreads reviews was just trying.

Fanfic can be excellent and sometimes even better than what inspired it. But what I've seen so far is not promising. So just be warned - This may be a book for which you hope for the best, but are prepared for the worst.

author: Sky Oldham
title: I loved the book
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2016
content: I loved the book. Don't get me wrong. I am an absolute fan and love the book. I've waited months for it to be released. I am also one that cares for my books too much. I treat them with respect. I am extremely upset because when I received my copy of this book the cover was ripped and destroyed. The pages were in terrible shape. Everything about it was just heartbreaking. I ended up crying because someone thought it was okay to mishandle a book in that way. Now don't get me wrong. The box it came in was perfectly fine. But the book wasn't!!!!

author: Amazon Customer
title: The story reads like a terrible piece of fan fiction
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2016
content: The story reads like a terrible piece of fan fiction. I'm sure it looks great on stage, but anyone who is a big Harry Potter fan will be frustrated reading this. It's best to not read it and pretend it never existed.

author: Sagar Yadama
title: Disappointing Read
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
Harry Potter has been one of my favorite series since elementary school, and I knew this play would not live up to expectations  I would have had from an eighth novel.

That being said, there are a couple things I expect from a Rowling endorsed work that presumably will be  treated as canon. I expect the work to play by the rules set down in the original series and I expect character actions to make sense considering their personalities and motivations in the original series. Unfortunately, this was not the case for the cursed child.

This play had major conflicts with mechanics established in the original series. Aside from that, after extensive mapping and diagramming of the events, I determined that at least 3 major events could not have ocurred solely based on the information provided in this play. I am aware that the main series contains occasional inconsistencies, however, the plot holes in this play are used to drive the main story. At some point  you need a  story that is plausible within the  boundaries of the fantasy world. The  Cursed child's plot is fundamentally impossible even while ignoring conflicts with the original series.

In addition to story plausibility, many characters acted contradictory to their personality in the  original series. I understand that people change as time goes by, but there are several cases in which a character who has not changed completely undermines his original series self. The amazing character arcs that Rowling created are competely thrown out the window.

Overall, this felt like a story written by someone who did not bother to maintain consistency with the previous novels or even within this story itself.

author: Amazon Customer cate16
title: A travesty!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content: This is a play. So, what. Much of the great literature is written in play-form. This is NOT great, however. Not even good! I was hesitant to buy this, based on the early Amazon reviews, but Michiko Kakutani, of The New York Times, gave it a great review. I can only say: Thanks, Michiko, for wasting my time and money! This is SO far from the quality of the Harry Potter series, it's really appalling that Rowling gave it her blessing. The plot is amateurish. There is a real lack of understanding of the way children think, act, or speak. Frankly, NONE of the characters were recognizable. And worse: it is POORLY WRITTEN, folks! Poor grammar! Yeah, apparently you can be a successful script writer without being able to write proper English! Wow! This is a shock and a disappointment. Having read through the series multiple times, I quit half-way through this book in utter disgust!

The characters are not true to themselves. It is rushed and leaves you feeling empty. Unless you want your soul torn into pieces as you read this debacle of a story and  tarnish your memory of all that is the wizarding world, avoid this horcrux.

title: This was the biggest waste of money I have ever spent in my entire ...

I honestly had zero expectations going into this play, but was still shocked at how terrible it was. It is very obvious it is not JK's writing. The characters are almost always caught saying/doing something their original characters would obviously never convey. The dialogue is cheesy and predictable. The entire plot is just a big cliche of another typical butterfly effect scenario, and a very simplified one at that. Even when you overlook how drastically it misfits with its preceding Harry Potter universe, it's gaping plot holes and horrible dialogue make it almost unreadable. I am truly embarrassed and disgusted with myself that I fell for this con.

author: M. Krenzin
title: What HAPPEND Jk Rowling!!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content:
My name is Esther. I have always loved your books... they are the best books ever to be written. Your books have inspired me, a 13 year old girl to write books of my own. Gosh, I was so in love with your world and its magic, I begged for my mom and dad to let me cut a harry potter scar of my own. They refused, and said I would have to wait until I was 18. I still remember all those nights I cryed myself to sleep because my mom and dad wouldnt let me watch or read them. I remember despairing, and thinking they would never LET me read them all or watch them. I dreamed of harry potter, i had wonderful magical dreams. I used to say that I was Lily Potter, I was Harry Potters daughter. I was so desparate that when no one was there I looked up spoilers of the movies and books. Then pretend that I watched the movies with him... i remember being made fun of, my brother and sister made fun of me and made me so mad and sad. "You dont even LOOK like him!"
"Your being delusional!" "Your a lyer."
I told them, "I put a spell on myself to make me look like a brown haired girl, but really i am Lily... with red hair and brown eyes." I remember staying up super late to do pretend homework, pages and pages of it, till my hand almost fell off. Me and my freind used to pass letters back and forth, pretending to do lessons at hogwarts, detention, quidditch, yule ball. I used to cry when I read parts of Harry Potter when people made fun of him... i knew how he felt! I wrote down every single speel and memerized it. I was so excited when I heard that there was a 8th book coming out, I counted down the days, Months, years... and when I finally got the sample the day it came out... i wanted to cry. What have you done to my Freinds and companions! Where is that exciting magical action packed book that i love so much! Where is the jokes, where is GEORGE!!! What happend to smart clever HERMIONE!!! What happend to Brave and kind HARRY!!! GINNY! RON!!! LILY!!!!!! DUMBLEDORE!!! Jk Rowling, please dont tell me you actually approved of this and LIKED it???? Please! What has happend! I look up to you so much... you are what keeps me going when I despair of writing my book. But now... I want to cry.
Please, everyone says this is your last book! Dont let it be! Write another that is actually the "8TH BOOK!!!" Please. please. please. You broke so many hearts the day you let them publish that. I will never understand, and I know you might not take me seriously because Im only 13, but please consider.
I now this sounds weird, But I send my love and best hopes to you. May you always be happy, and find strengh in dark times. Always look for the light that glimmers in the darkness.
You are still my hero.
Esther.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Ugh, just no.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: I wish I could UN-READ this book! I'm now re-reading Sorcerors Stone to cleanse my heart and mind of this, because EWW what did I just read?! It felt like the characters we know so intimately, and love so dearly, were ABSOLUTE strangers...This book is a disgrace to their legacy! Harry was totally unrecognizable, and one dimensional, for the majority, nay, the ENTIRETY, of the story. Hermoine lost all the cleverness and grace that makes her so lovable/heroic. And Ron was essentially comic relief, with no depth whatsoever. Couldn't feel further from the Trio that we've come to know, love, and call our best friends. Not only was their dialogue and interaction so bizarre, but the other characters as well; including the highly anticipated kids of our heroes. I legitimately tried to stretch my imagination to see the scenes in my mind and heart, and there were certainly a few (and I mean VERY few) tender moments with a small glimmer of familiarity to JK's wizarding world, but the horrific plot and dialogue quickly turned tenderness into disappointment. I'm seriously so saddened that JKR put her stamp of approval on this, normally she can do no wrong in my eyes, but this book was such a disappointment. There's more wizarding world familiarity in a 60 second trailer for Fantastic Beasts, than there was in this entire book! At least one good thing came out of Cursed Child, I'm 100% going as the Trolley Witch for Halloween.

author: Charmayne Grandy
title: Childhood dissapointment
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content: I'm going to start by saying, I grew up with Harry Potter. I am still currently for probably the thousandth time rereading the books I grew up loving. Harry Potter and the cursed child is abismal. Harry, Ron, hermione, Draco, everyone is completely lost in this, they are just names used at this point. The story was sloppy and very rushed, moving years in only a few pages. I understand that as we grow older we change but this had very little left of anyone. At best I can describe it as a very poorly written fan fiction. Everything about what I at least loved about Harry Potter was completely removed. I understand this was a script for the play but I don't think it remotely was written by jk. If it was I would expect details from previous books to be correct and not severely muddled like the movies were. I am very dissapointed, and am not considering this a Harry Potter book, it was abismal. If there is anything I wish I could tell jk, it's this: we loved Harry yes but his story ended, we want more yes, but we fell in love with the world, and that is what we want more of. Tell us a story that has nothing to do with him or his family.

author: harry w. greenberg
title: ... sure if I can even put into words how disappointed I was after reading this story
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content:
I'm not sure if I can even put into words how disappointed I was after reading this story. But before I get into it, I want to make a few things clear. 1. I knew it was a script and not a novel; that is not what I have an issue with. 2. I am a massive Harry Potter fan and I absolutely love the books and movies. 3. I'm sure this is a very entertaining play to watch, but it does not belong in the Harry Potter franchise/universe.
Okay. The biggest problem with Cursed Child is that it wasn't written by Rowling. She can pretend that she had something to do with it, but she didn't, or if she did, she must really no longer care at all what happens to her precious wizarding world. This story had so many major plot holes that would never fly in a HP novel. Part of what makes Harry Potter so special is the amount of details that JK put into it. Nothing in the HP books was an accident, and even today almost 10 years later fans continue to notice amazing details that no other author would take the time to put into a "children's" story. Cursed Child reads like fan fiction, and there is nothing wrong with fanfiction, but it pisses me off to no end that Rowling is calling this an official sequel to her otherwise perfect series. This writer was lazy and decided to recycle a cliche story-line while ruining our beloved characters in the process. What is the point?We did not need this story. It gives no new insight to the wizarding world (unlike any of the short stories that were actually written by Rowling, those are great) and it does not tell us anything that we didn't already know about Harry. Spoiler alert (but not really): Harry works at the Ministry of Magic! His relationship with his son isn't perfect! But after useless conflict that only rehashes the past, everyone lives happily ever after! The magic of Rowling's books is not present here, and there are at least 3 major plot holes that ruin the entire integrity of the story. I don't want to actually spoil anything, because I do believe that you should read it for yourself, but this book is a disgrace. What makes me the most angry is that this piece of sh*t was given to us, and then Rowling says "that's it for Harry! Cursed Child is the end of his story!" when it should have never been part of his story in the first place. I could go on and on, but basically, this book sucks and it is ridiculous that it is considered canon. Jk Rowling was my queen, I thought that she could do no wrong, but after reading Cursed Child I have been seriously rethinking things.....

author: CC
title: Tremendous disappointment,  None of the characters are recognizable.
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: There are multiple problems with this work, including an improbable, convoluted plot.  But the worst parts of this script are the utterly unrecognizable characters.  This is absolutely unforgiveable and leaves me baffled.  Who are these people?  How did this get so screwed up?  Since when is Draco Malfoy a source of wisdom and advice to Harry Potter?  Why change Snape into a weird buddy-buddy defender instead of the delghtfully unpleasant character who is heroic despite himself? Yes, Scorpius is genuinely attractive as a person, and that is fine.  But does any of this REALLY feel like the orignal series?  Or honestly, isn't this like Imposter Harry Potter - and a transparent fail?  My advice is, skip this.  Don't pay a dime for this.  Borrow it from the library if you must, but please do not spend your hard-earned money.  This book is a tremendous disappointment.

author: TL
title: Bad. Bad. Bad.
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2018
content:
As a true Harry Potter, I have to say that this “story” is just wrong. There are so many flaws. The characters don’t even talk or behave as they did in Rowling’s books. It’s an insult to the intelligence of fans who have spent years reading and rereading the HP series. A couple of dudes who knew nothing about HP wrote this and screwed it up royally. I get the vibe that these two guys didn’t even bother to read the HP series...for example, if they did, they’d understand how the Fidelius Charm would work at the Potter’s home and how because James and Lily were hiding Harry, they weren’t able to leave the house (Lily mentions this in a letter the find she once wrote to Sirius in DH). Yet, here...the two dudes have James and Lily out pushing Harry in a pram. Major contradiction to the original story.
This “story” is worse than fan fiction because at least most fan fiction, however bad it may be, is written by true HP fans who actually do keep their facts straight.

author: Josh Brown
title: Literary Vomit.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2016
content: This is an awful story that is 100% untrue to the original characters and original plot line (which the book manages to change like 3 times… sorry for the spoiler; I won't give any more but just be warned that everything "crazy" that happens in the story is absolutely ludicrous and will anger you immensely).  I feel like J.K. Rowling decided to have a contest where she had fans write the last story, and then would pick the best one as the winner while editing and changing it for inconsistencies.  She then got ridiculously lazy, scattered the entries all over the floor, threw a dart up in the air, slapped her name on the first script it hit without even looking at it, and had it published.  It did not hit a good one.  JK Rowling, you've officially sold out.  The only redeeming quality about this entire book is that it is in play form, meaning there is very little writing, meaning you will waste fewer hours of your life reading it (think tearing off a bandaid on a particularly nasty wound.)

Hopefully it won't give me too many nightmares in the meantime.

author: Alex Parrish
title: Not a Harry Potter story. More like bad fanfiction.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2016
content:
There will be some spoilers in my review. Consider this your warning.
Oh boy, where do I begin... First of all, this is not a book. This should be obvious to most, but in their zeal, some people have overlooked the fact that this is a play. A play not even written by JK Rowling.
As far as plays go, it is uninteresting and bland. Not terrible, but it's middle-school-pageant level stuff.
As far as Harry Potter stories go, it is a soul crushing disappointment.
Harry Potter stories are, at their core, mystery books in a fantasy magical setting. This play has no mystery to it. Sure, it has a twist or two, but no major overarching mystery that the characters and audience need to solve. The narrative plays out like a bad piece of fan fiction. There are some interesting parts at the beginning that do a decent job of getting you hooked, but after that, it's just plain awful stuff. One of the central pieces of canon from The Prisoner of Azkaban is completely ignored: The time turner. In Rowling's book series, a time turner is a device that allows you to rewind time by a few hours and live things back forward to the present. However, it does not allow you to change time. Before rewinding time, you are able to observe in own timeline anything that you do after rewinding time. Once you rewind time, you are destined to live that out exactly as it already happened. However, in this book, time turners are used to go back decades, and somehow only allow you to stay in the past a few minutes. They do this over and over again, Butterfly Effect style.
This turns Harry Potter and the Cursed Child into a time travel book. And The Butterfly Effect did it much better.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Book 8? BLASPHEMY! It's just a really bad fanfiction!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content: Despite being a Harry Potter fan for many years, I was greatly let down by the mangled mess of time travel and fairly weak and confusing plot. Seriously? I've read other Harry Potter fanfiction more worthy of being a Rowling-approved sequel than this garbage. I cringe every time I see this stupid script.  I WILL NOT AND DO NOT ACCEPT THIS AS CANON! I can only hope the Fantastic Beasts movie will be good.

title: A dud.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
I did not enjoy this story, and I really wanted to. The first 2/3 of the story is a tale of teenage angst. The final 1/3 is interesting, premise-wise, but extremely week. "And then EVERYONE had children and their children reenact the same dramas" is boring. The Malfoys have drama again (even though Harry and Draco ended on good terms?), Harry doesn't see anything wrong with locking up his son (uhm...)?  Delphi is.. actually I still don't know what her original goal was. I'm trying not to throw spoilers here, but what was she getting at with Cedric? Before Albus & Co see the possible other outcomes, what did she hope would happen?

Sigh.  I'll still see the play when it comes around, but I won't travel to see it like I had planned.

author: Joshua
title: J.K. Rowling has become the George Lucas of literature...
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2016
content: “Harry Potter and the Cursed Child” is an abomination.  Most people I have spoken with said they despised the script form used to tell the story; but that is not the problem.  The true problem lies in the mediocre attention to detail, poor writing style, predictable storyline, and general disregard for previous novels.  The story reads like a fan-fiction written by a thirteen-year-old.  Cannon from previous novels and J.K. Rowling’s website are thrown out the window to advance the storyline.  The new characters are easily forgettable and even the original characters (i.e. Harry, Ron, and Hermione) are utterly boring.  The story generally follows of a theme of “I love you and, therefore, I must protect you even though protecting you is the cause of the problem.”  The concepts of time travel, anomalies, and the Butterfly Effect are abused to the point it is painful to turn the page.  Some try defending the book by pointing out there are two other people who helped write this book and to that I say “irrelevant!”  By including her name on the cover, J.K. Rowling accepts full responsibility for this highly-disappointing novel.  The inferior quality of this book leads me to believe that J.K. Rowling only returned to the Harry Potter universe when she realized she had only one series to her name worth reading.  After reading “Harry Potter and the Cursed Child”, it is clear she has no regard for her previous works, her fans, and the literary world.  J.K. Rowling has become the George Lucas of literature, choosing to throw her passion for storytelling away for the sake of a few quick bucks.  I have already dispensed of my copy of this book and will never read a future piece of writing by J.K. Rowling, John Tiffany, or Jack Thorne from this moment on.

(¬_¬)

author: Kevin A. Kilroy
title: WHY!!!! WHY????
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
J.K how could you? I wanted to love this book and at first it was amazing. But the charm wears off with a far fetched plot. Bringing one of the least important characters back to life? VOLDERMORT HAS A KID? Who in their right mind would sleep with VOLDERMORT? Overall, it read like mediocre fan fic.
The relationship development was clumsy. In trying to show a close relationship between friends, the author made it seem like Albus and Scorpious would end up together but then it came to nothing. The author clearly had no experience writing relationships or young characters. Also, Harry is a complete jerk throughout (probably because he can't come to terms with his son being gay). His charter as a whole is completely tarnished.
Finally, there are a lot of characters I'd rather see in this than voldermort's secret love child. None of the other Weasly kids appear, no Teddy, no Victorie. And Ron has reverted back to the maturity of a 14 year old. Poor Hermione!
It seems like someone clumsily wrote fan fiction in screenplay format. If I didn't know she was richer than the queen, I'd think JK just did this for the money. I'm heartbroken

author: Kisha Tarog
title: As a person who loved the HP series
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2016
content:
As a person who loved the HP series, cried while reading the books and watching the movies, fangirling over it with my best friend about essentially which house we'd be in and things like that, this book, or should I say, this play manuscript does no justice to this series.

It started off okay. There's the whole teenage angst and not wanting to be compared to someone from your family (your siblings, or should I say DAD in this case). But then it fell apart when Harry Potter, the boy we grew up with, apparently does not grow up in the bildungsroman that is supposed to be the Harry Potter series.

And apparently, being in an adult means you can't be a competent wizard. Harry Potter, the boy who defeated Voldemart with an Expelliarmus spell - AN EXPELLIARMUS SPELL- who was just so incredibly talented in the dark arts and magic, could not even defeat the titular character 'the cursed child' by himself.

I'm so incredibly disappointed at the level of writing this play offered.

author: Seamus
title: Pure GREED. Love Harry Potter Stories? don't ruin that by reading this garbage! You've Expierenced better versions of 'story'
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
Awful. Truly awful. An unbelievable disappointment. I wish there was a spell that could make me forget this drek.

The Dementors aka John Tiffany and Jack Thorne have sucked the soul out of Harry Potter. Clearly they've already gotten to JK to allow this.

Story was weak. Writing was worse. Plot...infantile. What a horrible attempt to cash in. Not even a tiny bit original. JK Rowling should be embarrassed. How she could allow this to be published...and with her name on it.

This 'play' could (might) have been written by a 5th grader, a slow 5th grader. I wonder if JK Was merely drunk while watching 'Back to the future' one day and thought 'gee, I could make another $250,000,000 or so with that.

The reviews do not do the story justice.  Merely calling it terrible is an injustice to all the books and plays that are merely terrible when this is so much worse.

author: Amazon Customer
title: As disappointing as you expect
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2016
content:
I was in the book store today, and I saw this on the shelf.
"Really? Another Harry Potter? Um, is Rowling desperate to recapture fame? Has she already spent up her vast fortune and in need of a cash injection? .... Oh, I gotta take a peek anyway"
This was the flow of internal dialogue I had in my head as I approached the shelf and nervously picked up a copy. My cynical mind wrestled with my hopeful heart. Maybe, just maybe, this will be a fun read.

I leafed through the first section and grew increasingly dismayed and profoundly irritated with myself for having wasted 20 minutes reading it in the store. When I left and arrived home, I had three benefits from reading that first part:

1) I'm glad I didn't purchase it. What a waste of money that would have been.
2) While it sucks to be right, at least I didn't waste more of my life reading it in the feint hope it might improve
3) By the time I got home and set about venting my frustration to my husband, I realized my brain had already purged 2/3 of what I read. I could barely recall any significant detail that made it worth wasting breath upon. Hurray for brain efficiency!

content: The very talented JK Rowling, has a very distinctive rhythm and flow to both her action and dialogue, conspicuously absent throughout this. The conclusion, which was obvious from the beginning, has become a dismal yet merciful coup d' gras.  I would hope Ms Rowling would be more discreet in selecting  writers in the future.  In closing, I've seen much better work posted by readers,on Pottermore.

Scorpius was cool, though.

author: gift Card recipient
title: the problem is that it is a terrible script. What a mess
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
Incredibly...wrong.  Spoilers. Voldemort with a child?  Then why his obsession with living forever? Snape calls Granger "Hermione", no way.  Harry calls Professor Dumbledore, "Dumbledore"?  In which alternate reality? Ron gets drunk at his wedding? Don't think so.  Ron is a real wimp?  He rode a knight in Real Wizards Chess. Draco Malfoy likes Granger bossing him around?  He wanted her dead and Granger broke his nose. Dumbledore, who we are again reminded doesn't really live in portraits, none the less has an out of character emotional melt down in front of Harry? Really? Dumbledore?  And why exactly did Delphi murder a kid?  So we could be reminded there is no death penalty in the wizarding world (just hellish solitary confinement at Azkaban) The problem isn't that it's a script and not a book, the problem is that it is a terrible script.

What a mess.  Rowling's lost her touch and a chunk of her most devoted audience with this rubbish.

author: Amazon Customer
title: POOR FOLLOW-UP and not because it's a play
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2016
content:
DISAPOINTED
At school in England I had to read stories in “Play” format so I do not have a problem with that type of reading. My problem with this book is that the characters are NOT AT ALL who they are, or should I say were!
At the end of the last book we see that Harry SEEMS to have a good relationship with Albus, as far as one can tell from a book ending. Now they dislike each other.
Draco saved Harry and Harry saved Draco. Though there was no conversation at the end of the last book one would think they had a mutual peace. Not so in the new book.
The story is not as well developed as the 8 book series.
Harry and Ron are Not Aurors???
Hermione is Minister???
A Time Turner would be kept in the Ministers office and those children would be able to figure out how to get it and work out how to use it???
3 turns goes back a few hours for the type Hermione had. I’m sure there is more than one type, but please.
I will finish the book but I don’t recommend it to anyone for the cost. It’s rather a big disappointment to end the story this way when Rowling could have done the encyclopedia of characters and made a lot of people really happy.

author: MelissaJean
title: Heartbreaking for true Potter fans
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2016
content:
(no spoilers in this, I haven't actually finished the book and I've already made me decision on it) I'm heartbroken to be writing this.. I cannot tell you how big a part of my life the Harry Potter series has been. To say I adore it isn't enough. So The Cursed Child is killing me. It's so bad.

I tried so hard to tell myself that it's a play, it has to be a little different, they can't have every little detail and every single character. And I could get over missing details and characters. What I can't get over is the out right absurdity and silliness. I know it sounds like a crazy thing to say about a series about magic, but it's true. In the original series Rowling could write about unicorns and flying broom sticks and magical ways of being immortal, and she did it in a way that made you feel it was possible, made you feel like you could really be a part of that world. This book doesn't have that. Instead it has me shaking my head and getting irritated at how little it follows the concrete facts Rowling worked so hard to establish. It always amazed me how she wrote a series over several years and everything tied in so well together; this book just doesn't have that.

The first part I found ridiculous was the trolley witch. Suddenly she's this hundreds of years old being whose food turns into bombs and can turn her hands into spikes but apparently has no means of stopping two boys who are supposed to be bad at magic (they can't do spells well until they practice them, like twice, and suddenly they can. They also never get in trouble for doing magic outside of school) from jumping off the train.
Then there's the 'engorgio' charm. It sounds like a small detail but it really bugs me. They use it to engorge someone's head and he floats away. In the original series engorgio was used to make things bigger, not fill them with helium. As I said, it was something so normal in the original series, and it just gets completely skewed in this, and it's an example of this kind of thing happening multiple times.
Another thing I can't stand is the time turner. A man wants Harry to go back before Voldemort's return to power and save his son's life. This so greatly diminishes everything that was established in earlier books about time turners and even about Harry's relationship with this man.

There are so many other examples of things that just don't fit into the Harry Potter world, but the worst thing about reading this is that these characters just aren't the same. These aren't the characters we fell in love with. Ron's just a moron, I can't get a grasp on who Harry is at all, and with Draco it's like they can't make up their minds about if he's supposed to be nice or a jerk. You would expect Rose, with a laid back father, loving mother, and close nit family to be a good person, but she's nothing but a little snob. Honestly with the huge Weasley family and all the others Harry's surrounded himself with, you just expect them all to be close nit and loving, but that's just no the case and it's so sad.

The deeper into this book I get, the more it feels like a fanfiction written by a juvenile, and the more I feel like it has to be a joke. It's sad for those of us who have stuck loyally by this series to see Rowling willingly put her name on something that so clearly undermines the series she worked hard to create. This is not the Harry Potter we know and love.

author: Amanda
title: Spoilers and I don't care

content: I loved the books even after I felt JKR sold out. Fine fine fine. But to me this script play book -whatever- is unforgivable. She tells us Voldemort is incapable of love, she tells us he didn't need anyone, she tells us he didn't care for being touched so we're to believe that he and Bellatrix -in the middle of a war against Harry- are just going to stop everything to have sex? He might have trusted her as much as he could but to physically connect with her,come on.  And for them to have a child to go back and try to change time so her father could win-whatever.  This was a cheap attempt to smear us-her beloved readers- with bringing back cherished characters from the dead for a last hurrah.  This fan fiction should have never been allowed to besmirch any of us or our characters.

author: Nate
title: This book makes the frustrations of watching Groundhog day seem like a day on a beach.
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 16, 2019
content:
Sort of a spoiler warning.

You start the story exactly where you'd expect things, except for Harry's son Albus being a moody sourpuss (young Snape type) character.  The first Act was okay, then when the major plot twist happens at the beginning of Act 2, everything you knew and loved about the original books hits the proverbial fan.  I had to put the book down because it was so difficult to endure.
This book by no means is a long read.  One with middle school reading abilities could read it through in a matter of a long evening (it is a play after all).  However, the metaphorical stabs to the heart made me take days in between sessions.  Like a masochist, I went back for more.  Only to experience the assault to memory of a beloved character/story over and over.
This is not a lot different then if you had a magic wand (pun intended) to wave and fix the last season of Game of Thrones...except in complete reverse.  You had a perfect story, neatly tied up in a pretty bow, and you burned it like an anarchist just to watch it burn.

author: There are much worse games to play
title: Harry Potter fans, don't read this poorly written fanfic
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2016
content:
The top part of this review will be as spoiler-free as possible. Long story short, if you are a fan of the books, do yourself a favor and skip this script because it reads like a poorly written fanfic. Here are the following reasons why:

1. A lot of the characters act and say things completely out of character - like the script was written by someone who only watched the movies and did not read the books. You will experience your favorite characters saying and doing things that they would never say or do in the original books. This script was clearly not written by Rowling and written by writers who have no in-depth understanding of the nuances of each character.
2. The major plot line is something that isn't even possible in the original Harry Potter books. Prepare to have a major theme from one of the books reversed in the script. The plot line is also a cliche and overused trope in television shows.
3. This script has no major consequence on the original plot. So you aren't missing out on anything by not reading this.

Conclusion to the spoiler-free section: There's a reason why most HP fans are calling this a poorly written fanfic. That's because in bad fan fiction, the writers don't usually get the characters correctly and use overused and un-creative plot devices you see in movies and TV shows. This is exactly how I would describe this script.

***SPOILERS SECTION***
To go more in-depth in my points above (with spoilers), let's look at #1-3 again.

1. The original characters are back including Harry, Ron, Hermione, and their spouses. But Harry has temper tantrums that he never exhibited in the books. Hermione is done correctly while Ron is reduced to slapstick humor. Draco seems a bit out of character as well. Snape makes a brief cameo and does the weirdest things you wouldn't expect Snape to do. Like he actually calls Ron by his first name and gets a bit sappy. You would expect Snape to keep calling Ron "Weasley."
2. The major plot line is about going back in time and establishing alternate universes. First of all, THAT'S NOT EVEN POSSIBLE IN THE BOOKS. In the third book, we learned that whatever happens, already happened and cannot be changed. Time cannot be changed in the Harry Potter universe. You can go back in time but that has already happened and the consequences have already happened. In the third book, Buckbeak was already saved before Harry and Hermione went back in time. Second, going back in time and changing the timeline is an overused trope in television and movies. It is un-creative and lazy because everything just goes back to the way it was at the end. And nothing new was added. This leads to #3.
3. Like the overused trope in television shows, the alternate "bad" timeline is always fixed in the end and everything goes back to the way it was. This is exactly what happens in The Cursed Child. So you aren't really missing out by skipping this "eighth" installment. Nothing new is added. The conflict occurs in the past but everything is fixed in the end so it doesn't affect the present. In fact, by skipping this script, you will spare yourself the facepalms and anger that might come up from the terribly written plot and character development.

Conclusion for the spoilers section: Harry's kid goes back in time and messes things up. Oh no, Voldemort is now in power. Now they have to go back and correct it. They do. Everything goes back to normal. Yay. That's it. Plus you can't even recognize the characters sometimes because they do and say things they would have never done in the original books. This script does nothing to add to the Harry Potter universe and is worth skipping to spare yourself of the poor writing and constant contradictions to the original HP universe.

author: md21
title: Should have stopped with Deathly Hallows
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2016
content: J.K. Rowling should be ashamed of this release.  In addition to huge plot holes, this story directly contradicts much of what was establish as "fact" or canon in the original seven stories.  Furthermore, the inclusion of characters whose story arcs had already been beautifully told was completely unnecessary.  I wanted to enjoy this as much as the previous Potter works, but I could not.  To me it is nothing more than fan fiction that is only loosely based on what was created in books 1-7.  After all of the thought and care that was put into Harry Potter's seven story journey, I would have hoped much more attention to detail would have been evident in this installment.  An utter disappointment.

author: S. Bird
title: Killing the goose that lays the golden eggs: Not true Potterverse and NOT AT ALL true JKR writing
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content:
Reads badly like a story in a monthly magazine written for subscribers. I feel they disrespected the Potter fans worldwide and am returning this book pronto.
Found glaring plotholes(IMO) and like another reviewer said, the characters do not stay true to their own values from the original series.
Really bad fanfic! Not at all worth the hype and the fact that there is a "Definitive script" also being released later at some point shows that the publishers and whoever else is making even a single penny off this book have published it for the money.
Should not say this is the "Eighth story, 19 years later" and tarnish the memories and expectations of the readers. Especially when JKR keeps blowing her trumpet saying that her Potter writing is done fully and finally, but still keeps churning content regularly!
Personally, I would like to say to JKR that she should have waited to publish this work and ironed out all the discrepancies and issues first instead of what seems to be a very rushed and improperly vetted publication.
Not even worth 10$ and they are selling it for 18$ on Amazon to make that fast buck before everyone catches onto the absolute rubbish that this book is.
I don't mind it being a play OR a script but even as either it seems terrible with magical beings making muggle references in dialogue amongst other terrible nuisances this book creates.
JKR, it's OK to not put out more HP stuff, we can live with what's already out there but please don't ruin it for everyone by giving your blessing to such ditchwater writing. Sorry John Tiffany and Jack Throne, maybe your own creative characters would have had more justice done than for you both to have used the names of the favourites of millions worldwide and disappointing them such.

title: Rowling, I want my money back!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
Rowling, I want my money back! I have an idea - everyone, who is as disappointed as I am, let's send our books back to Rowling! How come her name appeared on this?.. Do not spend your money and time. It's a disaster. The characters are not themselves. In HP original series it took 1800+ pages to describe HP 4 years in Hogwarts. Here for his son it took - guess how many?-- 10! Yes, ladies and gentlemen, TEN pages! 10 pages for 4 years. Still, it could have been good if there were no such horrible mistake which make me think that the authors consider readers/audience complete idiots. SPOILER: Act three in the end: Albus is left without his wand which has been taken from him and snapped. This fact was mantioned two times. Act four: "Albus opens both doors with his wand". How come? When and where did he obtain his wand again?
As I said: Rowling, I want my money back!

I honestly cannot imagine why, unless each audience member was compensated heartily for a positive review. The plot is AWFUL. Time travel, and not in the Prisoner of Azkaban sense, but in the Back to the Future, Part 2 sense. A secret love child for Voldemort, which is a plot device so utterly ridiculous I nearly chucked the book across the room. There is nothing, NOTHING of the magic of the real Harry Potter books.

I really don't care if this is technically "canon" or not. It's not for me. It is truly wretched and I wish I had never read it.

author: Amazon Customer
title: The trolley witch does what?
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2016
content:
Nothing about this book reflected a shred of the character growth Jo built with her beloved characters since our first trip to Hogwarts with the Sorcerer's Stone.

I have been trying to articulate just how upset I am but it ends up being a long rambling of "AND THEN THIS happend, but that wouldn't happen because of THIS and WHY would ______ do THAT?"

It hurts me that I didn't like it. Part of me thought "am I just old now? would third grade me like this?", but no. I think third grade me would also feel cheated. Part of me thought "maybe this doesn't translate well in a book? maybe in the play it makes more sense?" but I just don't see how that would be true.

I chalk this up to fan fiction, but even that is upsetting because I have read much better fan fiction. Knowing Jo accepts this as canon is unsettling to me. I don't know about your but I am purging this from my memory. It ended nineteen years later. But then again, I was even critical of that. It felt cheesy.

These two were so, so, so, so, lucky to have this opportunity and blessing from Jo to help continue the story and I feel they were careless. Eternally bummed.

title: Like so many others
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2016
content: Like so many others, I really wanted to like this. Really. Yes, I knew it was a play and got over the fact that there wouldn't be any descriptions of settings or thoughts. I knew I wouldn't get lost in it as I had the novels. But this is totally unacceptable. There is no character development.  There is little consistency. The plot is lumpy and disjointed. I don't feel like I know anyone even though I know almost every character very well. She should have just written a new novel - it would have been more satisfying for everyone (probably her as well). Not to put too fine a point on it, but this sucks.

author: JAK
title: Harry Potter and the Cursed Child - an abomination not deserving of being named the "8th Book"
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: I'd give this cheesy bit of silly fan fiction zero stars if that were an option. If J K Rowling really had a hand in this, then she's sold out because this is so bad, so camp, so UN -Potter, it's unbelievable. I don't mind that it's a play script; that's fine and doesn't interfere in any way.  But the "plot" isn't a celebration of magic, it's a mess; the machinations of a mind not in tune with the Potter world at all.  One gets the impression that this Jack What's-His-Name - the "creator"- never read the books and either doesn't care for the Potter characters or resents Rowling's creativity and success because he seems to delight in twisting the characters as we've known them into unrecognizablely silly plot devises.  As I said - this is nothing more than fan fiction, and poorly written at that. This reads more like the literary attempts of a 14 year old fan girl.  A best seller?  Of course - because Potter fans were cynically manipulated into expecting something vetted by Rowling to be quality.  Instead we got ripped off by a piece of crap using the names of characters we love.  Fooled us once, Ms Rowling, but it won't happen twice. You owe us a sincere apology.

content:

content: If I could give it no stars I would! What a waste of time and money! I realize this was supposedly written in the same vein as Rowling. But this is nothing like JK Rowling!  The characters were all pathetic and completely out of sync with their personalities in the original books. I didn't find anything to make me like this. And being written as a script had nothing to do with my dislike.  The story (what there was of one) dragged on like a sore tooth and I had to force myself to finish it. content: This book was NOT written by JK Rowling, it just borrowed her name for the cover. Rowling herself is a master wordsmith, but this script written by Jack Thorne reads like cheap fanfiction. The plot is lackluster, the dialogue is out of character, and the language is overly simple.

author: Deborah Gimbel
title: A nightmare come true
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2019
content:
My step-daughter offered to let me read her copy of this. Huge mistake on my part.

I used to have nightmares as a child that I was reading my favorite book of all time, Lord of the Rings, and in the dream I was horrified to find that what I was reading was some horribly written, pale imitation of the story I so loved. I would wake up nearly in tears. Alas, my dream has actually come true with this story, a horribly written, pale imitation of the HP universe I so love. Do yourself a favor and don't sully your love of all that is HP with this money-grabbing tripe...stick to the books ACTUALLY written by Rowling.

author: roogirl

author: Charlotte
title: "Do not pity the dead, Harry. Pity the living, and, above all pity those who read Harry Potter and the Cursed Child.”
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
Spoilers!!

Huge Harry Potter fan-- 16 years of reading!! So I was incredibly excited for the new one. I keep wondering if there's a therapy group where all the disgruntled fans can congragate and weep together. I'm also refusing to consider in cannon as it was not JKR herself who penned.  What they did to the INTEGRITY of these characters. I'm sick over it.  The entire 7 book series was about friendship, love and loyalty, and Harry knew that; and most importantly, knew that's what made him different from V. You're telling me, he, Ron and Herm  didn't continue to live and instil those values in their children? Rose was a bully, who was prejudice against someone without knowing them first.  Harry would never said he wished his kid wasn't his, or sacrificed his kid's only friendship over gosip. Harry wouldn't have choosen work over time with his family, which after all he'd been through WAS ALL HE EVER WANTED.

If someone were to ask me, what is your favorite thing about Harry Potter?, I would hands down reply: Harry Potter's moral integrity, that is the heart of the series. It's his choosing to sacrifice himself for what is good. It's choosing friendship over suspicion. It's a defiant effort to turn towards the pain of loving and losing, then choosing not to love at all. It's choosing to do what right, and best for others even when it hurts, is inconvenient, or scary. It's fighting for truth and justice, even when you're the only one doing it.  And when you move away from those central themes, the integrity of who we know Harry (and friends) to have PROVEN himself to be, you destroy Harry Potter and all that he stood for for 7 books.  This new book is the worst kind of trash, the one that destroys the soul of our hero.

Also, what they did to calm, measured, quirky, wise Dumbledore, making him a weepy, rude mess, who spoke in cliches, issuing a completely unnecessary "apology" to why Harry was at the Dursleys, when Dumbledore had already apologized profusely for that in HP5 AND severely told off the Dursleys in HP6 for their abusive behavior! It was just phony emotional porn!

  And Ron's a proper idiot who got drunk during his wedding?! He would have never disrespected Hermione like that. Hermione was neither clever, nor charming; she didn't come up with hardly any solutions. And what a weak, floppy mess Harry was during the fight scene?! His 16 year old self could have fought better. It's like they sucked the soul out of the books, like a dementor wrote it!! This is not even pointing out the horrible plot holes! No, I refuse this book is real. It's a bloody mess!

author: JonKear
title: Opportunism at its finest.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content: This was pretty bad, and for what it's worth it doesn't have anything to do with the script format of the book. It's the story, the story is absolutely vapid, and were it not for its title it would have been discarded among the throng of shameful attempts at engaging storytelling. The plot is centered around time travel, quite possibly the most cringeworthy storyline cliché imaginable and completely passes over the essence of the series in the first place. Throughout the first few acts the reader is constantly being jerked around in a half-assed attempt to catch them up to speed, and the sparse snapshots of life that we are shown do little to rival the sentiment of merely watching an episode of Full House. I'm thoroughly convinced that anybody who rushes to the defense of this book is so intransigently entrenched in fandom that they couldn't work past the guilt of having grown up with Harry Potter to even consider slandering this abomination to an incredible series. I can't help but think that this shoehorned hardback is opportunism at its finest.

content: I have never been so disappointed. I knew it was a play, I knew it would be shorter. I had no trouble following the plot. I'm still incredibly disappointed that this piece of Fanfiction, poorly written and planned fiction at that, is being passed off as canon. I will never accept it as such. The entire plot amounts to several instances of deus ex machina. I liked Albus and Scorpius, I loved the Draco Malfoy saw redemption as a good father. But these characters are nothing like the ones in the epilogue of Deathly Hallows. I've waited to review this book because I loved the series so much. I have the books in two languages and have read them multiple times in each. I started collecting the illustrated versions, too. If I am forced to accept this as canon, though, that enjoyment is tainted and I don't think I'll ever go back to being the fan that I was. I mean, did we really need that ridiculousness with the trolley witch?

author: Abby
title: I loved the original Harry Potter books
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
Expectations were high. I loved the original Harry Potter books, and I even thought The Casual Vacancy and the Galbraith books were pretty good.

Unfortunately, this reads like bad fanfiction. My favorite characters appeared in name only, with none of the depth, charm or interesting dynamics that made the original Potter books so compelling.

Perhaps the lack of character development could have been saved by an interesting plot, but the Cursed Child lacks that as well. The storyline is driven by how growing up in the shadow of his father, Harry Potter, makes Albus Potter a dark and tortured soul. Although Albus' siblings seem perfectly well adjusted (basically mini-Fred and mini-Ginny), Albus suffers from ANGST, causing him to pull incredibly stupid stunts that advance the plot in the absence of any logic or reason.

Clever, creative world building could have possibly saved this illogical story with flat, annoying characters. And yet the writers fail to add any dimensions to the HP Universe, instead using old set pieces (that I used to know and love) in ways that make no sense while simultaneously sucking all the whimsy and wonder out of Magical Britain.

If you would like to read Harry Potter fanfiction, I recommend hpmor.com instead.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Horrible. Disappointing. Embarrassing for J.K. Rowling!
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2016
content: I'll start by saying that I'm in the camp of people who knew this was a script of the play, not an actual book. That having been said, this "play" is absolutely horrible. My main thought while reading this was "Did Rowling even READ this drivel before she signed off on it?" There are several inconsistencies with the original story and characters, and don't even get me started on the odd phrases that the original characters would have never used, such as Ludo Bagman. "Krazy Krum??" "Delicious Diggory??" The Ludo Bagman we know was jovial and slightly immoral, but never that ridiculous. Ludo isn't the only problem; none of the characters were true to themselves, and they were even unrecognizable in some ways.There are parts that are mildly entertaining, but nearly enough to redeem itself. On the whole, I simply cannot believe that J.K. Rowling allowed her name to be associated with what basically amounts to glorified fanfiction - and not even particularly good fanfiction, either.

author: Broken_Harlequin
title: Less Soul than a Horcrux
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2016
content:
Unforgivable. If Harry Potter and the Cursed Child had been marketed as a work of fan fiction inspired by the series, I would probably be generous enough to give it a second star. I, like most reviewers here, love all things Harry, after all. Or thought I did. No, what is truly unforgivable about Cursed Child is the fact that it is marketed as official canon.

SPOILERSSPOILERSSPOILERS

Now on to what passes for a plot. The main plot device revolves around time-turners- something that is difficult to pull off well in the first place. JK's original conception of a closed time loop, which helped to make Prisinor of Askaban such a great, tight story, is completely absent here. Instead, Albus and Scorpius go back in time and change the present as a result. Not only does this leave gaping plot holes as far as the eye can see, but it seems like nothing but a poor ploy to bring back dead characters in alternate universes. There are so many original stories that could have been constructed around the Harry Potter universe. But instead we have to suffer through hackneyed cliches that would make a 14 year old cringe. Obviously, this would all be more impressive on the stage, rather than in script format, but the fact that the writers were willing to sacrifice characters and plot for cheap thrills, shows that little respect remains for the fans and what originally made Rowling's books so magical.

This leads me into what was, for me, the worst aspect of the story of all. The characters are completelely one-dimensional and lifeless. They seem like parodies of their former selves. Real emotion is sacrificed on the altar of cheap expressions and woeful writing. It reads like a bad soap opera. Like a terrible cover of your favourite song. Albus and Scorpius are the least egregious, through virtue of their being new characters not explored at length in the canon. Harry, Ron and Hermione are shallow. Dumbledore, instead of wise and magical, is a weeping mess. Haven't the writers heard that 'less is more?'.

Finally, this brings me to the climax of this hot mess. Voledmort's child. No. Just no. This is a plot device so cliched it should make anyone cringe. Also, the logistics make zero sense. Negative sense. Are we really supposed to believe that Voldemort and Bellatrix had time to make a child during the Battle or Hogwarts? Of all the devices they could have come up with, it would be almost impossible to conceive of something as half-baked as this. It's like a bad sequel, but worse.

I don't know what I should have expected. I knew this was a play, I knew it could almost certainly never be as good as the original series, but nothing could have prepared me for this monstrosity. Again, if it was not passed off as canon, I would probably have had a chuckle at it before trying to expunge it from my memory. But as it is, it's unforgivable. Fortunately someone bought it as a present for me, so at least I saved my thirty dollars. But I also can't know the satisfaction of tearing it to pieces. Honestly, there's MUCH better fan fiction to be found out there, by people who are loyal to the spirit of the canon. But Harry Potter and the Cursed Child is flash with no meaning. A cash grab with less soul than a Horcrux.

author: That one really harsh critic
title: belongs in the ouat and Harry crossovers section of fanfiction.net
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
I am not kidding here. I thought this seemed an awful lot like one of those time travel/alternate universe episodes of once upon a time. Like they decided to do a Harry Potter and once upon a time crossover fanfiction.

To begin with, Harry and Draco are friends just like Snow White and Regina (evil queen)  become friends on ouat. Except that relationship had at least two seasons to develop before Regina finally decided to ditch her grudge with Snow White, charming, and Emma. This just comes out of nowhere. It could work if we had a story about draco's official redemption (I think there were several moments in the original series where we saw potential for Draco to break away from the death eater crowd).

THEN THE VILLAINESS' PARENTAGE IS REVELAED AND MY SUSPICIONS WERE CONFIRMED THAT THEY MAY HAVE TAKEN ZELENA TOO!!!

The plot is pretty much the same as season 3b of once upon a time. The villainess' goal is to get back in time to prevent her father (Voldemort, who she has never met) from being killed by Harry Potter. When we first see her, she is disguising herself as Cedric Digory 's cousin and appears innocent just as Zelena the wicked witch of the west disguised herself as a midwife to get close to the heroes. On that show zelena wants  to go back in time to prevent her mother from giving her up. And reek havoc on the hero's lives!!!!

And Cora was The Dark One's best student and the creators have left open ended as to weather or not rumple is regina's real father. Apparently the Dark Lord had a child with his most loyal follower.

author: K
title: Don't buy even for your worst enemy, it is truly that bad
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: If you are into recycled plot lines with new characters added, this is the book for you. This play is one of the worst pieces of literature that I have ever read. I am, like a lot of the world, a huge Harry Potter fan and this book is more along the lines of fan fiction. Badly written, unimaginative, poorly constructed fan fiction, to be exact. It is too bad that the story couldn't have just ended in a dignified manner, instead of the characters' children being dragged through the mud and the same magical and juvenile mistakes explored again and again. The book beats one over the head with the dangers of time travel, which again is not a new concept in fiction. Anyone with any literary knowledge knows that if you step on a butterfly things will be different when you return. I recommend the book to absolutely no one. What a gigantic waste of time. If I could I would return the book as it is broken. It demeans and limits the characters from Harry Potter, they are washed out to be caricatures of their former selves. I was giving it my all and trying to remain objective until I got to the poly juice potion, a repetitive element from the original stories that it is no longer original.  I am surprised that Rowling lent her name and endorsement to this endeavor. Unless the stage show is along the lines of the Lion King in spectacle it must be a grueling two day experience. We are used to something new and fantastic from the mind of JK Rowling and the newest eighth book (what a bad choice of description) verifies that the imagination and storytelling of Rowling is not anywhere near what is offered between the pages of this play. Such a sad last attempt at glory for the Harry Potter series.

Now she tries to stay relevant by grabbing on to the last thing that made her famous.
The story is subpar with nothing new to people used to time travel stories. Given that it's a screenplay, it's filled with even more unnecessary words describing scene transitions. While it introduces new characters and plays with a few old ones, they do little to make me care about any of them. Avoid wasting your money on this. Give the old ones another read instead.
