content: This is not what I was expecting at all. Going in I assumed this was written by J.K Rowling, but from reading could glean fairly early Rowling didn't write it. The characters seemed off in general and their interactions with one another didn't fit their characters. Ultimately not knowing someone else wrote it was my own fault, but to be fair her name is rather distinct under the title and it was advertised as the eight story. (It even says so on the back cover.) Anyway, that all aside I still planned on enjoying the script for what it was, a story written by not J.K. Rowling and not a perfect representation of all of the beloved characters from the original books, but still a good story. Nope. The plot is garbage. If you take just a minute to think about it, it makes no sense in the context of the universe that was created. The new characters don't have many, if any redeeming qualities to them and the fact that the villain even exists makes me want to strangle someone! The entire story angers me deeply and thoroughly. Unfortunately, in the end it's a half baked idea that reads more like bad fan fiction. If you are a fan of the original stories avoid this like the plague. How on earth could Rowling have O.K.'ed this story? Ugh!

author: AF
title: I wish this could have been better
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 7, 2016
content:
Let me start by saying this is not a Harry Potter. If you want to read this book to rekindle the  Harry Potter love dont. It will make you hate HP. It is gut wrenching for me to be writing this but I need to get the word out.
Some of the sentences such as (For volemort and valour) and ( Thank dumbledore) make me cringe they really do.

SPOILERS AHEAD.......
I really dont understand the whole bellatrix voldemort thing. When was she pregnant with the dark lords child? And where was George and Hugo? What is going on? I hope they dont make another book because this was a major disapointment  I am sorry but Jk did not write this
. Do not buy this book. You are better off with the old books. It hurts me to write this review but I feel that I have to save you all the money.

author: Amazon Customer
title: What!?!???
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
When I got this book I thought the worst problem would it was a script and not an actual book... But no the whole story was a problem.
It breaks my heart as a HUGE Harry Potter fan that I have to give this a bad review but I simply can't give it a good one.
I don't know why jk Rowling would but her name on this was it for the money!??? Because this is NOT her work
The characters are not even close to who they are and the new charters are underdeveloped. * small spoiler* but what's up with Dumbledores!!??? He was uncharacteristically emotional and the same thing with harry after all harry has been through and lost he whined and cried more in this one story then in all seven books and Snape!???? I liked the idea of seeing Snape again but sadly it wasn't anything like Snape he was just to nice and to open feeling *spoiler end*
I'm the kind of person that can't predict what will happen next even when mostly everyone else can but in this story I could what going to happen every few pages the plot just sucked after JK Rowling spent so much time and effort in the other 7 books and connected every detail so well it's a insult to call this the 8th book the only thing I liked was the idea of some parts of the and that's it. I really hope the play made this script seem much better but otherwise it's just a way to make money sorry JK Rowling no matter how much I love you and your stories this was just a joke

author: Laura
title: Yuck!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2016
content:
Bought it in Costco. Super excited to finally have some more Harry Potter, since i grew up with the series, and absolutely loved it. That said, the Cursed Child was a complete and abject disappointment. It reads like a bad fanfiction, and the characters have been completely butchered.

Harry is an obnoxious helicopter parent, resembling Lucius Malfoy way to much for my comfort, and repeatedly putting down McGonagall and Dumbledore because they never had kids.

Wtf? These people practically raised you, you twit! And McGonagall just sits there and passively takes his s***?! Nah-ah, the Minerva we all know would have put him in his place.

And of course, the main blunder *SPOILER* Voldy and Bellatrix's baby.. WTF? Where was this baby while DH was going on? Was she about to pop while torturing Hermione? No one noticed? Or was she torturing Hermione while caressing a big ol' belly?

And if she was sooo obsessed with Voldy, why wouldn't she stay back and guard his kid? Why wouldn't V want to protect his legacy (and potential horcrux)?

Finally, Delphy's convoluted plot to off Harry makes no sense. Cedric is insignificant in the scheme of things. Go back and kill Lily as a kid. Go back and kill James at school. Go back and convince V not to try to kill Harry, but rather adopt it him. Soooo many alternatives.

The only redeeming element was Scorpius, since he was pretty funny. Other than that, the book is garbage. No matter what JK says, this junk will not be part of the HP canon in my head.

Final score: Yuck.

So many scenes and conversations from the book are directly contradicted in this script (like Harry "never having told anyone he was almost sorted into Slyherin"). Huge waste of time and emotion. I'm going to go eat some ice cream and try to forget this ever happened.

author: Jessica
title: Beyond disappointing
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 23, 2016
content:
Another disappointed HP fan here.
I grew up loving these books. It is beyond a doubt my favorite book series. I have worshiped JK Rowling for most of my life, I even have a HP tattoo. But what she has done here has broken my heart. I can look past the script aspect of this book, but the plot is absolutely not realistic. There are dozens, and DOZENS of plot holes that I will not go into for the sake of not spoiling whoever might be reading this. I cannot tell you how sad I am that JK Rowling had anything to do with this. I purchased tickets to see this play in London next year. I spent hundreds of dollars on these tickets, and will likely be selling them and cancelling our trip. There is no way that I can justify spending hours of my time on this nonsense, let alone flying halfway across the world to see the play in person.

author: Laura
title: Oof! I felt this one right in the childhood.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
content: Oh my lord this is bad. I walked into this realizing that the book was not written by JK Rowling and as such would be different in tone, but this was honestly not good. I, like everyone else here, have read all the Harry Potter books and am an avid fan, so when I saw an 8th book was coming out to expand on the short epilogue, I was obviously excited. One page in I already knew that this was not going to be what I expected. The dialogue between the characters was awkward and stunted, the jokes were painful, and the way the writer worded some actions just didn't make sense. For example, can we talk about this line? "The Sorting Hat walks through the students, who spring into their houses". Since when does the Sorting Hat walk around? I haven't even mentioned how odd Ron is in this book. He cracks Dad jokes and pranks people, which would be fine if he was George or even Mr. Weasley, but Ron had never struck me as the dad jokes and running a joke shop guy. Everything just feels wrong. There was even a line in there about Professor McGonagall walking around with a large smile on her face. Since when is Professor McGonagall a cheery, wide-smile kind of lady? There just seem to be inconsistencies all over the place. I really don't understand how this got published and to call it the 8th book in the series is just a crying shame.

author: Ron in Arkansas
title: Great disappointment
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content:
I forced myself to finish this so that I could, in good conscience, write this review.  The following comments are my own opinion.
Edgar Rice Burroughs beginning writing Tarzan, John Carter of Mars, At the Earth's Core, etc. when, as a struggling salesman, he read the serial novels in magazines, and said, "I can write something this bad!"  This is how I feel about the HP and the Cursed Child script - even I could have written something this terrible!  The characters were one dimensional distortions of the ones we know form the HP novels, the dialogue was shallow and insufferable, and the plot entirely predictable given the THOUSANDS of previous works dealing with the consequences of time travel.  There is absolutely nothing original here, and it has all been done, and better done, by many, many others.  It was terribly boring, and I found myself wondering if the writer(s) were paid by the word, because it was the "script that would not die!"  I thought it would never end!  I couldn't stand it, and I don't know how JKR would have allowed her name to appear on it.  The entire story deserved 30 pages or less for the entire plot (a very weak one) to have been written, and, frankly, I think should have never been written.

The "magic" was all a re-do of prior stuff all mashed up and contrived.  The characters were NOT the ones from the novels.  The story line was a boring re-do of countless time travel stories.  The plot moved forward at the speed of a receding glacier.  I only wish I could sell my Kindle version at a used book store, but, alas, I can't, and can only delete from my devices.

While I have some hope for the upcoming movie, I"m canceling my pre-order of the script.  I've learned my lesson!

author: Jeff Paulus
title: An awful conclusion to my favorite childhood book series
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2018
content:
This novel ruined a lot of the Harry Potter canon I grew up to know and love.  The characters have become completely foreign to me - I do not recognize them.  I despised Harry's son Albus, he seemed to be a largely annoying, whiny brat, who has far less sense than Harry did on his worst day.  Ron has become nothing more than a bumbling comic relief stooge.  On the whole, the book felt incredibly cheesy, made me cringe, and I had to struggle to finish it.

In my mind, despite what J.K. Rowling says, the Harry Potter series ended with the seventh book.  Can anyone hit me with an 'Obliviate' memory spell because I'd love to forget about ever reading this.

author: BellaNova
title: I really wanted to like it.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2016
content:
How could you allow this J?
I love J.K. Rowling and the Harry Potter series. What she did was nothing short of masterful. Those books were fleshed out to the point of being real, feeling real. Every damn sentence had a purpose, a meaning, lead to a bigger picture. This...felt nothing short of a cheap knock off. Honestly, if Cursed Child had been released as a fanfic or an side story, it would have been okay but...I just cannot believe she would release this haphazard mess as cannon.
I grew up with these characters, I know them well. Cursed Child did not include any of the characters I remember from the original series, at best I would call them mere shadows of their formal selves. Where is Ginny's spark? What happened to Harry's bravery and true heart? Why is Hermione so bumbling now? Where is Ron's everything? (Seriously though, what the hell happened to Ron?) And don't even get me started on Dumbledore.
I knew things would feel different in this book being based on a screen play but I at least expected the dialog to be on point, but no. There were many times the characters would 'say' things that made everything J.K. did in the way of world and character building crumble.  Plus that prophecy? Did a 5 year old write it? All of these problems just chip away at the plots' integrity until we are left with a shoddy fanfic written by someone who was under qualified and over imaginative.
The one shining star in the whole novel was Scorpius Malfoy-obviously they put the most of their effort into him and his character but that is unacceptable when you are writing in the world of Harry Potter.
To people on the fence about whether or not you should read it allow me to give you this one piece of advice, If I could, I would go back and not read it. The sour taste it left is very hard to swallow.  However, I had to read it-bad reviews and all.
Let me be clear-I did not like this; could not like this book because of how much I loved the original series. Having read this feels like I cheated on a perfect relationship and spoilt all the good it brought me.So, my plan is to forget about this book as soon as possible before it becomes a permanent dark stain on a otherwise perfect world.

author: Brad Eason
title: Not Potter
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 11, 2017
content: I refuse to acknowledge this as part of the Potter universe. It reads like a play made up by 7-year-olds. The more you think about the plot and characters, the more you realize this contradicts the amazing world Rowling crafted. I'm not sure why she decided to give this her blessing (she did not write it).

To make more MONEY........  this has to be the ONLY reason because who in their right mind could possibly think anyone would enjoy reading this rubbish .....  it's bloody awful and we've ALL been betrayed and suckered in !!!!!! Everyone involved is laughing all the way to the bank ......

I HOPE J.K. Rowling reads these reviews. I want her to know that we know she sold us out..... I want her to know how disappointed we are ....

content: This play is so far removed from the nature of the characters developed by JK Rowling in the original book series that I couldn't finish reading. It was honestly that bad. Bottom line: you are better off not reading this, don't corrupt your memory of these beloved characters with this garbage.

It is a play script, and reads as such, but the problem is the story itself.  Suspension of disbelief is just impossible.  Very disappointed and will be when they make it movie as well.

author: greenplace
title: Not canon
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2016
content: It's not canon-compliant, and the writing quality is not good. I understand why people who haven't read the books more than once might enjoy it, and that it must be an amazing play, but the story should have never been announced as canon. Maybe I'm bitter. But don't spend money on it if you're a diehard fan--the story will just break your heart, and not in a good way.

author: Jonas Bronstein
title: This isn't Harry Potter.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2016
content:
Everyone's personality changed - and not for the better.

Gaping plot holes for the most significant story element destroy the basis for a good story.

As a huge Harry Potter nut - I've read all the books multiple times, including many fanfics like Harry Potter and the Methods of Rationality (which is an excellent series written as if Harry was a genius, and last I checked the #1 fanfic)...I don't take "Cursed Child" as official HP canon. I take it as an experiment, and hope the money it raised supported good charities. Hopefully, if she's not under too strict of a contract, JK can fix this affront to her beloved series in the future.

author: Amazon Customer
title: But after reading page after page my excitement started to turn dull, and I couldn't feel the vibe I usually ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
SPOILERS! BE WARNED!

When first introduced to the Harry Potter series, I really thought nothing of it-literaly- , that the amount of fame it had gotten at the time was, well, crazy.
 But after reading  even the first few pages I instantly got hooked and have adored the series ever since then.
Now when I heard a few months prior to the opening date that there was a new Harry Potter book, I was just thrilled!
But after reading page after page my excitement started to turn dull, and I couldn't feel the vibe I usually felt when opening up one of J.K Rowling's HP books.
Of course, I kept in mind that it wasn't the original author who wrote this book, and that was probably the biggest problem about this book.
Even if you bring in the seemingly best writer in the world to continue a book, there will most certainly be a change in the atmosphere of the book.
Harry Potter, the one thing in the world he wanted was a family, and he can't give up ministry work time to spend time with the only one he has now?
Hermione and Ron's daughter, Rose, judging a 'book by its cover' before even knowing the person.
That's not what either the parents would ever teach their children.
Look, the format of this book was 'alright'- a bit kidish to me- but I am only saying it was alright solely because of Snape.
But the characters weren't really truly there.
I felt as though throughout the whole book everything was monotone, just a robot talking, and that- as weird as it is to say- did break my heart a bit that these wonderful characters were wasted.
There was no joyful, scary, sinister, homey, evil, and AMAZING feeling in this book at all. But I need, really really need J.K Rowling to rewrite this herself.
No shade on the two new authors, but you can't just write someone else's book without making it your own, and not everyone wants that..
Hope this was alright.

content:

author: Indigo Bunting
title: Like Ginny. She's a total blank
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
First major problem: it's a therapy novel. (Except it's a play.) It's not action, it's not "showing" instead of "telling," it's ridiculous quantities of self-reflective psychologist couch language between all the characters, including between the teenagers, and all of it utterly unconvincing.
Second major problem: the characters are either caricatures of their former selves extended into the future, or have no personality at all. Like Ginny. She's a total blank. Ron is a fool. Scorpius came closest to having a personality, but he kept talking in therapist-chair sentences (see First major problem, above).
Third major problem: Stupid story line. I figured out ages ago that J. K. Rowling engineered the destruction of all the Time-Turners at the end of HP5 precisely in order to avoid getting stuck in the endless tedium of time travel stories. There are contradictions in this one, like all time travel stories, but ultimately what made it so irritating is that it was just a way to re-engineer the old drama of Voldemort. Seriously? Couldn't think of *anything* else to tell a story about in the magical world?
Ugh.

author: Lightfinger
title: An Out-Of-Character mess with an overly-complicated plot and very little heart
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2016
content:
As someone with a Harry Potter tattoo, I'd say I'm a pretty big fan of the series. So that makes me all the more disappointed in this play. While I understand that, as a play, it's meant to be performed, and some of the nuance might be lost in translation, the flaws are too dramatic to be excused like that. All our beloved characters, Harry, Hermione, Ron...they're all horribly out of character. And OTHER beloved characters (Neville, Luna, George, Teddy, to name a few) are completely missing. The plot is convoluted and overwrought, the big "reveal" is extremely obvious from very early on, and to be honest, the story is just...bad.

I wanted this play to be the heart-wrenching tale of a son trying desperately to connect to a father that he can't understand, the story of a father who is trying to come to terms with both his horrible past and the fact that his son seems to be the very antithesis of him. I wanted this story to be HUMAN, even though it's set in a magical world.

What I got was a story that is too caught up in its own magical setting to remember that a good story should ALWAYS be driven by the characters within it.

If you're a Harry Potter fan, feel free to get this book to complete your Harry Potter shelf of books. But don't go into it expecting to learn anything new about the Wizarding World that you fell in love with all those years ago. This play reads like poorly written fanfiction. Feel free to skip it.

content: I'm a big fan and this falls very short of Rowlings other books. Very disappointed. It was annoying and confusing to read... yes its a theater script and I know how to read those... this was terrible. I can see where Special Effects on stage in London could make this more appealing...this story NEEDS it! But as a book its flat, dull, illogical, whiny, bitter, depressing, old-hat, and where the plot does advance... its very rote and predictable. Reads as if someone else whose extremely amateur wrote it, not Rowling. Poor choices all through it... I literally stopped reading it halfway through... it just kept getting worse and worse and worse.  I am very sad for Rowling on this project... she can do so much better.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Complete and Utter Sh!t...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
I would highly recommend not spending your money on Harry Potter and the Cursed Child. If you are a fan of the Harry Potter series, in love with its rich characters and skillfully woven plot, this book will be nothing but a disappointment to you, as it certainly was for me. The magic is absent and the wit is nonexistent, and I often found myself staring in disbelief at the, frankly, absurd and bizarre, things that were happening. For specifics, read below, but fair warning, there are many spoilers.

From the first few pages even, you begin to get an inkling of its strangeness, of its total detachment from the world we all know and love, the world that was painstakingly crafted, with love and care, throughout the seven Harry Potter books. The Cursed Child holds none of that care -- in fact, it’s carelessly written, nonsensical, bizarre. The plot is an unbelievable mess, filled with gaping holes. The old characters are shadows of their former selves, so badly written that you begin to wonder if Jack Thorne gave the series anything more than a cursory glance before penning the monstrosity that is Ron’s characterization. Seriously. What the hell was that. The new characters are nowhere near interesting enough for us to even feign interest in them as people -- they’re one dimensional, walking cliches. Speaking of cliches, The Cursed Child overflows with them, exploring such contrived ideas such as “What if Cedric Diggory never died?” or “What if time-turners basically functioned like time machines?” or “What if Voldemort had a daughter with Bellatrix Lestrange?” Yes, you read that correctly. Said daughter is Delphi, our new antagonist, a quirky twenty-something that Albus Potter has the hots for, despite the fact that he’s...fourteen? The characters often know too much about the events that occurred within the series, to the extent that Albus or Amos Diggory can confidently recite the exact dialogue of an event that happened over twenty years ago. Essentially, Harry Potter and the Cursed Child reads like bad fanfiction. Really bad fanfiction. If I hadn’t read it in a hardcover book that’s already sold millions of copies (regrettably), I would’ve assumed that The Cursed Child had been penned by a preteen Harry Potter fan, upset by “smexy” Cedric’s death and an unabashed shipper of Voldemort x Bellatrix. The fact that the screenplay was really written by a grown man, and given the a-ok by Rowling herself, is incredibly bewildering. Additionally, the whole business with the trolley witch? Three words. What. The. Hell.

content: When I received this book I flipped to the end to see how many pages long it was as I do with all books. The blank full and part pages and the short lines turn this 308 page book into about 100. Hate the format, have never read a play before and doubt I ever will again. Plot line foolish.  I'm a 70 female that has read all the books at least twice and listened to them on audio books of which I have the full set . A sorrowful end to a wonderful series.

author: Gabby
title: No. Just, no.
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2017
content: Absolute rubbish. JKR, why did you put your name on this and taint everyone's imagination with this "canon"?

author: lightsyouonfire
title: Ug!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
I made the mistake of rereading the original series immediately before reading this.  Mistake number one.

I purchased this book/script after being on the fence about it for months.  Mistake number two.

I read the many disappointed reviews and still spent money on it.  Mistake number three.

That said.  I'm sure the play itself really helps in covering up the rickety story line and many gaping plot holes.  I'd imagine the play is perfectly enjoyable to watch.  This, however was so disappointing to read.  And that's coming from a huge Harry Potter AND time travel fantasy fan.  Our beloved characters acted so far out of character throughout.  The story jumps several years in a single bound.  Everything is incredibly forced (relationships, personality traits, conversations) and doesn't sound like Rowling at all!

If you must buy this, I recommend reading only after its been a good year since you read the original 7 books.  That way you have a decent opportunity to forget as much as possible about the original story and don't compare the new story too closely with the originals.  I hated the last chapter of the 7th book for how forced and out of character it was, and this book was exactly the same.

And, if you're looking for a great fanfic, check out the James Potter series by G. Norman Lippert.

author: kaitward
title: EXTREMELY disappointing - contains spoilers.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
content:
Huge Harry Potter nerd here. Simply seeing a piece of artwork involving Harry Potter can send me into tears. Met my husband in a Harry Potter chatroom. Have read all the books MULTIPLE times each, etc etc. I am a HUGE fan.

J.K. Rowling has disappointed me a couple of times since the last book came out (mostly when she said Hermione and Ron should not have ended up together), but I will say this is the single biggest disappointment. I know she didn't write it - but the fact that she endorses it, and that I am to take it as canon, is frankly sickening.

Time for me to get spoiler-y:

***********SPOILERS***********

The characters were SO OUT OF CHARACTER. I could believe Harry having struggles with fatherhood due to the fact that his was dead. However, telling Albus he wished he wasn't his son? No. Never. Those words would not come out of Harry's mouth, not matter how provoked. Rose being prejudiced towards Scorpius? ROSE WEASLEY, the spawn of Ron and Hermione? They would have taught her to NEVER judge based on house, I feel that she would never behave like that, shunning her own cousin just because he wanted to be friends with Scorpius. You're trying to tell me Draco Malfoy would be okay with his son befriending a Potter, and would have taught his son as much, but Hermione/Ron did not pass this along to Rose? Hermione was not her normal witty self, Ron did at least have some humorous moments - but Harry was just so off. Shunning family for work, telling Albus he couldn't be friends with Scorpius, his BEST FRIEND. That is something Harry would NEVER do. He knows the importance of friendship more than anyone! That is practically the whole point of the books. I just don't believe it.

Don't get me started on Voldemort having a daughter... He was never the type to be interested in procreating. I guess I could look over this, maybe he wanted to pass on his name, WHATEVER, but the fact that she is just kept hidden for years, and reemerges as Amos Diggory's nurse... why wasn't Harry's scar hurting the whole time? Why did he just now start to feel her presence? Why on earth would she choose to save Cedric in order to save Voldemort?! There are so many other ways she could have done that, much CLEANER ways, that perhaps wouldn't spawn a million different alternate timelines. And the time turner.. not even freaking canon, although I guess now I am supposed to consider it canon - going back in time as much as you want apparently, not to mention all of the things that doing that would change, and the fact that some people even had problems with how the third book handled messing with time. WHY CHOOSE THAT AS A PLOT? It's so hard to believe even when done properly. There are INFINITE other possibilities (as many other, BETTER fan fictions have explored). They could have done such great things with the story of Harry's kids. Instead they did this.

And Cedric becoming a death eater? Because he got humiliated at the triwizard tournament? HAS THE AUTHOR EVEN READ HARRY POTTER? Cedric was a purely GOOD human being, he would NEVER go to the dark side, especially over something so trivial. I don't even know if Cedric had the ability to feel humiliation, he was so confident in himself and his abilities. The fact that the entire plot of the book rests on him becoming a death eater like that is so ridiculous, it makes me sick to my stomach. He would've made a joke out of it and moved on, he didn't care if he won the tournament. I cannot believe this book was allowed to exist.

There were a very few select moments that I did enjoy. The flash of Hagrid as he picked Harry up out from Godric's Hollow (but, then again, anything involving Hagrid makes me melt). The fact that Albus was sorted into Slytherin was great, and the fact that Scorpius had a crush on Rose was great as well. Hermione being Minister of magic has long been my head canon. I admit I did shed some tears when Harry watched his parent's die, but only because that's a sad moment from the actual books. I don't like that he was there to witness it, along with all his friends and Draco. He saw it in his dreams, that should've been enough. There were some funny moments, mostly from Ron or Scorpius, but other than that, I really find nothing redeemable.

So, so disappointed.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Very average

content:

author: britany
title: Still waiting for the 8th HP Story
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
After waiting years and years for a new Harry Potter story, this could not have been more disappointing. I was fine with the play format, and to be fair I'm sure the play is fantastic, but on paper this story has no heart.

I don't know who those characters were, but they were not Harry, Ron and Hermonie. Don't even get me started on Snape. They did not retain one iota of his complex, dry personality. To me, that was the most unforgivable part of this whole endeavor. Why bring a character back just to disrespect him like that?

There were also major issues with the plot. Tacky soap opera twists, lazy plot holes and just a bad storyline altogether. I am disappionted in JK Rowling for lending her name to this and hope she can find a way to somehow repay true Harry Potter fans.

author: Readitandwept
title: JK's name on the book is misleading
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
Just...cringe-worthy.

First of all, it IS not written like a book because IT WASNT MEANT TO BE. It's a screenplay. That is okay. What is NOT okay is how poorly this is made. She didn't even read the script. I have to believe she didn't care because none of the characters are in character. They are horrible people- kids included. Just...all terrible and disfunctional.

The magic is missing. The dialogue is very weak, the kind that a twelve-year old would use in their own version of a sequel to Harry Potter after eating too much sugar.  Stuff happens horribly and inexplicably, just plot devices to make this pulsating mass of garbage seem to work. It is bad. Just...I've read fanfiction like this and said 'NOPE!' on the first page and never read it again and yet people eat it up because they think JK did it. It is as if one of those crappy fics got published. And J.K. dares call these two horrible writers her 'dream team'. I am never buying anything from her again if other people are involved. It's nightmare fuel.

It is...all so, SO bad.

Not even a trace of her work in there and the discrepancies between everything- characters, world she built, spells and the way she made the world to be after war - are painfully obvious. It's like a bad fanfiction. Blind fanaticism is just making everyone rave but it is honestly a very poor work of fiction for anyone. The fact that this is cannon makes matters worse.

Fans, please! I beg you! Don't praise this piece of crap. It's money milking at its finest and it will only lead to very poor quality in the future until the series dies a horrible death. Tell it as it is. It's bad and she shouldnt have praised it or even approved it. Reading it and writing it should've been her job, not some random stranger who apparently never read the books.

author: Roonitoons
title: An enormous disappointment for Potter fans and misleading to those who are new to the world
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2016
content:
I'm not sure what happened here. The only thing I can guarantee is that JK Rowling had nothing to do with the crafting of this story.

Reading a play is an inherently different experience from reading a novel, of course. Novels like the Potter series are full of rich narration and world building, whereas a play is reliant almost solely on the quality of the dialogue. Nuances in character development and narrative must come to life in the dialogue, even when watching a stage production, because true theater doesn't rely on sets, scenery or special effects. Reading the play should be comprable to seeing it live: of course, quality actors bring it to life, but seeing King Lear in person isn't generally any more powerful than reading the incredible script in your living room.

Was I naive for hoping for this kind of quality? Probably not, considering the playwrights are so accomplished. The dialogue in Rowling's books was, admittedly, not the most compelling, but her narrative and world building made up for it. Absent that, and absent a writer with a gift of crafting character interactions, this book was a massive disaster.

It truly does read like bad fanfiction, with massive leaps of logic and plot holes that are impossible to swallow and one-dimensional, cookie-cutter characters (something I think the Potter books avoided foxily).

As a lifelong Potter fan, I can't really accept this as canon, and I hope that those new to the Potter universe will avoid this chapter in the saga entirely.

author: CR
title: Harry Potter and the Spoilers
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content:
Let me start by saying that I am an AVID Harry Potter fan. I have read each book more times than I can count, and know each line of the movie. And, perhaps, that is my downfall with this book. Because as much as this book may have the Harry Potter logo, it cannot ever truly be a work of JK Rowling.
I have heard wonderful reports of this play. However, I believe that therein lies the fault of this book. It was meant to be seen. Not read.
The characters are hollow and two-dimensional. As someone who has read the series several times over, I just can't picture the characters saying the words that they are assigned. (Harry telling his son that he regrets having him? Seriously?) They change the personalities of the characters, changing Ron to a wanna-be funny guy, and Ginny from a strong willed partner, to a push-over.
To make matters worse, Harry's son Albus, the main character, is a brat. End of story. He is mean, selfish, and extremely dramatic.
The stories plot centers around time turners, evoking an old storyline, and bringing back an old enemy, Lord Voldemort. To me, this made the story lack any originality.
Bottom line, this book wasn't what I was expecting.

author: Ravenhoot
title: I wish Gilderoy Lockhart could Obliviate this book from my memory. It's worse than bad fan-fiction.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2018
content:
I would give this book zero stars if I could. First and foremost, because it's not a book. It's a script. Second, it is NOT a Harry Potter book and it was NOT written by JK Rowling. It was endorsed by her and she was consulted for continuity (which seems ridiculous because this book DESTROYS the continuity established in Harry Potter books 1-7).

This review will be chock full of spoilers and I won't feel bad about it one bit. Can you tell I'm bitter? GOOD. Let me tell you why before I get into the reasons this book was a complete disaster. I turned 11 years old on September 1st, 1998. That's right - my birthday is the same day the Hogwarts Express departs Kings Cross to return to Hogwarts. That also means I turned 11 two months after Sorcerer's Stone was published in the United States. I grew up with those books. With the exception of the first book, I went to every single midnight book release and all 8 midnight movie premieres (yes, my parents were cool and took me to the bookstore at midnight when I was 12). I grew up with Harry & co. I AM part of the Harry Potter Generation. These books are my childhood. They mean more to me than I can put into words. While it was bittersweet to close The Deathly Hallows on July 21st, 2007 (because I did go straight home and read the entire thing in one sitting) after reading "All was well," it was with a finality that the series had wrapped up and reached a satisfying conclusion. Okay, the epilogue did feel a bit fan-fictiony but we let that slide for the most part. But overall, Harry Potter fans were content.

From there, we gave hundreds if not thousands of hints to Ms. Rowling that if she was ever so inclined to revisit the wizarding world, we would absolutely ADORE a book series on James Potter and the Marauders' years at Hogwarts. Sirius as a teenager and all of the shenanigans that must have happened - the creation of the marauder's map, the trial and error of becoming animagi, James' shameless attempts at wooing Lily? YES PLEASE. But our pleas fell on seemingly deaf ears. Jo was adamant that she would never write another Harry Potter book. And she didn't. Now comes Cursed Child. I won't even refer to it by it's full name because it doesn't deserve the honor of being introduced as a Harry Potter book.

Imagine my delight when almost 10 years later, the world is quivering with anticipation at the release of ANOTHER HARRY POTTER BOOK! It was common knowledge that there was a stage play by the same name and the story was the same, but it wasn't explicitly mentioned that the book was going to be nothing more than a script of the play. It was marketed as a novel. So at 28 years old, did I go to the bookstore for the midnight release? Of course I did! My husband said he expected nothing less. I clutched that book like it was a portal that would return me to my childhood. I went home and immediately started reading, just as I'd done with the previous installments. My excitement was premature, however, since the longer I read, the angrier and more resentful I became. The story just got worse the further into I got. At any point, I could have just set it aside and said, "Absolutely not. I won't continue to read this garbage." But I personally cannot leave a book unfinished. So I finished it. And I hated every bit of it.

Cursed Child is not written by JK Rowling. I mentioned that once before. It is an enormous slap in the face to all the fans of Harry Potter who expected a continuation of the story they came to love so dearly. Now I will list some of the many reasons why it is a complete nightmare (in no particular order because I don't care enough to order them chronologically):

1. The kind, endearing trolly witch who sells sweets on the Hogwarts Express is actually an immortal train guardian who turns pumpkin pasties into grenades and defends the train from intruders. Okay, so where was she when the Dementors attacked the train in Prisoner of Azkaban, then?

2. Adult Ron helps run Weasley Wizard Wheezes and gives his nephew Albus a love potion. This is HIGHLY unlikely since love potions are essentially the wizarding world's equivalent of a date-rape drug and Ron unknowingly took one in their 6th year at school. I seriously doubt he would encourage the use of them after that incident.

3. The ENTIRE mess of the time-turner. To summarize, Albus and Scorpius use a time turner to go back in time to when Harry & co. were students to attempt to change the past. I honestly don't even remember why because I don't care. But the entire thing is ridiculous. Time turners were supposed to have been destroyed when Harry & co. broke into the Department of Mysteries in their 5th year. Hermione had to turn the time turner three times to go back three hours... Albus & Scoripus went back DECADES. Were they just sitting there turning the time turner thousands of times? One of the alternative timelines they create is one where Voldemort wins and rules the world. It's not pretty. But is also makes NO sense.

4. During one of their trips back in time, they messed up the timeline so Hermione didn't trust the Durmstrang students in their 4th year, leading her not to go to the Yule Ball with Viktor, leading Ron not to get jealous, which led to him and Hermione never getting married. That's pretty far fetched and a bit insulting to suggest that jealousy was the only reason Ron had feelings for Hermione. Oh and apparently since Hermione didn't marry Ron, she stayed single and became a DADA professor... and was meaner and more spiteful than Snape. Sorry, what? I find it REALLY hard to believe that Hermione would become this bitter spinster just because she didn't get married.

5. Harry is a terrible father. He actually tells Albus at one point that there are times he wished he didn't have him. First, what father is going to tell his kid that? Maybe a really detached father like Lucius Malfoy, but HARRY FREAKING POTTER would not say that to his kid. Especially when he grew up without parents in a household that didn't love him. Did the author of this monstrosity even open a real Harry Potter book before writing this script? Methinks not.

6. Harry is still a parselmouth. That makes no sense, since he only had that ability from the piece of Voldemort's soul that made Harry an unintentional Horcrux. When Voldemort destroyed that piece of his own soul, Harry should have lost that ability. That's just sloppy writing and poor fact checking.

7. Harry finally landed his dream job of being an Auror and he's like "ehh, whatever" about it.

8. In this alternate timeline garbage, Cedric Diggory didn't die in the Triwizard Tournament but instead, became a Death Eater. Yep, you read that right. He also killed Neville during the Battle of Hogwarts in Deathly Hallows. Were the writers just trying to piss off as many HP fans as possible?

9. Teddy Lupin. Remember him? Precious newborn orphan of Remus Lupin and Tonks and godson of Harry Potter? Well, Jack Thorne certainly didn't. Teddy does not appear in this book AT ALL. I get he would be 19 at the time and not at Hogwarts anymore... but it was pretty insulting to leave him out completely.

And the worse and quite possibly the biggest reason why I will never, ever accept this book as canon...

10. Voldemort and Bellatrix Lestrange had a secret lovechild named Delphi. I can't even begin to explain the reasons why this is not okay, but I'll try. First, the logistics just aren't there. Bellatrix died in the Battle of Hogwarts, so unless she had JUST given birth when exactly was she supposed to have had this child? Bellatrix was devoted to her master, sure, but who thought devotion translated into... that?! Bellatrix was married, or did everyone just forget that detail? Second, Voldemort was incapable of feeling normal human emotion. He thought it beneath him. He was obsessed with being immortal, but HE himself wanted to be immortal. He wouldn't have bought into that whole "ensuring his bloodline carried on" because he was making sure HE would never die - so why would he need an heir? The entire concept is just laughable.

The long and short of it is that Cursed Child is worse than fan-fiction. Honestly, that's even an insult to fan-fiction, because I've read plently of fan fics that are exponentially better than Cursed Child. So do yourself a favor - skip this and go to Archive of our Own and read some quality fanfic instead. There's some really great ones out there - ones that keep characterizations true and don't feel the need to take the continuity and put it in a blender. If you do own this book, I'm sorry. Take my lead and remove it from your bookshelves; put it somewhere that you won't have to see it and have the cosntant reminder of it. Lockhart was a terrible wizard, but he was exceptionally good at memory charms. I wish he was around to perform one on me so I could forget this book existed.

You let us down, Jo.

author: Lisa Girardi

author: Sharasa Kerbouchard
title: Words cannot describe my disappointment
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content: I am a very big fan of Harry Potter. I have read and re-read the entire series more times than I can count. I own 8 different sets of the books in a variety of formats so I always have access to them. I had been eagerly looking forward to reading this latest installment in the series and had pre-ordered my copy months ago. That said, words cannot describe how incredibly disappointed I was with this book. I knew it was not a novel. I had accepted that. In fact, that was the least of the problems in the reading. I knew that it was not written entirely by J.K. Rowling. I had, however, assumed (incorrectly, it seems) that since she had given her approval and blessing to the story that it was worthy of her name. I was sadly mistaken.  SPOILER ALERT  Having hoped for a reunion with all the old characters and perhaps an introduction to some new ones, I was very disappointed to see our old friends so flat and out of character. Yes, people change over time, but these were almost resembling the "Horcrux Harry and Horcrux Hermione" of the final book in the sense that they were similar to our characters yet horribly different. In this case, they were flat.  They acted and spoke in ways the original characters would never have done. Even the photo of Dumbledore was a caricature of his former self. I read the entire book, however, as I did, I found myself anxious to finish and dispose of it. Canon or no, this will not be joining my beloved sets of books.  I have seen fan fiction that is better than this.  Indeed, it is written like a poorly executed piece of fanfic. There were so many different ways the characters of Albus and Scorpius could have been developed. And why, after having lived in a magical world for so many years where people routinely lived to be hundreds of years old, are the characters dying so young?  We are led to believe that Malfoys are gone, that the parents of many of their former classmates are gone, that professors are gone. I do not understand why this has happened, and there is little in the way of explanation. Overall, I was very disappointed in the writing quality. Perhaps the stage version is richer and more detailed than what we see here, and I truly hope it is, but if given my choice at this moment, I certainly would not pay to see this performed.

date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2016

author: Harley R.
title: Glad it was compressed into a script and not an 800 page novel.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2016
content: I have been a Harry Potter fan since 2000. I avidly read the original seven books several times a year, I have a half sleeve of more than thirty different pieces from the HP series, I have countless amounts of merchandise, I have three complete sets (hardback, paperback, and French paperback) of the series, etc., and yet... This story was a complete disappointment. The script part was fine, no complaints there, but the story and characters within that script are just so awful. How did our beloved characters become so lifeless and at times cruel? How did this plot get approved when it breaks so many rules Rowling herself wrote? I understand playwrights wrote it and only based their story off of Rowling's work, but I don't know how Rowling endorsed it. I have honestly read better fan-fiction on the internet. With that being said, I'm sure this story is lovely when it is performed live. But much like "A Very Potter Musical", I refuse to adapt "Cursed Child" into the Harry Potter canon. By all means, go see the play and/or read this script, but my advice is to watch/read it as fan-fiction and not as a real continuation of the Potterverse.

author: NyteScrybe
title: Has Rowling Gone Fanfic?
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2016
content: It was just okay.  To me, it read like a fanfic, scratched out in the dead of night under the covers and with a flashlight by a lonely Scorpius/Albus shipper.  If I want to read fanfiction...and I DON'T...there are plenty of places to go for free.  It isn't even that this is a play; I knew that going in.  It's the out-of-character personalities, inconsistencies, plot holes, and mostly, the fanfic tripe (give me a freakin' break) are a turn-off.  I gave it one star only because I enjoyed seeing Snape again.  Lacking a Time-Turner, I'm going to perform a Confundus charm on myself to forget this ever happened.

author: Emily
title: They shot themselves in the foot...*SPOILERS*
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
I'm a hardcore HP fan, but I went into this with modest expectations and I was still let down. It was a quick read, but I only pushed through to the end so I could be accurately critique it. As I see it, there are three main problems:
1) The characters are not done any justice. They're unrecognizable. Did the playwright even read the books before he did this?
2) MAJOR continuity problems, both against the backdrop of the original series and within the story itself. Cedric became a Death Eater. The book skipped completely over mentioning that before Scorpius goes to research it. Why did the Trolley Witch chase them out and explain that not even the sneakiest had ever escaped her, and then they just...do...? They can't find Albus and Scorpius. Didn't they use magic when they jumped the train? Don't they have the trace on them? They see the Potters in their house in Godric's Hollow the day they die. The house was protected by the fidelius charm, so they shouldn't be able to see it...right? How did they get the blanket to leave a message on it then get it back to Baby Harry? When exactly was Bellatrix supposed to be pregnant? You know you can't make Polyjuice potion in one afternoon, right? And Voldemort is in power again and everyone is allowed to/not scared to say his name? I could go on, but you get the point. They're amateur writing mistakes.
3) There is none of the zest and humor and gripping plot twists of Rowling's original world. It doesn't read like her and I can't figure out how she got talked into putting her name on it.
I hope it goes off better on stage, but they really shouldn't have tried to milk the cash cow by publishing it. All they've managed to do is tick off a lot of hard core fans who can easily expose its many flaws.

author: W. Fu
title: Dissapointment
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2016
content:
This book, if you can call it that, is unreadable. I'm a big fan of the Harry Potter series, both books and movies. I wouldn't classify myself as a fanatic, I can't recite lines or remember the names of each spell but I have always thoroughly enjoyed the series. The first seven books were so well written, Rowling took you on a journey and you felt everything she described. She portrayed each character, big roll or small roll, with all the same detail. You hated Potter's cousin and you could just picture what he looked like each time he spoke.
Fast forward to this book, upon seeing this I was super excited. I pre-ordered on Amazon and counted down the weeks until it arrived. I had already expected a play format (was not enthused) and understood that most likely Rowling did not write much or any of this book but was excited nonetheless. First day, I downloaded the book and started reading and it was completely unreadable. It felt like a poorly written fan fiction, now I don't know if it's because the author or because it's a script. I understand that as it's adapted from a play, the audience can visually see the characters and don't need it described to them. If that's the case, then this book is just a lazy way to make $$$$$$$$$$.
Thorne barely described the characters and I had no idea what Potter's boy looked like. Each character sounded like they were pouting and complaining without any real plot. I ended up reading 20% of this on my Kindle and had to return it. I read the rest of the plot on Wikipedia and it was much more satisfying.
Save your money and time, read the wikipedia version, I think it has more details than this "book".

title: 13 year old Potter-head says it's not worth the paper it's printed on.

content:
I bought this book for my 13 year old daughter because she desperately wanted it and because she's read all of J.K. Rowling's books. I couldn't  believe how disappointed she was after reading it in one day. She hated this book and said it was the worst book ever by Rowling. She said the character development was poor, story line poor, and all in all, not worth the paper it was printed on. I was shocked because J.K. Rowling is like a god in your home and she has several copies of each and every book in the Potter series.
I didn't read it myself and I am not a potter-head, but my daughter is and I will take her word for it. In fact, she was scheduled to go on an Alaskan cruise and wanted to cancel so she could wait in line at B&N to be among the first to get this book. I spent an hour convincing her that the Alaska trip was a better choice and that I would get the book and have it for her upon her return.  I did and she read it the day after her vacation cruise. Sorry to say folks -- and I mean no disrespect, but JK missed the mark on this one.

title: Love J. K

author: aggieback
title: Disappointed
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2016
content: Sigh. I am an avid reader and a huge fan of Harry Potter. J.K Rawlings's well thought out original series is one of my favorites. This composition was just bad. Of all the rich possibilities to consider, to use a cliche plot device and rehash the old storyline was just disappointing. In fact, it was ridiculous to think that you-know-who would have a child. It comes off as a poorly written play designed purely to cash in on the Harry Potter legacy. Read it if you want, but be prepared to be disappointed.

author: Reagan
title: Barely Potter And The Cursed Read
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2016
content:
I understood what this book was going to be before i took the leap. Page after page i read knowing it had to stand on it's own merits and not in the shadow of the first 7 books. That my friend... is exactly where it fell short. The story from start to finish, the characters and ultimate outcome is so incredibly lackluster and inconsequential that it breaks my heart. Remove Harry's name from the cover and what you have left is a bland, uninteresting story and characters that you have to struggle to connect with. I wish i could give the book four thumbs down but unfortunately i only have two so that will have to suffice.
Although Harry Potter isn't the main character in this book, and it hardly matters, the story and characters feel lifeless and the finished product feels more like a rough draft that wasn't fully fleshed out.

"It was always difficult being Harry Potter and it isn’t much easier now that he is an overworked employee of the Ministry of Magic, a husband and father of three school-age children."

And lastly, the "formula" that worked so well in the original books is nowhere to be found. The universal appeal of Harry Potter is that adults can remember being children and wanting to have magical powers and go on adventures and most present day children want to have magical powers and go on adventures. Who in their right mind, young or old wants to grow up to be an overworked employee that has no time to spend with their family? J.K Rowling and her cohorts have clearly been getting their ideas from the George Lucas School Of How To Destroy Your Own Legend. Sorry for the rant. Very disappointed in what could have been an amazing story.

author: Amazon Customer
title: One Star
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2016
content: Storyline was boring.

author: T. D. Joyner
title: A horrible excuse for a book in the Harry Potter universe

content: A horrible excuse for a book in the Harry Potter universe. If you're one of the few people who actually liked the epilogue at the end of The Deathly Hallows then this book might speak to you, but if you hated the epilogue you're going to hate this book even more.

title: Just pretend like this doesn't exist
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2019
content: I was so excited to read this and hugely let down especially by Harry's personality,,; he really didn't feel like the same character at all

author: Amazon Customer
title: Never Thought I'd Say It
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2016
content: I was so insanely excited when I found out that we were going to get the Harry Potter and the Cursed Child script as a book. I could not wait, finding out was one of the happiest days of my life. I did not get to attend the midnight release but I'm glad I didn't. This is not Harry Potter, not even a tiny bit, it's not even good fanfiction, I have read much better. If it was fanfiction and I'd  have read the description and have passed it right on by. I am beyond disappointed in this book's storyline and treatment of characters, I was prepared for the script read which takes a lot away so I never expected it to be the literary masterpiece the other books were but this goes far beyond that. This goes beyond disappointment, this book destroys the Harry Potter world as we know it, nothing is the same, all the rules have been changed and turned on their heads. I've seen so many spoilers and it doesn't even bother me, they can't ruin it because I hate this book, it is awful. I wanted to make it through it because I feel you should be knowledgeable about something if you want to have an opinion on it, but just a quarter of the way through (all of which has been agonizing and forced, making me not want to read for the first time in my life) I don't know if I can go on. It has already done enough damage to the wonderful Harry Potter that I hold so dear. This is not the Harry Potter that taught us compassion and understanding, that the world isn't black and white, the importance of friendship, love, and loyalty, that made our generation one of the most tolerant and had both children and adults who hated reading doing exactly that. This is not Harry Potter. I never thought I would say it but I am GLAD it's over.

author: DJJ
title: Reads like a bad fanfic
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2016
content:
I really can't wrap my head around her putting her name on this.

Cons:
Reads like a bad fanfic.
Characters don't act like themselves.
Unbearably cheesy at some points.
The plot literally is impossible if you are following the established rules for time travel from the series.
Villain is so obvious, I literally said "oh there's the plot twist villain" at the first mention of this character.
It might work as a play (I haven't seen it) but it simply doesn't work as a book its far too short. I wasn't remotely invested in Albus or Scorpius or their friendship.

author: Captain Skyhawk
title: Well so much for that...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content: Aw well. :( I knew that this was going to be written as a play, I love Harry Potter and I do my research. I was so excited for this book and the script format is not why this book gets a one star review.  I'm sure it makes for an interesting play, but I refuse to believe that this story is canon. So much contradicts the logic of the original books that it just can't be canon.  It does nothing to add to the story and it taints the integrity of every character in the books from Harry, to Cedric, even the Trolly Witch.  This book does not add to the  original story, it cruelly subtracts from it. I'll always love Harry Potter, always, and that's exactly why I do not like this book. Although I'm going to pretend this is just some weird published fan fic and read the original books without imagining weird time travel bs all up in my grill.

author: Katie O.
title: JK is nowhere near this book
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2017
content: So so so bad. I can't believe JK signed off on this. I understand writing needs to be different for stage than for lit, but this was just BAD writing. Literally every character has terrible cheesey lines, super flat dialogue, and no unique voice. Even the well-established veteran characters (Harry, Hermione, Ron, Draco) all read as indistinct (with the exception of Ron who apparently becomes a bumbling fool in his 40s, making jokes that I suppose were supposed to be corny dad jokes, but just make him sound stupid). It's disappointing that the authors didn't just commit to the homosexual relationship they were establishing between the two main characters, at least that would have made it a little more valuable as an HP story, culturally - even if the writing is garbage.

author: Matt west
title: I love the first 7 Potter books
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2016
content: First off, I love the first 7 Potter books. I've read most of them 10+ times. This script was pure garbage. It really was not even the fact that it was a script that made it so terrible. That dialogue was just awful. None of the lines seem like anything any of the characters would really ever say. Everything seemed off. The plot was forced and awful, and nothing flowed. The lines were absurd, particularly Ron's lines. If someone had not read the original books they would read this one and think Ron was mentally handicapped. This book not only fails to add to my love of the Potter world, but it detracts from it. This is the most disappointing book I have ever read in my life. JK Rowling was a genius in the first 7 books, and in some of the accompanying small books. This doesn't even seem like she wrote ANY of it. Any competent college student with macbook could have written another book. I'm SO mad that when JK Rowling finally released another Potter book/script that it was this bad. She either has lost her touch, or is a total sell out for the money. Shame on you JK Rowling.

content: The story was good but I didn't like the way it was put into a play form.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Disappointing...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content:
To start this off, like other reviewers here... I also grow up with Harry Potter.

It was so obvious that J.K. Rowling, even though her name's written the biggest, has so little to do with the script.

EVERYONE WAS SO OUT OF CHARACTER. Every dialogue was unnatural and the plot is as ridiculous as a Boggart. Do they really want us to believe that Draco, as kind as he has become, has the pride to admit that he was envious of Harry's friendship?! That Ron is a useless moron who crack jokes all the time without offering any help?! That Hermione is as useless as Ron, just with more dialogues?! That Harry isn't getting along with his son just because Albus is different when Harry himself was different his entire life?!

The plot has many plot holes and doesn't even add up to the previous stories. It feels like the writers are some amateurs writing a fan fiction online. I don't mind whether this is a script or a novel, but to call this an OFFICIAL continuation of Harry Potter is just trash. I'm going to treat this as I treat Mean Girls 2, this book never existed.

But, hey, if you want to get nostalgic, just buy it. But keep your hopes lower than the lowest.

author: DLT
title: This is NOT a HP Book
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2016
content:
Let me start off by mentioning two very important point about myself as a reader: 1. I hate paying for shipping and will go out of my way to avoid it 2. I am a massive Harry Potter Fan. In fact, in preparation of reading this book I reread all the Harry Potter books. Not that I wasn't going to anyway, but it was a lovely excuse. Moving on, I have decided not only to return this book, but to pay money to return it. It cannot sit on my shelf amongst the other HP books. I refuse. There are basically three reasons why this book is not a HP book and after I have returned it and finished this review I am going to promptly forget it ever existed:
1. This is not written nor does it sound like JK Rowling. This "story" may have been "based on a JK Rowling story" but it just does not seem like it. It truly seems more like a poorly developed fan fic. JK Rowling is seamless, sophisticated. She doesn't allow for many mistakes to be made. It often felt like whoever wrote this play didn't even read the HP books but merely watched the movies. Big Mistake.
2. The story is poorly developed and poorly executed. As I mentioned, there are a ton of mistakes made. I won't go into them as other reviews have beautifully listed them. So if you want a list of all the mistakes made and the impossibilities according to previous books, look at some of the other longer reviews.
3.  The characters, our characters, our beautiful trio, does not sound/act/speak or do anything like they generally would. Ron is an imbecile throughout this novel, Hermione isn't terribly bright, Harry isn't himself, not at all, and the new characters we are introduced to aren't well developed.  The author (whoever it is) doesn't mention key characters like Teddy. Not to mention the direction they do go in with the plot is just beyond ridiculous. The author seems to spend more time on Cedric Diggory than he does on Ron or Hermione.

While reading this book I continued to keep in mind that this book is written as a play, that reading a play is different from reading a novel, and that as a play you will not get the same emotional insight as you would in a novel. Apparently it is very good watching this play on stage. However, as a book, I cannot and do not like this and for me, it is not "the next installment" but a poorly written and poorly developed fan fic turned into a play. I am so disappointed. I can't even believe JK Rowling approved this for publication.
